courses.title: Principles of Accounting I
courses.description: A study of the underlying theory and application of financial accounting concepts. These concepts include measurement principles, financial statement preparation, and introductory financial analysis.

courses.title: Principles of Accounting II
courses.description: A study of the underlying theory and application of managerial accounting concepts. These concepts include cost measurement, decision making, budgeting, and variance analysis.

courses.title: Aerospace Systems Design Competition I
courses.description: Team-oriented aerospace systems design project directed by a faculty advisor.  Typically a national student competition in aircraft, rotorcraft, or spacecraft design. Technical role commensurate with freshman standing.

courses.title: Introduction to Aerospace Engineering
courses.description: Overview of aerospace engineering. Common terminology, introduction to use of engineering models, professional and ethical standards and experience with team-based design of aerospace systems. Students cannot receive credit for both AE 1601 and AE 1350.

courses.title: Introduction to Bioengineering
courses.description: An introduction to the field of bioengineering, including the application of engineering principles and methods to problems in biology and medicine, the integration of engineering with biology, and the emerging industrial opportunities. Crosslisted with BMED, CHE, ECE, ME, and MSE 1750.

courses.title: Thermodynamics & Fluids Fundamentals
courses.description: Thermodynamic and fluid properties. Conservation laws, Isentropic flow, shocks and expansions, introduction to flows with friction and heat transfer. Applications to aerospace devices. Students cannot receive credit for both AE 2010 and AE 3450.

courses.title: AE 2010 Recitation
courses.description: This recitation is an optional session in support of AE 2010. This course is designed to allow students the chance to apply their knowledge of concepts through problem solving and group discussions.

courses.title: Fluid Fundamentals
courses.description: Flowfield concepts, fluid properties, conservation equations for flows, isentropic flow, shocks and expansions, introduction to flows with friction and heat transfer. Applications to aerospace devices.

courses.title: AR 2011 Recitation
courses.description: This recitation is an optional session in support of AE 2011. This course is designed to allow students the chance to apply their knowledge of concepts through problem solving and group discussions.

courses.title: Dynamics
courses.description: Motion of particles and mass center of bodies, kinematics and kinetics of rigid bodies in plane motion, work-energy and impulse-momentum methods, 3-D dynamics of rigid bodies.

courses.title: AE 2220 Recitation
courses.description: This recitation is an optional session in support of AE 2220. This course is designed to allow students the chance to apply their knowledge of concepts through problem solving and group discussions.

courses.title: 3D Dynamics
courses.description: Kinematics and kinetics of rigid bodies in three-dimensional motion.

courses.title: AE 2221 Recitation
courses.description: This recitation is an optional session in support of AE 2221. This course is designed to allow students the chance to apply their knowledge of concepts through problem solving and group discussions.

courses.title: Aerospace Systems Design Competition II
courses.description: Team-oriented aerospace systems design project directed by a faculty advisor. Typically a national student competition in aircraft, rotorcraft, or spacecraft design.  Technical role commensurate with sophomore standing.

courses.title: Introduction to Experimental Methods in Aerospace
courses.description: Introduction to laboratory instrumentation and measurement techniques used in aerospace. Basic application of sensor principles, uncertainty analysis, interpretation and analysis of experimental data, and documentation.

courses.title: Technical Communications for Aerospace Engineers
courses.description: Development of technical communication skills required by aerospace engineers. Includes written, oral and visual communication methods.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research Assistantship
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Normally taken by sophomores. Course material devoted to special topics in aerospace engineering.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Normally taken by sophomores. Course material is devoted to special topics in aerospace engineering.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Normally taken by sophomores. Course material devoted to special topics in aerospace engineering.

courses.title: Special Problems
courses.description: Research topic selected in consultation with advisor. A brief description, endorsed by the faculty advisor, must be approved by the School.

courses.title: Special Problems
courses.description: Research topic selected in consultation with advisor. A brief description, endorsed by the faculty advisor, must be approved by the School.

courses.title: Special Problems
courses.description: Research topic selected in consultation with advisor. A brief description, endorsed by the faculty advisor, must be approved by the School.

courses.title: Aerodynamics
courses.description: Aerodynamics of airfoils and wings in subsonic, transonic and supersonic flight. Laminar and turbulent boundary layers and effects of viscosity on aerodynamic performance.

courses.title: Aerodynamics Recitation
courses.description: Recitation course for AE 3030.

courses.title: Numerical Methods for Aerospace Engineering
courses.description: Basic numerical methods in Aerospace Engineering taught in Fortran or C, language instruction included.  Numerical integration, interpolation, FFT, linear algebra, initial and boundary value problems.

courses.title: Structural  Analysis
courses.description: Application to structural analysis. Basic equations of elasticity. Bending, shearing and torsion of thin walled structures. Energy methods for structural analysis and application to finite element theory for trusses and beam structures. Students cannot receive credit for both AE 3140 and AE 3125.

courses.title: Introduction to Aerospace Vehicle Performance
courses.description: Orbital mechanics, orbit determination, and spacecraft maneuvers. Basics of airplane flight including climb, cruise, takeoff, and landing. Actuator disk theory and elements of rotorcraft performance.

courses.title: Design and Systems Engineering Methods
courses.description: Overview of aerospace design and systems engineering. Tools to organize the design process and to support design decisions. Introduction to numerical optimization and trade studies.

courses.title: Aerospace Systems Design Competition III
courses.description: Team-oriented aerospace systems design project directed by a faculty advisor. Typically a national student competition in aircraft, rotorcraft, or spacecraft design.  Technical or leadership role commensurate with junior standing.

courses.title: Thermodynamics and Compressible Flow
courses.description: First and second laws of thermodynamics. Thermodynamic properties and state equations. Isentropic flow. Flows with shocks and expansions.  Flows with friction and heat transfer. Students cannot receive credit for both AE 3450 and AE 2010.

courses.title: System Dynamics and Vibration
courses.description: Modeling and analysis of lumped- and distributed-parameter systems, free and forced vibration in mechanical systems, free vibration in structural systems. Students cannot receive credit for both AE 3530 and ME 3017 or AE 3530 and AE 3515.

courses.title: Control System Analysis and Design
courses.description: Control system performance analysis and specifications, classical methods of control system analysis and design, introduction to modern control methods. Students cannot receive credit for AE 3531 and AE 3515 or AE 3531 and ME 4452.

courses.title: Experiments in Fluid and Solid Mechanics
courses.description: Experimental laboratory in solid and fluid mechanics, aerodynamics, propulsion. Emphasis on measurement techniques, analysis and interpretation of data, comparison to analytical predictions, and reporting.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Normally taken by juniors. Course material devoted to special topics in aerospace engineering.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Normally taken by juniors. Course material devoted to special topics in aerospace engineering.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Normally taken by juniors. Course material devoted to special topics in aerospace engineering.

courses.title: Special Problems
courses.description: Research topic selected in consultation with advisor. A brief description, endorsed by the faculty advisor, must be approved by the School.

courses.title: Special Problems
courses.description: Research topic selected in consultation with advisor. A brief description, endorsed by the faculty advisor, must be approved by the School.

courses.title: Special Problems
courses.description: Research topic selected in consultation with advisor. A brief description, endorsed by the faculty advisor, must be approved by the School.

courses.title: Computational Fluid Dynamics
courses.description: Discretization of PDEs, stability and accuracy considerations, iterative and time/space marching schemes, aerospace applications.

courses.title: Aeroacoustics
courses.description: Concepts and techniques, noise sources, data acquisition and reduction, aeroacoustic resonances, commonalities in the music of wind instruments and sources of aircraft noise, community impact.

courses.title: Introduction to Propeller and Rotor Theory
courses.description: A study of the theory and equations used in the design of propellers and helicopter rotors.

courses.title: Rotorcraft Aeromechanics
courses.description: Basic rotor aerodynamics and dynamics, helicopter performance and trim, introduction to helicopter stability, control and vibration.

courses.title: Aerothermodynamics
courses.description: Convective heat transfer and viscous drag in high- temperature and high-speed flowfields. Inviscid hypersonic theory, real gas effects, and wall thermal protection strategies.

courses.title: Finite Element Analysis
courses.description: An introduction to classical approximation techniques and the fundamentals of the finite element-method applied to structures and structural dynamics with aerospace applications.

courses.title: Structural Integrity and Durability
courses.description: Multiaxial stress states, inelasticity in metals and polymers, yield criteria, metal fatigue, fracture, stress intensity factors, fracture toughness, fatigue crack growth, metal creep, and polymer viscoelasticity.

courses.title: Structural Dynamics and Aeroelasticity
courses.description: Structural dynamics of one-dimensional systems. Analysis of static aeroelastic phenomena, unsteady aerodynamics, and flutter.  Equations of motion for complete aeroelastic systems; solution techniques.

courses.title: Aircraft Design I: Conceptual Design
courses.description: Conceptual design and synthesis of fixed wing aircraft.

courses.title: Aircraft Design II: Preliminary Design
courses.description: Preliminary design and synthesis of fixed wing aircraft.

courses.title: Space System Design I: Conceptual Design
courses.description: Conceptual design and synthesis of space systems. Students apply mission and spacecraft design principles.

courses.title: Space System Design II: Mission Design
courses.description: Advanced design applications of space systems. Students apply mission and spacecraft design principles.

courses.title: Rotorcraft Design I: Conceptual Design
courses.description: Conceptual design of traditional, urban air mobility, unmanned rotorcraft vehicles.

courses.title: Rotorcraft Design II: Preliminary Design
courses.description: Preliminary design of traditional, urban air mobility, unmanned rotorcraft vehicles.

courses.title: Aircraft Design
courses.description: Aircraft Vehicle Design. Preliminary design or case study of a complete flight vehicle, including a propulsion system, a structural system, and a control system. Students cannot receive credit for both AE 4341 and AE 4350.

courses.title: Space System Design
courses.description: Spacecraft subsystems and synthesis. Students apply mission and spacecraft design principles in developing a space flight mission concept. Topics may vary. Students cannot receive credit for AE 4342 and AE 4356.

courses.title: Rotorcraft Design
courses.description: Rotorcraft Vehicle Design. Preliminary design or case study of a complete rotorcraft flight vehicle, including a propulsion system, a structural system, and a control system. Students cannot receive credit for both AE 4343 and AE 4358 or AE 4343 and AE 6333.

courses.title: Aerospace Systems Design Competition IV
courses.description: Team-oriented aerospace systems design project directed by a faculty advisor.  Typically a national student competition in aircraft, rotorcraft, or spacecraft design. Technical or leadership role commensurate with senior standing.

courses.title: Space Flight Operations
courses.description: This course introduces the foundations and analysis of space flight operations for human and robotic space missions.

courses.title: Life Cycle Cost Analysis
courses.description: Modeling of total cost of complex systems over their entire life cycle.  Modeling risk uncertainty for complex energy, environmental, and military systems.

courses.title: Accident Causation and System Safety
courses.description: This course provides an in-depth examination of the multi-disciplinary issues in accident causation and system safety (prevention) across different industries.

courses.title: Jet and Rocket Propulsion
courses.description: Principles of aerospace propulsion systems. Thermodynamic cycles. Thermodynamics of combustion. Turbine engine and rocket performance characteristics. Cycle/component analysis of engines and turbomachinery.

courses.title: Advanced Aircraft Propulsion
courses.description: Analysis, preliminary design of turbomachinery and combustors for aircraft; engine design, off-design performance. Introduction to advanced architectures: including scramjets, pressure gain combustion, electric propulsion.

courses.title: Introduction to Combustion
courses.description: Basics of combustion and combustion devices. Chemical thermodynamics, reaction rates, premixed/nonpremixed flames, ignition, stabilization, and pollutants.  Applications in turbine, rocket, and internal combustion engines.

courses.title: Aircraft Flight Dynamics
courses.description: Three-dimensional rigid body dynamics, aircraft equations of motion, static and dynamic stability, flight control design, introduction to aeroelastic phenomena. Students cannot receive credit for both AE 4531 and AE 3521.

courses.title: Spacecraft Flight Dynamics
courses.description: Cover fundamental material in orbit and attitude dynamics. Investigate orbits, rendezvous/intercept maneuvers, interplanetary transfers, attitude coordinates, attitude stability, attitude control, and attitude estimation. Students cannot receive credit for both AE 4532 and AE 4310.

courses.title: Introduction to Humans & Autonomy
courses.description: Learn the fundamental principles underlying the functions performed by humans and by autonomous systems in dynamic, complex domains. Credit will not be awarded for both AE 4552 and AE 6552.

courses.title: Introduction to Avionics Integration
courses.description: Avionics in modern aerospace vehicle systems, including impact on design and performance. Specific case-studies; covers: navigation, GPS, stability augmentation, radar, health monitoring, databases, human factors, and software.

courses.title: Dynamics and Control Laboratory
courses.description: Experiments in dynamics and control related to aerospace engineering topics.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research Assistantship
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Wind Engineering
courses.description: An introductory course on wind energy and its potential; modeling and design of wind turbines; analysis of the economic benefits of wind turbine systems.  Credit not allowed for both AE 4701 and ME 4701.

courses.title: Biofluid Mechanics
courses.description: Introduction to the study of blood flow in the cardiovascular system.  Emphasis on modeling and the potential of flow studies for clinical research application. Crosslisted with CHE and ME 4757.

courses.title: Biosolid Mechanics
courses.description: The mechanics of living tissue, e.g., arteries, skin, heart muscle, ligament, tendon, cartilage, and bone.  Constitutive equations and some simple mechanical models. Mechanics of cells. Applications. Crosslisted with CHE and ME 4758.

courses.title: Engineering Acoustics and Noise Control
courses.description: Study of acoustics related to noise and its control; acoustics terminology wave propagation, wave equation solutions, instrumentation, data processing, room acoustics, noise control, noise legislation. Crosslisted with ME 4760.

courses.title: Mechanical Behavior of Composites
courses.description: Stress-strain behavior of composites, property of matrix and reinforcing materials, mechanics of fiber-reinforced composites, lamina and laminate analysis, and mechanical performance.  Crosslisted with CEE, CHE, ME, MSE, and PTFE 4791.

courses.title: Composite Materials and Processes
courses.description: Basic principles of selection and design of composite materials and their manufacturing and testing. Cost factors. Laboratory exercises on manufacturing and tests. Crosslisted with CEE, CHE, ME, MSE, and PTFE 4793.

courses.title: Composite Materials and Manufacturing Testing
courses.description: Basic principles of selection and sign of composite materials and their manufacturing and testing. Cost factors. Laboratory exercises on manufacturing and tests. Crosslisted with CEE, CHE, ME, MSE, and PTFE 4794.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Normally taken by seniors.  Course material devoted to special topics in aerospace engineering.

courses.description: Special Topics in Aerospace Engineering.

courses.description: Special Topics in Aerospace Engineering.

courses.title: Special Problems in Aerospace Engineering
courses.description: Research topic selected in consultation with advisor. A brief description, endorsed by the faculty advisor, must be approved by the School.

courses.title: Special Problems in Aerospace Engineering
courses.description: Research topic selected in consultation with advisor. A brief description, endorsed by the faculty advisor, must be approved by the School.

courses.title: Special Problems
courses.description: Research topic selected in consultation with advisor. A brief description, endorsed by the faculty advisor, must be approved by the School.

courses.title: Viscous Fluid Flow
courses.description: Fundamental conservation laws.  Laminar flows, wall-bound and free shear flows. Separation, heat transfer, and compressibility effects. Introduction to flow instability and transition to turbulence.

courses.title: Turbulent Flows
courses.description: Basic characteristics of turbulence.  Statistical methods. Reynolds averaging, kinetic energy budget, and scaling issues.  Homogeneity and isotrophy.  Free and wall bounded shear flows. Simulation and modeling.

courses.title: Advanced Aerodynamics
courses.description: Introduce concepts, derivation and application of aerodynamic fundamentals. Emphasis on advanced knowledge in analysis and design of fixed-wing, launch/atmospheric return vehicles, and rotating systems.

courses.title: High-Speed Flow
courses.description: Transonic small disturbance theory. Transonic potential flow modeling. Supercritical airfoil design. Physics of hypersonic flow.  Newtonian flow. Modeling of hypersonic viscous and inviscid flow.

courses.title: Unsteady Aerodynamics
courses.description: Unsteady potential theory for various speed ranges. Calculation of steady and unsteady aerodynamic loads on airfoils and wings.  Vortex flows. Topics of current research interest.

courses.title: Computational Fluid Dynamics
courses.description: Finite-difference, finite volume methods for solution of Navier-Stokes and Euler equations. Classification of equations, stability, grids, boundary conditions, implicit and explicit methods, turbulence modeling.

courses.title: High-temperature Gas Dynamics I
courses.description: Defining equations for compressible flows, real gas properties and their effect on the behavior of equilibrium and non-equilibrium flows.

courses.title: Aeroacoustics
courses.description: Lighthill's theory of aerodynamic noise and extensions, flow/acoustic interactions, feedback phenomenon, supersonic jet noise, aeroacoustics of ducts, propeller noise, helicopter noise, sonic boom.

courses.title: Rotary Wing Aerodynamics
courses.description: Vortex wake modeling; analytical inflow theories; modern computational methods for rotary wing aerodynamic analysis; aerodynamic noise.

courses.title: Dynamics of Turbulence
courses.description: Fundamental physics of turbulent flows.  Vorticity dynamics, Kolmogorov similarity hypotheses and nonlinear interactions. Mixing and dispersion. Direct and large-eddy simulations, Reynolds stress modeling.  Advanced topics.

courses.title: Advanced Structural Analysis I
courses.description: Stability of elastic systems under quasi-static loads. Classical, kinetic, and potential energy approaches through rigid member models.  Buckling of elastic bars and frames. Energy methods.

courses.title: Analysis of Aerospace Structural Elements
courses.description: This course focuses on the analysis of advanced aerospace structures. Beam theory is reviewed, plate theory is introduced.  Classical and energy solutions are presented.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Solid Mechanics
courses.description: Unified overview of fundamental aspects of solid mechanics, from nonlinear continuum mechanics to linear elasticity, including an introduction to energy methods and other special topics.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Aerospace Structural Analysis
courses.description: Overview and fundamentals of aerospace structural analysis, including virtual work and energy methods, buckling and advanced structural theories.

courses.title: Structural Optimization
courses.description: Mathematical methods of constrained optimization, sensitivity analysis, approximation concepts, decomposition techniques, shape optimization in the context of structural design.

courses.title: Advanced Aeroelasticity I
courses.description: Understanding and analysis of aeroelastic phenomena in fixed-wing aircraft, static aeroelasticity, dynamic aeroelasticity, and dynamic response and transient stresses in aircraft structures.

courses.title: Advanced Dynamics I
courses.description: Kinematics of particles and rigid bodies, angular velocity, inertia properties, holonomic and nonholonomic constraints, generalized forces.

courses.title: Advanced Dynamics II
courses.description: A continuation of AE 6210.  Equations of motion, Newtonian frames, consistent linearization, energy and momentum integrals, collisions, mathematical representation of finite rotation.

courses.title: Rotorcraft Structural Dynamics and Aeroelasticity
courses.description: Elementary blade dynamics, flap-lag dynamics, ground resonance, structural dynamics of rotating beams, nonlinear elastic blade analysis, harmonic balance and trim, Floquet theory.

courses.title: Structural Dynamics
courses.description: Dynamic response of single-degree-of-freedom systems, Lagrange's equations; modal decoupling; vibration of Euler-Bernoulli and Timoshenko beams, membranes and plates.

courses.title: Applied Nonlinear Dynamics
courses.description: Nonlinear vibration methods through averaging and multiple scales, bifurcation, periodic and quasi-periodic systems, transition to chaos, characterization of chaotic vibrations, thermodynamics of chaos, chaos control.

courses.title: Optimization for the Design of Engineered Systems
courses.description: Introduction to optimization problem formulations for engineering design, algorithms for constrained nonlinear programming, multiobjective and multidisciplinary optimization, and robust design optimization.

courses.title: Rotorcraft Design I
courses.description: System approach to conceptual design of aerospace systems with emphasis on rotorcraft. Comprehensive methodologies for aerospace vehicle synthesis and sizing. Integration of technologies. Students cannot receive credit for both AE 6333 and AE 4343.

courses.title: Rotorcraft Design II
courses.description: Students work together on this application to complete the preliminary design stage of a specific rotorcraft. Participants are exposed to disciplinary and interdisciplinary issues.

courses.title: Aircraft Design I
courses.description: Stochastic approach to conceptual design of aerospace systems with emphasis on aircraft and missiles. Comprehensive methodologies for aerospace vehicle synthesis and sizing. Integration of technologies.

courses.title: Aircraft Design II
courses.description: Students work together on this application to complete the preliminary design stage of a specific aircraft or missile. Participants are exposed to disciplinary and interdisciplinary issues.

courses.title: Orbital Mechanics
courses.description: First graduate-level astrodynamics class that includes two-body orbital mechanics, orbit determination, orbit prediction, orbital maneuvers, lunar and interplanetary trajectories, orbital rendzvous and space navigation.

courses.title: Planetary Entry, Descent and Landing
courses.description: Entry flight mechanics and dynamics, aerothermodynamics, thermal protection systems, aerodynamic decelerators, descent and landing.  Robotic and human exploration mission studies for aerobraking, planetary entry, aerocapture.

courses.title: Spacecraft Attitude Estimation and Control
courses.description: Attitude representations, dynamics, estimation, and control. Spacecraft attitude sensors and actuators. Attitude determination and control topics applied to spacecraft and space missions.

courses.title: Satellite Orbit Determination
courses.description: Satellite Orbit Determination is a graduate-level course designed to provide the theoretical and practical knowledge to estimate the position of a satellite from tracking measurements.

courses.title: Air Breathing Propulsion System Design I
courses.description: Air breathing propulsion design with emphasis on multidisciplinary design issues related to system integration, cycle selection, performance, cost, reliability, maintainability, etc.

courses.title: Safety by Design
courses.description: Autonomous situational flight model allows students to examine complex behaviors in the "pilot-vehicle-operational conditions" system.  Flight certification and airworthiness requirements are mapped into formal scenarios.

courses.title: Aerospace Systems Engineering
courses.description: Introduction to aerospace systems engineering. Systems engineering and quality engineering methods and tools. Top-down design decision support processes, computer integrated environments, Integrated Product/Process Development (IPPD).

courses.title: Advanced Design Methods I
courses.description: Introduction to modern probabilistic design methods and techniques. Design of experiments, Taguchi methods, response surface equations, robust design, risk and uncertainty, technology assessment and selection.

courses.title: Applied Design Laboratory
courses.description: Introduction to computing tools and processes used in subsequent applied design courses in graduate fixed wing, rotary wing, and space systems design tracks.

courses.title: Introduction to System of Systems Engineering Principles
courses.description: Introduce students to the development and analysis of complex System of Systems, and their practical application to formulate Grand Challenge projects.

courses.title: System of Systems Engineering Applications
courses.description: Application of developed System of Systems analysis frameworks for the performance of Grand Challenge projects.

courses.title: Combustion Dynamics
courses.description: Acoustic wave propagation in inhomogeneous flows, flame-acoustic wave interactions, and control of combustion-driven oscillations.

courses.title: Turbulent Combustion
courses.description: Fundamentals of interaction between flow turbulence and reactive scalars.  Theoretical, numerical, and experimental methods. Physics of premixed, non-premixed, and partially premixed turbulent combustion.

courses.title: Turbine Engine Aerothermodynamics
courses.description: Analysis and design of gas turbine engine components including axial flow compressors, turbines, inlets, and nozzles.  Heat transfer and turbine blade cooling.

courses.title: Rocket Propulsion
courses.description: Analysis and design of rocket engines including liquid, solid, hybrid, and advanced propulsion systems.

courses.title: Electric Propulsion
courses.description: The course provides a solid background of the operating principles, performance characteristics, and design features of the state-of-the-art electric propulsion systems.

courses.title: Helicopter Stability and Control
courses.description: Helicopter general equations of motion, rotor forces and moments, helicopter stability and control characteristics, handling qualities, flight control system design.

courses.title: Random Processes and Kalman Filtering
courses.description: Probability and random variables and processes; correlation; shaping filters; simulation of sensor errors; Wiener filter; random vectors; covariance propagation; recursive least-squares; Kalman filter; extensions.

courses.title: Aerospace Guidance and Navigation
courses.description: Earth's shape and gravity. Introduction to inertial navigation. GPS aiding. Error analysis. Guidance systems. Analysis of the guidance loop. Estimation of guidance variables. Adjoint analysis.

courses.title: Optimal Guidance and Control
courses.description: Euler-Lagrange formulation; Hamilton-Jacobi approach; Pontryagin's minimum principle; Systems with quadratic performance index; Second variation and neighboring extremals; Singular solutions; numerical solution techniques.

courses.title: Mathematical Principles of Planning and Decision-Making for Autonomy
courses.description:
The course will introduce the students to the mathematical tools and the theory 
for formulating and solving problems that involve high-level decision-making for controlling and planning of autonomous systems with an emphasis on aerospace applications.

courses.title: Advanced Flight Dynamics
courses.description: Reference frames and transformations, general equations of unsteady motion, application to fixed-wing, rotary-wing and space vehicles, stability characteristics, flight in turbulent atmosphere.

courses.title: Multivariable Linear Systems and Control
courses.description: Techniques for analysis and description of multivariable linear systems. Tools for advanced feedback control design for these systems, including computational packages. Credit will not be awarded for both AE 6530 and ECE 6550 or AE 6530 and ME 6401.

courses.title: Aerospace Robust Control I
courses.description: Robustness issues in controller analysis and design. LQ analysis, H2 norm, LQR, LQG, uncertainty modeling, small gain theorem, H-infinity  performance, and the mixed-norm H2/H-infinity problem.

courses.title: Aerospace Robust Control II
courses.description: Advanced treatment of robustness issues. Controller analysis and design for linear and nonlinear systems with structured and non-structured uncertainty. Reduced-order control, stability, multipliers, and mixed-mu.

courses.title: Control of Aerospace Structures
courses.description: Advanced treatment of control of flexible structures. Topics include stability of multi-degree-of-freedom systems, passive and active absorbers and isolation, positive real models, and robust control for flexible structures.

courses.title: Cognitive Engineering
courses.description: Cognitive engineering addresses a range of technologies and work environments that will support human cognitive performance, including information systems, decision support, automation, and intelligent systems.

courses.title: Aerospace Nonlinear Control
courses.description: Advanced treatment of nonlinear robust control. Lyapunov stability theory, absolute stability, dissipativity, feedback linearization, Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman theory, nonlinear H-infinity, backstepping control, and control Lyapunov functions.

courses.title: Graduate Internship
courses.description: Graduate Internship for which the student is paid.

courses.title: Wind Engineering
courses.description: An introductory course on wind energy and its potential; modeling and design of wind turbines; analysis of the economic benefits of wind turbine systems. Credit will not be awarded for both AE 6701 and ME 6701.

courses.title: Introduction to Mechatronics
courses.description: Modeling and control of actuators and electro-mechanical systems. Performance and application of microprocessors and analog electronics to modern mechatronic systems.

courses.title: Evaluation of Human Integrated Systems
courses.description: Evaluation of human integrated systems including translating research questions into measurable objectives, overview of evaluation methods and data analysis techniques applicable to such systems.  Credit not allowed for both AE 6721 and ISYE 6231.

courses.title: Acoustics I
courses.description: Fundamental principles governing the generation, propagation, reflection, and transmission of sound waves in fluids.  Crosslisted with ME 6760.

courses.title: Acoustics II
courses.description: Radiation and scattering of sound waves in fluids, duct acoustics, dissipation phenomena. Crosslisted with ME 6761.

courses.title: Applied Acoustics
courses.description: Mufflers, resonators, acoustic materials, barriers, industrial noise, room acoustics, active noise control. Crosslisted with ME  6762.

courses.title: Kinetics and Thermodynamics of Gases
courses.description: Thermodynamics of nonreacting and reacting gas mixtures. Introductory quantum theory, statistical thermodynamics, and gas kinetic theory. Crosslisted with ME 6765.

courses.title: Combustion
courses.description: Introductory chemical kinetics, detonations and deflagrations, laminar flame propagation in premixed gases, ignition and quenching, laminar diffusion flames and droplet burning, turbulent reacting flows. Crosslisted with ME 6766.

courses.title: Linear Elasticity
courses.description: Governing equations of linear elasticity, plane elasticity, boundary value problems, airy stress function and complex variable methods, simple three-dimensional solutions. Crosslisted with ME 6769.

courses.title: Energy and Variational Methods in Elasticity and Plasticity
courses.description: Applications of energy and variational methods in engineering mechanics to elastic, plastic, and dynamical behavior of deformable bodies.  Crosslisted with ME 6770.

courses.title: Dynamic System Simulation and Modeling
courses.description: Models of dynamic systems, such as aircraft, ground vehicles and machinery, and manual control.  Numerical simulation techniques and applications. Interactive simulators. Student programming project.  Crosslisted with ISYE 6779.

courses.title: Robotics Professional Preparation
courses.description: Preparation for a professional career in Robotics. Local & visiting speakers. Program introduction. Technical resume preparation. GT Robotics labs & resources.

courses.title: Robotics Professional Preparation 2
courses.description: Preparation for a professional career in Robotics. Local & visiting speakers. Selecting and applying for Internship. Developing capstone project proposal. Public speaking practice and preparation.

courses.title: Robotics Professional Preparation 3
courses.description: Preparation for a professional career in Robotics. Local & visiting speakers. Interview preparation & career search. Technical report writing and presentation.

courses.title: Acoustic Propagation
courses.description: Propagation of sound in inhomogeneous fluids; ray acoustics, ocean and atmospheric acoustics, nonlinear acoustics. Crosslisted with ME 7764.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Fracture Mechanics
courses.description: Advanced study of failure of structural materials under load, mechanics of fracture, and microscopic and macroscopic aspects of the fracture of engineering materials. Crosslisted with CHE, CEE, ME, and MSE 7772.

courses.title: Advanced Fracture Mechanics
courses.description: Nonlinear fracture mechanics including elastic-plastic and time-dependent fracture, advanced test methods, J-integral theory, and extensions. Crosslisted with CEE, CHE, ME, and MSE 7773.

courses.title: Fatigue of Materials and Structures
courses.description: Mechanical and microstructural aspects of nucleation and growth of cracks under cyclic loading conditions, notch effects, cumulative damage, multiaxial loading, and fatigue crack propagation. Crosslisted with CEE, CHE, ME, and MSE 7774.

courses.title: Topics in Fracture and Fatigue of Metallic and Composite Structures
courses.description: Brittle and ductile fracture criteria. Failrue prediction in composite structures. Free-edge and internal delamination. Anisotropic cracks. Fatigue behavior of composites and metal. New micromechanical models. Crosslisted with CHE, ME, and MSE 7775.

courses.title: Introduction to Robotics Resesarch
courses.description: Familiarizes students with the core areas of robotics; mechanics, control, perception, AI, and autonomy. Provides an introduction to the mathematical tools required in robotics research.

courses.title: Damage, Failure, and Durability of Composite Materials
courses.description: Analysis and failure of fiber-reinforced composite material systems.  Mechanisms of toughening, multiple cracking mechanisms.  Failure in woven fabric, braided, and special geometry composites.  Crosslisted with CHE, CEE, ME, MSE, and PTFE 7791.

courses.title: Advanced Mechanics of Composites
courses.description: Anisotropic elasticity, hygrothermal behavior, stress analysis of laminated composites including 3D effects, stress concentrations, free-edge effects, thick laminates, adhesive and mechanical connections, fracture of composites. Crosslisted with CHE, CEE, ME, MSE, and PTFE 7792.

courses.title: Manufacturing of Composites
courses.description: Major manufacturing techniques of metal-ceramic and polymer-matrix composites.  Modeling of processes with emphasis on fundamental mechanisms and effects. Crosslisted with CHE, CEE, ME, MSE, and PTFE 7793.

courses.title: Design Seminar
courses.description: Case studies of existing aerospace systems; assessment of design payoffs and risks; industry experts provide case examples and knowledge transfer to course participants; field trips.

courses.title: AE Graduate Seminar
courses.description: Introduce AE graduate students to world-class aerospace researchers and topics, discuss and demonstrate basic graduate student resources and skills.

courses.title: Robotics Internship
courses.description: Graduate Internship at a partner company, GTRI or a GT Robotics lab.

courses.title: Robotics Capstone Project
courses.description: Teams or individuals apply the knowledge and skills acquired throughout the MS program to a faculty supervised robotics project.

courses.title: Robotics Research Foundation I
courses.description: Multidisciplinary research course supervised by two robotics faculty from different schools participating in the robotics Ph.D. program.

courses.title: Robotics Research Foundation II
courses.description: Continuation of AE 8751 (Robotics Research Foundation I).

courses.description: Special topics of current interest.

courses.description: Special Topics in AE.

courses.title: Teaching Assistantship
courses.description: For graduate students holding graduate teaching assistantships.

courses.title: Research Assistantship
courses.description: For graduate students holding graduate research assistantships.

courses.title: Scientific Foundations of Health
courses.description: Students will learn how genetics, the environment and human behavior influence well-being.  Topics include health fitness, immunity, nutrition, stress management and chronic disease prevention. Credit not allowed for both APPH 1040 and APPH 1050 or HPS 1040 or APPH 1060.

courses.title: The Science of Physical Activity and Health
courses.description: Students will learn the importance of health fitness, good nutrition, stress management and chronic disease prevention.  Activity portion of course will focus on training to improve fitness.  Credit not allowed for both APPH 1050 and HPS 1040 or APPH 1040 or APPH 1060.

courses.title: Flourishing: Strategies for Well-being and Resilience
courses.description: This course is designed to help students improve their health/well-being and flourish by using conceptual pillars such as coping, resiliency, optimism, mindfulness, and emotional intelligence. Credit not awarded for both APPH 1060 and APPH 1040 or APPH 1050.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Topics of current interest in applied physiology.

courses.title: Special Problems
courses.description: Individual studies in applied physiology.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Topics of current interest in applied physiology.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Topics of current interest in applied physiology.

courses.title: Clinical Gait Analysis
courses.description: Analysis of normal and pathological human locomotion. Study of theory and instrumentation for measurement of temporal and spatial kinematics and kinetics, electromyography, and plantar pressure.

courses.title: Biomechanics and Kinesiology in Prosthetics and Orthotics
courses.description: Mechanics of human movement applied to the study of artifical limbs and braces. Emphasis on neuromuscular control, Newtonian mechanics, kinematics and kinetics.

courses.title: Clinical Pathology
courses.description: Systems level overview of human pathology with emphasis on the effect of disease on human movement and neuromechanical function.

courses.title: Systems Physiology I: Cellular Mechanisms of Plasticity
courses.description: The course will focus on adaptations of skeletal, muscular, and neural systems at the cellular level.

courses.title: Systems Physiology II: Physiology of Neuromotor Tissues
courses.description: The course will focus on function and adaptations of skeletal, muscular, and neural systems. Interactions among the various systems and their plasticity will be emphasized.

courses.title: Systems Physiology III: Integrated Systems and Adaptation
courses.description: The course will focus on integrative mechanism impacting motor system performance. Interactions among the various systems and their plasticity will be emphasized.

courses.title: Laboratory Rotations in Prosthetics and Orthotics
courses.description: This course will provide the opportunity for students in individual laboratories to support their graduate training in prosthetics and orthotics.

courses.title: Studies in Responsible Conduct of Research in Prosthetics and Orthotics
courses.description: This course will cover areas related to research ethics, the responsible use of animial and human models and collaborative research issues in prosthetics and orthotics.

courses.title: Studies in Rehabilitation Research: Prosthetics and Orthotics
courses.description: This course will provide students in the PhD Training Program in Prosthetics and Orthotics to study issues in Rehabilitation Medicine.

courses.title: Biostatistics
courses.description: Introductory statistical principles and methods of experimental design, sampling, power estimation, and hypothesis testing using ANOVA and regression.

courses.title: Exercise Metabolism
courses.description: The course will focus on the biochemical pathways that provide fuel for the human body during rest and various levels of physical activity.

courses.title: Biomechanical Aspects of Human Motor Control
courses.description: The course will examine selected motor control problems that the nervous system faces in the process of managing this mechanical complexity.

courses.title: Locomotion Neuromechanics
courses.description: This is a course that will introduce topics  on the biomechanical and neural aspects of the control of limbed locomotion and movement.

courses.title: The Aging Movement Control System
courses.description: The aim of this course is to review research literature dealing with the effects of advances in age on the CNS and motor performance.

courses.title: Mechanics and Pathomechanics of Movement Control
courses.description: This course is designed to understand the potential effects of selected disorders of the neuromuscular system on movement control.

courses.title: Neuromuscular Physiology
courses.description: This course discusses the application of current experimental techniques in human studies in vivo.

courses.title: Methods of Human Neuroimaging
courses.description: The purpose of the course is to introduce various methods of functional neuroimaging in humans.

courses.title: Ion Channels in Health and Disease
courses.description: This course will examine the structure, function and regulation of ion channels from both excitable and non-excitable cells.

courses.title: Movement Disorders
courses.description: This course serves as an introduction to the clinical and research aspects of movement disorders.

courses.title: Cellular Physiology and Adaptation
courses.description: This course will focus on adaptations of skeletal, muscular and neural systems at the cellular level.

courses.title: Neuromotor Physiology
courses.description: The course will focus on function and adaptations of the skeletal, muscular and neural systems. Interactions among various systems and their plasticity will be emphasized.

courses.title: Integrative Physiology
courses.description: The course will focus on integrative mechanisms impacting motor system performance. Interactions among the various systems and their plasticity will be emphasized.

courses.title: Human Neuroanatomy
courses.description: The purpose of this course is to learn the anatomical makeup of the human nervous system.  In this course we will closely examine details of central and peripheral neuroanatomy with links to function.  As well, comparisons with non-human vertebrate neuroanatomy will be made.

courses.title: Classics in Neuroscience
courses.description: The purpose of this seminar is to learn and explore the history of neuroscience from a perspective of reading classic papers that have evolved.

courses.title: Muscle Structure and Plasticity
courses.description: Covers the biological processes underlying skeletal muscle structure and function, as well as rigorous mathematical models of those processes.

courses.title: Ethics of Biotechnology and Bioengineering Research
courses.description: This course examines the ethics of biotechnological research, including issues in the realm of research ethics, bioethics, and healthcare robotics.

courses.title: Lower Limb Orthotics I
courses.description: This course is the first part of a two course series and sets the essential elements of theory, technical design and patient management.

courses.title: Upper Limb Prosthetics
courses.description: Clinical training for the practice of prosthetics emphasizing adult and pediatric upper limb prostheses.

courses.title: Spinal Orthotics
courses.description: Clinical training for the practice of orthotics emphasizing adult and pediatric spinal orthoses.

courses.title: Upper Limb Orthotics
courses.description: Clinical training for the practice of orthotics emphasizing adult and pediatric upper limb orthoses.

courses.title: Transfemoral Prosthetics
courses.description: Clinical training for the practice of prosthetics emphasizing adult and pediatric transfemoral (above knee) prostheses.

courses.title: Assistive Technology
courses.description: Theories and devices associated with assistive technology and mobility aids, emphasizing topics important to clinical practice in prosthetics and orthotics.

courses.title: Clinical Practicum in Prosthetics and Orthotics
courses.description: Clinical observation of the practice of prosthetics and orthotics and related medical disciplines.

courses.title: Seminar
courses.description: The purpose of this course is for students to learn the research process from the early stage of identifying a question through publication of work.

courses.title: Research Seminar I
courses.description: A forum for graduate students in prosthetics and orthotics to present topics related to their research interests.

courses.title: Research Seminar II
courses.description: A forum for graduate students in prosthetics and orthotics to present and discuss topics related to their research interests.

courses.title: Research Seminar III
courses.description: A forum for graduate students in prosthetics and orthotics to present topics related to their research interests.

courses.title: Elementary Arabic I
courses.description: Introduction to listening, speaking, reading, and writing in Arabic and to the culture of Arabic-speaking regions.

courses.title: Elementary Arabic II
courses.description: Continued listening, speaking, reading, and writing in Arabic with further study of the culture of Arabic-speaking regions.

courses.title: Understanding Arab Culture
courses.description: Arab beliefs and values regarding topics such as religion, society, family, the dynamics between men and women, and social norms are discussed.  Taught in English.

courses.description: A rapid review of grammar with continued use of listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills in Arabic, all with a cultural emphasis.

courses.title: Intermediate Arabic II
courses.description: This course focuses on listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills in Arabic in an introduction to literature and within a cultural context.

courses.title: Arabic Arts, Science and Technology Through History
courses.description: An examination of Arab accomplishments in Sciences, Technology, Philosophy and Art (700-1300 AD) through historical documents, books and movies.  Taught in English.

courses.description: Advanced grammar, listening, reading, writing, speaking, the language of contemporary Arabic society, politics and culture through task-based language teaching.  Taught in Arabic.

courses.title: Advanced Arabic II
courses.description: Listening, reading, writing, speaking the language of contemporary Arabic society, politics and culture through task-based language teaching.  Taught in Arabic.

courses.title: Contemporary Arab Culture
courses.description: This course covers topics in Contemporary Arab Culture in Modern Standard Arabic – such as news stories, cultural debates, contemporary movements, etc. Taught in Arabic.

courses.title: Perspectives on the Arab-Israeli Conflict
courses.description: This course examines diverse perspectives on the Arab-Israeli conflict from literature, film, music, culture, and media in translation.  No previous background required. Taught in English.

courses.title: Introduction to Africa
courses.description: This interdisciplinary course will use a variety of approaches to study significant aspects of contemporary Africa’s societies, cultures, and representations. Taught in English.

courses.title: Men-Women In Islam
courses.description: The course discusses contemporary Arab women and men writers' interpretation of the Qur'an demonstrating the egalitarian and anti-patriarchal nature of its teachings. Taught in English.

courses.title: Intensive Advanced Arabic
courses.description: Develops students' receptive & communicative skills in Arabic while capitalizing on the rich linguistic & cultural surroundings.  Part of ARBC LBAT summer program.

courses.title: Arabic for Business and Technology I
courses.description: The first sequence of two courses in which students learn the linguistic and pragmatic language of business culture in the Arab World.  Taught in Arabic.

courses.title: Arabic for Business and Technology II
courses.description: The continuation of two courses in which students learn the linguistic and pragmatic language of business culture in the Arab World.  Taught in Arabic.

courses.title: Foundation Studio 1
courses.description: Introduction to creative problem-solving and the design realization cycle through project-based design exercises that emphasize the role of representation.

courses.title: Architecture Design Studio 1
courses.description: Introduction to the design of complex problems through an emphasis on integrative and collaborative design strategies, research , critical reflection, and interdisciplinary teamwork.

courses.title: Media + Modeling 1
courses.description: Intermediate approaches to two and three dimensional modeling and representation in architecture using both manual and digital media and techniques.

courses.title: Introduction to Design and the Built Environment
courses.description: Introduction to architecture and building construction through case studies that illuminate past and present practices, as well as future possibilities within the discipline.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special topics in design.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special Topics in design.

courses.title: Architecture Design Studio 2
courses.description: Elementary design exercises exploring fundamental issues of form and space through analysis of architectural elements and compositions and their use in creative problem solving.

courses.title: Architecture Design Studio 3
courses.description: Elementary design exercises focusing upon the compositional integration of building and site through the creative assimilation of programmatic, technical, and contextual requirements.

courses.title: Media + Modeling 2
courses.description: Advanced approaches to two and three dimensional modeling and representation in architecture using both manual and digital media and techniques.

courses.title: History of Architecture I
courses.description: Architectural history from antiquity through the eighteenth century emphasizing buildings in their cultural context as informed by social, technological, and constructive factors and theoretical positions.

courses.title: History of Architecture II
courses.description: Architectural history during the nineteenth and twentieth centuries emphasizing buildings in their cultural context as informed by social, technological, and constructive factors and theoretical positions.

courses.title: Modern Architecture and Art in Europe, America and Australia: Nineteenth and Twentieth Centuries
courses.description: A brief survey of architecture and art in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, including a discussion of related influences on developments in those fields.

courses.title: Construction Technology and Design Integration I
courses.description: Introduction to building anatomy, technical and expressive characteristics of materials and their organizational assembly.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research Assistantship
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special Topics in design.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special Topics in design.

courses.title: REVIT
courses.description: Visualizing a form enhances a designer’s ability to communicate ideas.  Course will demonstrate how REVIT can facilitate the Conception of a design from various points of genesis.

courses.title: Art & Architecture in Greece
courses.description: An intensive on-site investigation of the role that the arts and architecture have played in the development of classical Greek civilization.

courses.title: Art & Architecture in Italy I
courses.description: Investigations of the painting, sculpture, and architecture of the Classical, Early Christian, Byzantine, and Medieval periods in Italy with special emphasis on Rome.

courses.title: Art & Architecture in Italy II
courses.description: Investigations of the painting, sculpture, and architecture of the Renaissance and Baroque Periods in Italy with special emphasis on the works in Rome.

courses.title: Design Strategies
courses.description: The design process as reflection in action. The logic of design decisions. The synthesis of diverse bodies of knowledge in design. Interdisciplinary collaborations in design.

courses.title: Architecture Design Studio 4
courses.description: Intermediate architectural design projects emphasizing the functional priorities and expressive potential of building technologies through studio problems of varying programmatic and contextual complexity.

courses.title: Architecture Design Studio 5
courses.description: Intermediate architectural design projects exploring the inter-relationships of various programmatic models, normative building types, and technological themes within specific physical, urban and cultural contexts.

courses.title: Modern Arch and Art Workshop
courses.description: A brief survey of key ideas of architecture and art in the twenieth century and exploration of their application to current architectural design and representation.

courses.title: Constructing the Visual
courses.description: Promote an understanding of visual representations as they pertain to art, architecture and the use of architecture representations in the structuring of persuasive statements/arguments.

courses.title: City Literacy
courses.description: The course frames the city as material and social space, focusing on everyday experience in exemplary cities to explore how they are conceived and negotiated.

courses.title: Portfolio Design
courses.description: Explores strategies of descriptions, representation, and presentation and other art-related ideas in order to communicate design work and design speculation effectively.

courses.title: Environmental Systems and Design Integration I
courses.description: Human physiology, the occupation of space, and principles of sustainability.  Micro-climate, energy consumption, thermal loading, passive solar strategies, daylighting, optics, and acoustics.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special Topics.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special Topics in design.

courses.title: Structures 1
courses.description: Gravity loads on building structures.  Introduction to structural planning.  Design of wood and steel structures.  Properties of wood and architectural metals.  Computer-based analysis of structures.

courses.title: Architecture Design Studio 6
courses.description: Advanced studies in architectural design emphasizing application of analytical, conceptual, and representational skills within projects that engage and problematize urban context culturally, ecologically and technologically.

courses.title: Architecture Design Studio 7
courses.description: Advanced studies in architectural design emphasizing application of analytical, conceptual, and representational skills within projects that engage and problematize urban context culturally, ecologically and technologically. Capstone Design Studio.

courses.title: Introduction to Historic Preservation
courses.description: This course provides an overview of the history, philosophy, organization, current legislation, policies, and practice of historic preservation.

courses.title: Architecture and Minimalism
courses.description: This course examines the influence of "minimalism," the 1960s art phenomenon, upon architecture culture and production from 1968-present.

courses.title: Architecture in Georgia
courses.description: A field study and archival research on the architecture of the state of Georgia outside of Atlanta.

courses.title: European Modernism
courses.description: Survey of European architecture from Art Nouveau to LeCorbusier.

courses.title: Introduction to Art and Architecture in Italy
courses.description: Required preparation for the COA Summer Program in Italy.  The course includes the fundamentals of art and architecture,  basic Italian language skills, and  library research for required summer program projects.

courses.title: Barcelona:  Architecture, Urban Design, Public Space
courses.description: Architectural history of the city of Barcelona and its public spaces, with a focus on the major urban and architectural projects since 1850.  Offered through the Studies Abroad Program.

courses.title: Form and Narrative: Cross Media Analysis
courses.description: This theory course will involve an extended comparison between architecture and related art forms, especially painting, film, and writing.

courses.title: Architecture and Discourse of the Everyday
courses.description: Application of the concept of the everyday to architectural practice from perspectives of European social theory, American cultural landscape studies, and contemporary architectural theory.

courses.title: Modern and Contemporary Architectual Theory and Criticism
courses.description: Introduction to modern and contemporary architectural theory and criticism, including writings and manifestoes, analyses, projects and buildings.

courses.title: Dwelling: Histories and Theories of Enviornmental Behavior and Design
courses.description: Explores scholarship and case studies from multiple disciplines relating to issues of place, community identity and memory, culturally constructed meaning, and appropriate use of resources.

courses.title: Museums: History, Theory, Design
courses.description: Investigates museums as manifestations of the construction and content of knowledge, the public mission of cultural and scientific institutions and the framing of visitors experience.

courses.title: History of Urban Form
courses.description: History of the city as a collective work of architecture with an emphasis on the city's physical form and space.  Credit not allowed for both ARCH 4151 and COA 6151.

courses.title: Reinvestigating the Detail: The Ornamental and the Everyday
courses.description: Explores the role of the detail in contemporary architectural practice.

courses.title: Green Construction
courses.description: This course focuses on the means, methods, strategies, and technologies to improve the energy efficiency and performance of buildings, and to reduce the environmental impact of buildings. Credit will not be awarded for both ARCH 4226 and ARCH 6226 or ARCH 4226 and BC 4710.

courses.title: Architecture and Ecology
courses.description: Introduction to ecological design theory, research, and practice in architecture, including writings, criticism, and analyses of buildings and projects.

courses.title: On Growth and Form
courses.description: Combination of aesthetic theory, history and digital design theory. The tracing of digital design (or generative design) back to its early roots in Romanticism.

courses.title: Building Simulation in Design Practice
courses.description: Numerical simulation of performance of characteristics of whole buildings. Review of the finite element method for uniform treatment of transport phenomena in different building technology domains. Credit not awarded for both ARCH 4240 and ARCH 6241.

courses.title: Advanced Structures Seminar
courses.description: Fundamentals of steel and concrete design and the computerized design of steel and concrete structural systems for multi-story buildings.

courses.title: Programming and Building Evaluation
courses.description: Building programming and evaluation of building performance with respect to the aims of organizational users, policy development, and the process of planning and design decisions.

courses.title: How do we dwell?
courses.description: Explores environmental behavior and the role of design in it through exploration of place and space, communal identity and memory, and natural and social ecology.

courses.title: Professional Practice of Architecture
courses.description: Principles and framework of professional practice including ethics, legal climate, business practices and contracts, project process and management, office organization, and methods of building production.

courses.title: Traditions of Architectural Practice
courses.description: Critical examination of architectural practice. Cultural derivation and technological transformation of various conventions of representation, construction, and design; speculation about future paradigms of architectural practice.

courses.title: Retrofitting Suburbia
courses.description: Study of suburban redevelopment trends, projects, and policies that improve environmental, social, and economic sustainability, with an emphasis on urban design strategies. Credit not awarded for both ARCH 4320 and COA 6120.

courses.title: Housing and Culture
courses.description: Examination of social, cultural, and behavioral  issues as they influence the form of houses and housing.

courses.title: Architectural Theory
courses.description: A critical perspective on the topics, voices, and texts that have  dominated architectural discourse in the West.

courses.title: Collage Making
courses.description: Concepts of Collage within art, architecture, and culture, manual and electronic approaches to two and three-dimensional collage-making.

courses.title: Introduction to Visual Arts
courses.description: Orientation to issues of visual perception and representation of form and space through freehand drawing, composition, color, texture, mixed-media, and journal making.

courses.title: Drawing and the Human Figure
courses.description: Studio instruction in figure drawing from the live model with emphasis on the structure and dynamics of the human figure.

courses.title: Collage Making
courses.description: Concepts of collage within art, architecture, and culture; manual and electronic approaches to two and three-dimensional collage making.

courses.title: Representation in Watercolor
courses.description: Introductory course in the use of transparent watercolor for field painting and architectural representation. Theory of pigment characteristics in applied painting.

courses.title: Photography I
courses.description: Introduction to studio, darkroom, and field photography with emphasis on composition, processing, and printing.

courses.title: Photography II
courses.description: Advanced techniques in photography. Use of color, filters, four-by- five format cameras with emphasis on architectural photography.

courses.title: Building Furniture and Furnishing Buildings
courses.description: A course that focuses on schematic design development of furniture.  The emphasis of this course is on conceptual development and material and structural clarity.

courses.title: Urban Ecological Design
courses.description: This course engages the contemporary issues of urban ecology and its articulation to design. It explores relationship between urban forms and flows of ecology, energy, material, water and information. Credit will not be awarded for both ARCH 4447 and ARCH 6447 or ARCH 4447 and CP 6836.

courses.title: BIM (Building Information Modeling) Applications
courses.description: Survey of Building Information Modeling - its technologies exploration of new technologies to be applied and new procedures of project execution. Credit is not awarded for both ARCH 4503 and ARCH 6503.

courses.title: Geometric Constructs
courses.description: Geometric surface and solid construction fundamentals using parametric modeling tools; use of sketching workbenches. Credit will not be awarded for both ARCH 4505 and ARCH 6505.

courses.title: Parametric Design
courses.description: Exploration of concepts and mechanisms for creating custom parametric models that use hierarchies of relationships, constraints and rules for architectural components through parameters. Credit not awarded for both ARCH 4507 and ARCH 6507.

courses.title: Shape Grammars
courses.description: Shape grammars are a powerful formal system for the generative description, interpretation and evaluation of designs. Credit will not be awarded for both ARCH 4508 and ARCH 6508.

courses.title: Advanced Productions
courses.description:
Advanced integration of digital design and production technologies through Mixed Reality (MR)  
 geared towards collaborative immersive spatial design and production systems.

courses.title: Collaborative Design Workshop
courses.description: Collaborative Design Workshop provides a platform for students to participate in a "live project" that requires them to navigate external relationships and constraints as part of the design process.

courses.title: Architecture, Space and Culture
courses.description: Analytical models of the social functions of architectural space and evaluation of associated design choices, across a variety of building types.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research Assistantship
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Analog-Digital Design Computing
courses.description: Analog and digital approaches in design computation. Visual and symbolic representations. Algorithmic and computational tools. History and logic. Credit will not be awarded for both ARCH 4701 and ARCH 6501.

courses.title: Design Scripting
courses.description: Learning the concepts and application of scripting languages in architecture and form generation. Credit will not be awarded for both ARCH 4702 and ARCH 6502.
