REVIT
courses.description: Visualizing a form enhances a designer’s ability to communicate ideas.  Course will demonstrate how REVIT can facilitate the Conception of a design from various points of genesis.

courses.title: Art & Architecture in Greece
courses.description: An intensive on-site investigation of the role that the arts and architecture have played in the development of classical Greek civilization.

courses.title: Art & Architecture in Italy I
courses.description: Investigations of the painting, sculpture, and architecture of the Classical, Early Christian, Byzantine, and Medieval periods in Italy with special emphasis on Rome.

courses.title: Art & Architecture in Italy II
courses.description: Investigations of the painting, sculpture, and architecture of the Renaissance and Baroque periods in Italy with special emphasis on the works of Rome.

courses.title: Media + Modeling 1
courses.description: Introductory approaches to two and three dimensional modeling and representation in architecture using both manual and digital media and techniques.

courses.title: Structures 1
courses.description: This course provides students with a basic knowledge of analysis and design of building structures and the ordering of structural systems to resist gravity and lateral loads.

courses.title: Media + Modeling 2
courses.description: Intermediate approaches to two dimensional modeling and representation in architecture using both manual and digital media techniques.

courses.title: Architecture Core I Studio
courses.description: Foundation studies in architectural design emphasizing enalytical and analogical generative strategies applied to studio problems that engage architectural representation, composition, and fabrication.  Credit not allowed for both ARCH 6024 and ARCH 4021.

courses.title: Architecture Core II Studio
courses.description: Intermediate studies in architectural design emphasizing integrative design strategies that engage the programmatic, contextual, and constructed dimentions of architecure and its representations.  Credit not allowed for both ARCH 6026 and ARCH 4022.

courses.title: Architecture Core III Studio
courses.description: Intermediate studies in architectural design emphasizing integrative design strategies that engage the programmatic, contextual, and constructed dimensions of architecture and its representations.  Credit not allowed for both ARCH 6027 and ARCH 4023.

courses.title: Core 1 Studio
courses.description: Foundation studies in architectural design emphasizing analytical and analogical generative strategies applied to studio problems that engage architectural representation, composition, and fabrication.

courses.title: Core 2 Studio
courses.description: Intermediate studies in architectural design emphasizing integrative design strategies that engage the programmatic, contextual, and constructed dimensions of architecture and its representations.

courses.title: Core 3 Studio
courses.description: Intermediate studies in architectural design emphasizing integrative design strategies that engage the programmatic, contextual, and constructed dimensions of architecture and its representations.

courses.title: Advanced Architectural Studio 1
courses.description: Architectural design studio exploring advanced issues in architecture from the perspectives of professional practice, sustainability, technology and urban design.

courses.title: Advanced Architectural Studio 2
courses.description: Architectural design studio exploring advanced issues in architecture from the perspectives of professional practice, sustainability, technology and urban design.

courses.title: Advanced Architecture Studio 1
courses.description: Architectural design studio exploring advanced issues in architecture from the perspectives of professional practice, sustainability, technology and urban design.

courses.title: Advanced Studio 2
courses.description: Architectural design studio exploring advanced issues in architecture from the perspectives of professional practice, sustainability, technology and urban design.

courses.title: Design + Research Studio 1
courses.description: Advanced architectural design emphasizing innovation through applied research. Emerging methods of design generation/evaluation. Changing topics: healthcare, fabrication, urbanism, ecology, building performance, cultural institutions.

courses.title: Design + Research Studio 2
courses.description: Advanced architectural design emphasizing innovation through applied research. Emerging methods of design generation/evaluation. Changing topics: healthcare, fabrication, urbanism, ecology, building performance, cultural institutions.

courses.title: Advanced Architectural Design I
courses.description: Architectural design studio exploring advanced issues in architecture from the perspectives of professional practice, sustainability, technology and urban design.

courses.title: Advanced Architectural Design II
courses.description: Architectural design studio exploring advanced issues in architecture from the perspectives of professional practice, sustainability, technology and urban design.

courses.title: Architecture Design and Research Studio I
courses.description: Advanced architectural design emphasizing innovation through applied research.  Emerging methods of design generation/evaluation.  Changing topics: healthcare, fabrication, urbanism, ecology, building performance, cultural institutions.

courses.title: Architectural Design and Research Studio 2
courses.description: Advanced architectural design emphasizing innovation through applied research.  Emerging methods of design generation/evaluation.  Changing topics: healthcare, fabrication, urbanism, ecology, building performance, cultural institutions.

courses.title: Retrofitting Suburbia
courses.description: Study of suburban redevelopment trends, projects, and policies that improve environmental, social, and economic sustainability, with an emphasis on urban design strategies.

courses.title: Architectural History I - Antiquity through the 18th Century
courses.description: Architectural history from aniquity through the 18th century emphasizing buildings in their cultural context as informed by social, technological, and constructive factors and theoretical positions.  Credit not allowed for both ARCH 6105 and ARCH 4105 or ARCH 2111.

courses.title: Architectural History II - 19th and 20th Century
courses.description: Architectural history during the 19th and 20th centuries emphasizing buildings in their cultural context as informed by social, technological, and constructive factors and theoretical positions.  Credit not allowed for both ARCH 6106 and ARCH 4106 or ARCH 2112.

courses.title: Intro to Historic Preser
courses.description: This course provides an overview of the history, philosophy, organization, current legislation, policies, and practice of historic preservation.

courses.title: Architecture and Minimalism
courses.description: This course examines the influence of "minimalism," the 1960s art phenomenon, upon architecture culture and production from 1968-present.

courses.title: Public Space: Questions and Configurations
courses.description: This course addresses questions concerning present-day configurations of public spaces as a platform for analysis of the contemporary city.

courses.title: Islamic Architecture and Urbanism
courses.description: Two-part survey of Asian architecture and urbanism (excluding East Asia). The Islamic world up to the 18th century: the Mughal, Raj, and post-independence periods in Indian subcontinent.

courses.title: History of Renaissance and Mannerist Architecture
courses.description: Investigation of the history and theory of Renaissance and Mannerist architecture with a primary emphasis on Italy.

courses.title: Architecture and Discourse of the Everyday
courses.description: Application of the concept of the everyday to architectural practice from perspectives of European social theory, American cultural landscape studies, and contemporary architectural theory.

courses.title: Introduction to Principles of Classical Design
courses.description: An introduction to the principles of Classical and traditional architectural design through readings, discussions, and site visits with Classical architects.

courses.title: Architecture of the Arts and Crafts Movement
courses.description: Study of the theory, design, and construction  of the "artistic" house as embodied in the English and American Arts and Crafts Movement and in related developments elsewhere.

courses.title: Frank Lloyd Wright and His Influence
courses.description: Study of the life, work, and influence of Frank Lloyd Wright, including work of his apprentices and followers.

courses.title: History of Atlanta Architecture
courses.description: Study of the architecture of the Atlanta metro area.

courses.title: Introduction to Art and Architecture in Italy
courses.description: Required preparation for the COA Summer Program in Italy.  Includes the fundamentals of art and architecture; basic Italian language skills; library research for required summer program projects.

courses.title: Form and Narrative: Cross Media Analysis
courses.description: This theory course will involve an extended comparison between architecture and related art forms, especially painting, film, and writing.

courses.title: Architectural Representation
courses.description: Systems of architectural representation and codes of thinking, drawing, and reading architecture.

courses.title: Architecture and Ideology
courses.description: Architecture and politics in Italy, Germany, and the Soviet Union between the wars.

courses.title: Postwar Architecture and Urbanism in the U.S.: Design, Politics & History
courses.description: Introduction to the economic, social, political, cultural, and technological forces that shape architecture and cities in the United States after World War II.

courses.title: Dwelling: Histories and Theories of Environmental Behavior and Design
courses.description: Explores scholarship and case studies from multiple disciplines relating to issues of place, community identity and memory, culturally contstructed meaning, and appropriate use of resources.

courses.title: Museums: History, Theory, Design
courses.description: Investigates museums as manifestations of the construction and content of knowledge, the public mission of cultural and scientific institutions and the framing of visitors experience.

courses.title: Theories of Urban Design
courses.description: Contemporary theories of urban design and their relationship to the contemporary city examined through architects' writings, urban projects, and interdisciplinary criticism.

courses.title: Studies in Landscape Architecture
courses.description: History and theory of the designed landscape and garden from the ancient world to the present.

courses.title: History and Theory of the Modern City
courses.description: An examination of the evolution of the modern city in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries with particular reference to architectural, city planning, and urban design theories.

courses.title: Introduction to Urban Design
courses.description: Introduction of urban design ideas, research, and practice, examining traditional qualities of the American city and their possible applications in the contemporary city.

courses.title: Contemporary Architecture and Urbanism in Europe
courses.description: A course on contemporary architecture and urban projects in Europe, including the architect's writings, published criticism, and analyses of the buildings and projects.

courses.title: Race, Space, and Architecture in the United States
courses.description: This course examines the relationship between architecture - as social practice and as a labor market - and race in the United States.

courses.title: Formulation of Design Intention in Architecture
courses.description: Reviews theories of interpretive criticism in architecture, and develops methodological approaches to interpreting criticizing, and formulating conceptual intent in architectural design.

courses.title: Portfolio Design
courses.description: Explores strategies of descriptions, representation, and presentation and other art-related ideas in order to communicate design work and design speculation effectively.

courses.title: Studies in Architectural Building Assemblies
courses.description: Structural and cladding systems integration, environmental control, and tectonic representation explored through historical and contemporary case studies and applied design solutions.

courses.title: Building Enclosure: A Tectonic Element
courses.description: Investigations of enclosure design from three perspectives (technology, form, and culture), analyzing relationships of the four Semperian elements and Alberti's three parts of the enclosure.

courses.title: Architectonics
courses.description: The study of architecture of form from both an historical and a mathematical perspective.  The formal theory is applied mathematics, group theory, combinatroics, as well as recent studies in the history of mathematics.

courses.title: Contemporary Architecture and Construction Technology
courses.description: General exposure to questions pertaining to the production of building systems and assemblies through a series of case study projects by contemporary practicing architects.

courses.title: Eco-Tectonics: Making and Meaning
courses.description: Strategies of ecologically sustainable design and construction and the role of the architect in the stewardship of the environment.

courses.title: The Material Logic of Architecture
courses.description: Introduction to scientific and practical nature of architectural materials: soils, cements, metals, plastics, and glazing materials.  Laboratory includes fabrication of, and experiments on, architectural materials.

courses.title: Reinvestigating the Detail: The Ornamental and the Everyday
courses.description: Explores the role of the detail in contemporary architectural practice.

courses.title: Green Construction
courses.description: This course focuses on the means, methods, strategies, and technologies to improve the energy efficiency and performance of buildings, and to reduce the environmental impact of buildings.

courses.title: Architecture and Ecology
courses.description: Introduction to ecological design theory, research, and practice in architecture, including writings, criticism, and analyses of buildings and projects.

courses.title: Analytical Investigations in Urban Design
courses.description: Measures of urban and spatial form.  Analysis of street connectivity.  Models of space use and spatial congnition.  Comparison and evaluation of design alternatives.

courses.title: Construction Technology and Design Integration I
courses.description: Introduction to building anatomy, technical and expressive characteristics of materials and their organizational assembly.  Credit not allowed for both ARCH 6229 and ARCH 4219.

courses.title: Building Simulation in Design Practice
courses.description: Learn to use mainstream simulation packages to support building design in domains of Energy, CFD, Lighting, Ventilation.

courses.title: Building Physics Modeling
courses.description: Survey of basic thermo-fluid energy and mass flows in buildings, the interrelations between these flows, physical system modeling, and implications for building performance goals.

courses.title: Evidence-Based Design
courses.description: Fundamental concepts, research methods and case studies of evidence-based design.

courses.title: Building Structures I
courses.description: Introduction to design and analysis of building structures and ordering of structural systems to resist gravity and lateral loads. Emphasis on wood structures.

courses.title: Building Structures II
courses.description: Introduction to structural design and framing systems for steel and concrete with consideration of lateral loads and lateral load resisting systems.

courses.title: Advanced Architecture, Culture and Behavior:  Theories, Models and Methods
courses.description: Theories, models, methods and case studies linking architectural design to culture and behavior.

courses.title: Healthcare Design of the Future
courses.description: Introduction to research-based approaches to integrated healthcare design innovation.

courses.title: Urban Design: Policy and Implementation
courses.description: Introduction to urban design policy and practice across a range of scales including planning, architecture, landscape architecture, civil engineering, public policy and administration.  Credit not allowed for both ARCH 6303 and CP 6834.

courses.title: Near and Far: Cross-Cultural Practices in Art, Architecture, and Design
courses.description: This course will address the material culture of globalization and cultural diffusion, emphasizing the multicultural registers of work produced between and across geographical, cultural, and disciplinary boundaries.

courses.title: Ecological Practice: History, Polemics, and Poetics
courses.description: An historically and culturally grounded examination of the ecological perspective. Critical and productive engagement with green guidelines, laws, products, design briefs, and procedures.

courses.title: Traditions of Architectural Practice
courses.description: Critical examination of architectural practice. Cultural derivation and technological transformation of various conventions of representation, construction, and design; speculations about future paradigms of architectural practice.

courses.title: Practice of Architecture I
courses.description: Architectural practice from historical, sociological, and ethical perspectives with focus on professional leadership, practice management, and entrepreneurship.

courses.title: Practice of Architecture 2
courses.description: Methods of architectural project delivery and project management.  Fundamentals of building economics.  Emergent models of research-driven architectural practice.

courses.title: Theory of Architecture I
courses.description: Architectural program.  Building types from functional and morphological perspectives.  Design responses to building programs in the context of culture and politics.  Architectural responses to site.

courses.title: Theory of Architecture 2
courses.description: Approaches to architectural form, style, and tectonics from aesthetic, social, and technological perspectives.  Instrumental and symbolic uses of architectural media in design and building production.

courses.title: Electronic Media: From Technique to Culture
courses.description: The influence of electronic media upon representation and invention in architecture.

courses.title: Collage Making
courses.description: Concepts of Collage within art, architecture, and culture, manual and electronic approaches to two and three-dimensional collage-making.

courses.title: Dwelling: Histories and Theories of Environmental Behavior and Design
courses.description: Explores scholarship and case studies from multiple disciplines relating to issues of place, community identity and memory, culturally constructed meaning, and appropriate use of resources.

courses.title: Building Furniture/Furnishing Buildings
courses.description: A course that focuses on schematic design and design development of furniture.  The emphasis of this course is on conceptual and material/structural clarity.

courses.title: Design Computing
courses.description: Survey of computer representations and modeling techniques, including pixel-based images, vector-based drawing systems, and surface and solid modeling; use of applications built upon these systems.  Credit not allowed for both ARCH 6420 and ARCH 4420.

courses.title: 3D Modeling in Architecture
courses.description: Construction of 3D computer models of architectural structures.  Topics include: geometry creation, light and materials property, rendering, data exchange, and basic animation.

courses.title: Advanced Modeling and Animation in Architecture
courses.description: Advanced computer modeling of architectural form. Topics include: parametric design, parametric materials, special effects, object libraries, animation, and video production.

courses.title: Formal Systems in Design, Art, and Architecture
courses.description: This course will examine generative descriptions of languages of design, art, and architecture and explore various computational approaches to design with a special emphasis on shape grammars.

courses.title: Urban Ecological Design
courses.description: This course engages the contemporary issues of urban ecology and its articulation to design.  It explores relationship between urban forms and flows of ecology, energy, material, water and information.  Credit not allowed for both ARCH 6447 and CP 6836.

courses.title: Architecture Modeling & Media I
courses.description: Introductory approaches to two and three dimensional modeling and representation in architecture using both manual and digital media and techniques.

courses.title: Architecture Modeling & Media 2
courses.description: Intermediate approaches to two dimensional modeling and representation in architecture using both manual and digital media and techniques.

courses.title: Architecture Modeling & Media 3
courses.description: Advanced approaches to two and three dimensional modeling and representation in architecture using both manual and digital media and techniques.

courses.title: Analog and Digital Design Computation
courses.description: Analog and digital approaches in design computation. Visual and symbolic representations.  Algorithmic and computational tools.  History and logic.

courses.title: Scripting for Architecture and Design
courses.description: Learning the concepts and application of scripting languages in architecture and form generation.

courses.title: Building Information Modeling - Concepts and Applications
courses.description: Survey of Building Information Modeling - its technologies exploration of new technologies to be applied and new procedures of project execution.

courses.title: Digital Design and Fabrication Workshop
courses.description: Parametric design, planning and programming.  Develop design for fabrication in specific materials including wood, plastic, metals, concrete, or composite.

courses.title: Geometric Constructs in Digital Space
courses.description: Geometric surface and solid construction fundamentals using parametric modeling tools; use of sketching workbenches.

courses.title: Construction Materials, Systems, and Fabrications
courses.description: Physical and constructional properties of building materials.  Fabrication techniques for building components. Digital representations of materials, components, and fabrication processes.

courses.title: Parametric Modeling and Design
courses.description: Design using parametric modeling tools; use of sketching workbenches and development of custom parametric models.

courses.title: Shape Grammars
courses.description: Shape grammars are a powerful formal system for the generative description, interpretation and evaluation of designs.

courses.title: Computation, Creativity and Design Cognition
courses.description: This course investigates computational methods, models tools that support design creativity and cognition.  Credit not allowed for both ARCH 6509 and ID 6509.

courses.title: Advanced Productions
courses.description:
Advanced integration of digital design and production technologies through Mixed Reality (MR)  
 geared towards collaborative immersive spatial design and production systems.

courses.title: Robotic Fabrication
courses.description: Introduction to robotics in design and construction.  Kinematics and programing of 6-axis industrial robots.  Use of robotics in building fabrication and assembly operations.

courses.title: Research Colloquium
courses.description: Introduces students to the processes of developing a topic of inquiry and delivering projects in architectural design, and to prepare students for the development of a final MS research project to be delivered as a final deliverable of the MS program during the subsequent semester.

courses.title: Building Systems & Data
courses.description: A focus on the overlap between AEC (Architecture, Engineering, Construction) processes and the building models and data that support them.

courses.title: Environmental Systems I
courses.description: Basics of heat, light, and sound applied to buildings. Thermal loading, passive thermal control, thermal comfort, climate, passive solar strategies, light and daylighting, acoustics.

courses.title: Zero Energy House
courses.description: Design, analysis, operation, construction, and cost feasibility of so-called "zero energy" houses.  Credit not allowed for both ARCH 6731 and BC 6731.

courses.title: Urban Design Studio I
courses.description: Urban design laboratory problems focusin on analysis, design, and implementation strategies for contemporary urban problems.

courses.title: Urban Design Studio 1
courses.description: Urban design studio problems focusing on analysis, design, and implementation strategies for contemporary urban problems.

courses.title: Urban Design Studio 2
courses.description: Advanced urban design problems emphasizing the application of contemporary urban design research and multidisciplinary collaboration into the design process.

courses.title: Urban Design Studio 3
courses.description: Advanced urban design problems emphasizing the application of contemporary urban design research and multidisciplinary collaboration into the design process.

courses.title: Media + Modeling 3
courses.description: Advanced approaches to two and three dimensional modeling and representation in architecture using both manual and digital media and techniques.

courses.title: Urban Design Workshop
courses.description: Advanced problems in urban design and development focusing on the Atlanta region.  Integration of urban design theory and methods, economic development, political registration, and communication.

courses.title: Urban Design Workshop
courses.description: Advanced problems in urban design and development focusing on the Atlanta region.  Integration of urban design theory and methods, economic development, political registration, and communication.

courses.title: Urban Design Workshop
courses.description: Advanced problems in urban design and development focusing on the Atlanta region.  Integration of urban design theory and methods, economic development, political registration, and communication.

courses.title: Urban Design Workshop
courses.description: Advanced problems in urban design and development focusing on the Atlanta region.  Integration of urban design theory and methods, economic development, political registration, and communication.

courses.title: Architecture Professional Practice Immersion
courses.description: Immersion for first year Graduate students experiences of the Professional Practice of Architecture.

courses.title: Critical Positions in Architectural Design
courses.description: Advanced topics in the theory of architectural production focusing upon contemporary ethical dilemmas and the development of critical positions of design.

courses.title: Integrated Building Systems 1
courses.description: Examines approaches to building design and systems integration. Introduces resiliency as a means of integrating environmental assessment for energy efficiency and design for natural forces.

courses.title: Integrated Building Systems II
courses.description: Approaches building design and systems integration through the making of construction drawings and specifications of metal frame buildings, including structural steel calculations.

courses.title: Integrated Building Systems III
courses.description: Approaches building design and systems integration via the design and detailing of a concrete frame building, including engineering of the concrete frame and the mechanical systems.

courses.title: Integrated Building Systems 2
courses.description: Approaches building design and systems integration through the making of construction drawings and specifications of metal frame buildings, including structural steel calculations.

courses.title: Integrated Building Systems 3
courses.description: Approaches building design and systems integration via the design and detailing of a concrete frame building, including engineering of the concrete frame and the mechanical systems.

courses.title: Constructing the Visual
courses.description: Promote an understanding of visual representations as they pertain to art, architecture and the use of architecture representations in the structuring of persuasive statements/arguments.

courses.title: History of Urban Form
courses.description: History of the city as a collective work of architecture with an emphasis on the city's physical form and space.

courses.title: Flourishing Communities
courses.description: Introduces students to collaborative and participatory processes especially in relation to design, equity, diversity, and inclusion for underserved communities.

courses.title: Computational Building Simulation
courses.description: Students learn how to develop their own extensible Building Simulation software using Finite Element discretization in Matlab and apply it to research problem.

courses.title: Foundations of Architectural Theory
courses.description: Reviews thought and attitudes guiding architecture since the modern movement, their philosophical sources, and their relationship with architectural production. Defines architectural theory.

courses.title: Design & Climate Change
courses.description: This course positions design as an essential component of research that explores the sociocultural and eco-political dimensions of climate change as it applies to the built environment.

courses.title: Cognitive Function of Visual Design in Architecture
courses.description: Presents fundamentals of imaginative and cognitive functioning of visual design in buildings, and develops inter-disciplinary approaches to investigating visual form of buildings.

courses.title: Theories of Inquiry
courses.description: Introduction to research paradigms and their assumptions. The formulation of questions and frameworks of description, representation, analysis, interpretation, and data control.

courses.title: Introduction to Architectural Research 1
courses.description: Fundamental issues and methods across specializations in architectural research modules on causation and simulation.

courses.title: Introduction to Architectural Research 2
courses.description: Fundamental issues and methods across specializations in architectural research; modules on representation and interpretation.

courses.title: Introduction to Architectural Research 3
courses.description: Fundamental issues and methods across specializations in architectural research; modules on historiography and epistemology and on theories of design.

courses.title: Architecture Space & Culture
courses.description: Accounts of the social functions of architectural space and associated design choices, across a variety of building types and scales of environmental design.

courses.title: Building Simulation Seminar
courses.description: Numerical simulation of performance characteristics of whole buildings. Review of the finite element method for uniform treatment of transport phenomena in different building technology domains.

courses.title: Qualifying Paper
courses.description: Preparation for Qualifying Paper in Doctorial Program in Architecture.

courses.title: Air Force Leadership-Lab
courses.description: Air Force customs and courtesies, drill and ceremonies, and introduction to the military environment. Emphasis on developing the leadership and interpersonal skills needed of Air Force officers.

courses.title: Heritage and Values of the Air Force I
courses.description: A survey course designed to introduce students to the Department of the Air Force (DAF) and provides an overview of the basic characteristics, missions, communications and organization of the Air and Space Forces. Topics include: Formation of the Air Force, Military Customs and Courtesies, and Introduction to Leadership. Leadership Laboratory is mandatory for AFROTC cadets and complements this course.

courses.title: Heritage and Values of the Air Force II
courses.description: A survey course designed to introduce students to the Department of the Air Force (DAF) and provides an overview of the basic characteristics, missions, communications and organization of the Air and Space Forces. Topics include: What is War?, Principles of War and Tenets of Airpower, and What the Department of the Air Force Brings to the Fight. Leadership Laboratory is mandatory for AFROTC cadets and complements this course.

courses.title: U.S. Air and Space Power Fundamentals I
courses.description: This course provides a fundamental understanding of both leadership and team building. The lessons and course flow are designed to prepare students for field training and leadership positions in the detachment. Topics include: Listening, Full-Range Leadership, and Standards and Accountability. Leadership Laboratory is mandatory for AFROTC cadets and complements this course.

courses.title: U.S. Air and Space Power Fundamentals II
courses.description: This course provides a fundamental understanding of both leadership and team building. The lessons and course flow are designed to prepare students for field training and leadership positions in the detachment. Topics include: Human Relations, Conflict Management, and Stress Management and Resiliency. Leadership Laboratory is mandatory for AFROTC cadets and complements this course.

courses.title: Leading People and Effective Communication I
courses.description: This course utilizes student’s field training experience to take a more in-depth look at leadership. Special emphasis is placed on enhancing communication skills, and why that is important as a leader. Students have an opportunity to try out these leadership and management techniques in a supervised environment as juniors and seniors. Topics include: Change Management, Leading Diverse Organizations, and Managing Competing Priorities. Leadership Laboratory is mandatory for AFROTC cadets and complements this course.

courses.title: Leading People and Effective Communication II
courses.description: This course utilizes student’s field training experience to take a more in-depth look at leadership. Special emphasis is placed on enhancing communication skills, and why that is important as a leader. Students have an opportunity to try out these leadership and management techniques in a supervised environment as juniors and seniors. Topics include: Mentoring, Ethical Decision Making, and Establishing Expectations. Leadership Laboratory is mandatory for AFROTC cadets and complements this course.

courses.title: National Security and Preparation for Active Duty I
courses.description: This course is designed for college seniors and provides them the foundation to understand their role as military officers and how they are directly tied to our National Security Strategy. It is an overview of the complex social and political issues facing the military profession and requires a measure of sophistication commensurate with the senior college level. Topics include: National Security Strategy, The Total Force, and Capabilities and Force Packaging. Leadership Laboratory is mandatory for AFROTC cadets and complements this course.

courses.title: National Security and Preparation for Active Duty II
courses.description: This course is designed for college seniors and provides them the foundation to understand their role as military officers and how they are directly tied to our National Security Strategy. It is an overview of the complex social and political issues facing the military profession and requires a measure of sophistication commensurate with the senior college level. Topics include: Leadership Authority and Responsibility, Military Justice, and Airmen Comprehensive Assessment. Leadership Laboratory is mandatory for AFROTC cadets and complements this course.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Modern Systems Engineering
courses.description: Explore a wide range of modern systems engineering principles and development methodologies.  Address requirements engineering, systems definition, design and analysis, implementation, operation, and technical management.

courses.title: Systems Design and Analysis
courses.description: Introduce emerging techniques for systems and systems-of-systems analysis including IPPD, DOE, Taguchi methods, response surface equations, multi-attribute decision making, and concept feasibility assessment.

courses.title: Modeling and Simulation for Systems Engineers
courses.description: Introduction to modeling and simulation for systems engineers.  Topics include problem formulation, conceptual modeling, simulation methodologies, verification and validation, DOE, simulation execution, and output analysis.

courses.title: Leading Systems Engineering Teams
courses.description: Systems engineering processes provide a model for successfully managing complex systems.  Learn to apply management and development techniques used for successful commercial and government programs.

courses.title: Advanced Topics in Systems Engineering: Systems Modeling with SysML
courses.description: This core elective introduces SymML as a system modeling and design tool, with example applications, guidelines for application, and student projects on implementations in practice.

courses.title: Systems Engineering Laboratory
courses.description: Application of working knowledge of systems engineering techniques applied to a "case study" in an applicable domain.

courses.title: Vehicle Systems Analysis and Synthesis
courses.description: Vehicle Preliminary Design involves design iteration with disciplinary physics-based methods and tools.  Includes geometry and databases from conceptual design, six DOF modeling, analysis, and synthesized baseline.

courses.title: System of Systems and Architecture
courses.description: Develop a broader understanding of the interdependencies and interoperability issues, interfaces, and processes for creating and defining Systems Architecture for complex systems.

courses.title: Complex System Lifecycle and Integration
courses.description: System preliminary design must address product and process design throughout system lifecycle from integration through manufacturing to phase-out along with interfaces to other emerging systems.

courses.title: Complex System Design and Integration (Capstone)
courses.description: Student teams apply methods and techniques taught throughout the program to conduct complex system Conceptual Design based on requirements provided in a Request for Proposal.

courses.title: Sensor Systems Analysis and Synthesis
courses.description: Defines, classifies, and examines technology used in stand-alone sensor systems.  Centers on system-engineering trades useful in designing systems of sensors and systems of systems.

courses.title: Information Systems Analysis and Synthesis
courses.description: Tools and approaches for analysis and synthesis of enterprise information systems.  Topics include user-centered requirement, scenario-based design, UML, network/communications, iterative prototyping, and enterprise support.

courses.title: Analysis and Synthesis: Human Systems Integration
courses.description: Human Systems Integration Analysis and Synthesis, a PMASE complex systems elective, ensures human-related technical issues are properly addressed during system definition, design, development, and implementation.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Topics of current interest in Applied Systems Engineering.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Topics of current interest in Applied Systems Engineering.

courses.title: Construction Technology I
courses.description: An introduction to the planning and physical development process for the construction of projects of residential and light construction scale.

courses.title: Construction Technology II
courses.description: A continuation of Construction Technology I with an emphasis on large- scale and high-rise building, i.e., commercial building construction.

courses.title: Introduction to Construction Management
courses.description: Provides an introduction to the construction industry with emphasis on exploring career opportunities in construction.

courses.title: Construction Materials and Methods
courses.description: The course will cover the planning and physical development process for the construction of residential, commercial and heavy/industrial projects.

courses.title: Construction Plans and Estimates
courses.description: Course focuses on reading and accessing project drawing information, and estimating quantities for pricing of materials, labor, subcontracts and equipment.

courses.title: Construction Safety
courses.description: This course introduces the core elements of an effective safety and health management system in a construction project, and describes the application of OSHA standards.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research Assistantship
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Construction Cost Management
courses.description: Introduction to cost principles and cost analysis of construction projects, including classification of work, quantity survey techniques, construction operation costs, and bid proposals.

courses.title: Construction Law
courses.description: Legal aspects of construction contracts, bonds, insurance, and bidding. Owner, architect, contractor, and subcontractor relationships.

courses.title: Real Estate and Construction Finance and Accounting
courses.description: General introduction to the financing of construction and real estate development projects. Emphasis on financing requirements, activities, sources, and uses.

courses.title: Project Management I
courses.description: This course will offer construction planning and management techniques for project design and construction with a focus on different scheduling methods and their use.

courses.title: Construction Mechanics
courses.description: An introductory course to the evaluation of behavior of buildings, the properties of structural materials, and the behavior of load-resisting members.

courses.title: History of Construction Industry
courses.description: Addresses how today's construction industry is organized and its particular characteristics, how it evolved from early times and where it may be heading in the future.

courses.title: Building Information Modeling for Multi-disciplinary Integration
courses.description: This course introduces students to BIM and the changes it has been causing to the traditional design, planning, management, construction, facility management, and contracting practices.

courses.title: Trends & Pol For Res Dev
courses.description: An overview of development in the United States, current trends in residential development, and the impact of external factors on residential development.  This course is designed to help Building Construction students understand how their development impacts the social environment and quality of life of the community.

courses.title: Community Dsgn & Constr
courses.description: An overview of the principles of smart growth, livable communities and new urbanism and how these principles are implemented in the process from design to construction and marketing.

courses.title: Intg Design Constr & Dev
courses.description: A study of contemporary examples of an integrated approach to design, construction and development.  Course involves real-world project analysis from multiple points of view.

courses.title: Construction Management Project
courses.description: This class is the application of course materials covered throughout the Certificate in Construction Management to an actual construction project with a simulated business construct.

courses.title: Sustainable Community Design and Construction
courses.description: An overview of the principles of smart growth, livable communities, and new urbanism and how these principles are implemented in the process from design to construction and marketing.

courses.title: Project Management II
courses.description: This course covers practical project management, technology, and tools for this approach and the  required management skills for successful execution of projects.

courses.title: Value Engineering and Building Economics
courses.description: First part is an introduction to principles and methodology.  Second part is an introduction to economic principles and theories and how to apply the concepts and methods of building economics.

courses.title: Building Structural Analysis
courses.description: Emphasis being placed on the practical design and construction of structural elements.  The course includes basic design principles with a heavy emphasis on constructability and buildability.

courses.title: Senior Capstone Project
courses.description: A senior construction project that  includes redevelopment analysis and feasibility study, project development, and construction.

courses.title: Construction Marketing
courses.description: Methods of construction marketing and business development. Innovative computer applications, verbal skills development, professional strategies, market segmentation, and buyer behavior.

courses.title: Laboratory for Sustainable Design and Construction
courses.description: The goal of the laboratory is to teach students a comprehensive sustainable design and construction information system and a program of real-world, hands-on projects.

courses.title: Entrepreneurship in Construction
courses.description: Basics of construction business risk assessment, looking for construction opportunities, capital investment, computerized construction business, and business failures.

courses.title: Mechanical, Electrical and Plumbing Systems for Construction Managers
courses.description: This course covers the fundamentals of mechanical, electrical, and plumbing contracting, including terminology, components, and basic design features of HVAC systems; plumbing systems; and electrical circuits and service equipment. It also encompasses the presentation of current mechanical, electrical, and plumbing drawings, specifications, and building codes.

courses.title: Professional Internship
courses.description: Students work for a professional architecture/engineering/ construction company in which they learn, first-hand, about the construction industry.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research Assistantship
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Construction Management
courses.description: An accelerated-pace course designed to provide a basic understanding of fundamental topics including planning, budgeting, estimation, scheduling, and project close out.

courses.title: Green Construction
courses.description: This course focuses on the means, methods, strategies, and technologies to improve the energy efficiency and performance of buildings, and to reduce the environmental impact of buildings.

courses.title: Residential Construction and Property Management
courses.description: A course designed to orient students to the basics of apartment management and includes the business functions of marketing, leasing, and financing.

courses.title: Best Practices in Multi-Family Property
courses.description: A course designed to provide students with a broad range of the best practices related to the management of all types of multi-family residential property.

courses.title: Real Estate Development and Construction
courses.description: Provides an overview of the real estate development process as it pertains to construction development including trends and current issues.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Topics of current interest in building construction.

courses.title: Issues in Sustainable Construction Technology
courses.description: Course designed to help students achieve a basic understanding of the materials used in the commercial segments in the construction industry and how these relate to sustainable construction.

courses.title: Sustainable Energy in Architecture, Engineering and Construction
courses.description: An introductory course on sustainale energy in architecture, engineering and construction.  The goal of the course is to introduce students to fundamental concepts of sustainable sources of energy to power buildings and address the impact of these sources to applicable green building rating systems.

courses.title: Technology Applications in the Construction Industry
courses.description: Hands-on exploration of various present and Future technologies that can be applied in all stages of a facilities' lifecycle.

courses.title: Advanced Cost Management
courses.description: Cost management and control from early project inception to completion and applications throughout the life of a facility.

courses.title: History of Construction Industry
courses.description: Addresses how today's construction industry is organized and its particular characteristics, how it evolved from early times and where it may be heading in the future.

courses.title: Construction Management
courses.description: An accelerated paced course providing graduate students a basic understanding of fundamental topics including planning, budgeting, estimating, scheduling and project closeout.

courses.title: Building Information Modeling for Multi-disciplinary Integration
courses.description: This course introduces students to BIM and the changes it has been causing to the traditional design, planning, management, construction, facility management, and contracting practices. Credit will not be awarded for both BC 4050 and BC 6050.

courses.title: Construction X
courses.description: Course introduces the Construction 4.0 framework. It presents concepts related to cyber-physical systems and various component technologies as an innovation platform for the built environment.

courses.title: Digital Twins for the Built Environment
courses.description: Course introduces Digital Twin in built environment applications. Digital Twin integrate various technologies to create a living digital representation of a facility through its lifecycle.

courses.title: Professional Trends in Facility Management
courses.description: An introductory course covering the organizational, managerial, ethical, and legal principles for the delivery of facility management services.  Includes contracts and risk management.

courses.title: Professional Internship
courses.description: A course in which students work for a professional architecture/engineering/construction company in which they learn, first-hand, about the construction industry.

courses.title: Design-Build Organization and Management
courses.description: Introduction to Design-Build (DB) as a project delivery system.  Provides information about the organization, the process, and the effects of DB on the industry.

courses.title: Real Estate Development and Construction
courses.description: Provides an overview of the real estate development process as it pertains to construction development including trends and current issues.

courses.title: Introduction to Construction Program Management
courses.description: Survey of the construction program management profession, focusing on the comprehensive management of single and multiple building programs including pre-design, design, construction and post-construction activities.

courses.title: Maintenance Management of Built Assets
courses.description: This course covers the processes by which a facility and its systems are serviced and maintained during the facility's life cycle.  Includes acquisition, installation, operation, maintenance, and disposal of built assets.

courses.title: Value Management for Integrated Facility Design and Construction
courses.description: Principles and methodology of value management analysis concepts and an examination of future values and worth criteria affecting building design, construction, furnishings, and operations performance.

courses.title: Community Design and Development
courses.description: An overview of the principles of smart growth, livable communities and new urbanism and how these principles are implemented in the process from design to construction and marketing.

courses.title: Community Dsgn & Constr
courses.description: An overview of the principles of smart growth, livable communities and new urbanism and how these principles are implemented in the process from design to construction and marketing.

courses.title: Management of Pre-design Phase as Owner
courses.description: Examination of the Program Manager's role and responsibilities as owner during the pre-design phase including feasibility, organization, financing, legal, entitlement, planning, budgeting, scheduling, and team selection.

courses.title: Safety and Environmental Issues
courses.description: This course covers the environmental issues related to the performance of buildings and the health and risk factors for new and existing buildings.

courses.title: Design and Construction Law
courses.description: Overview of construction law and legal issues encountered by the construction manager including U.S. laws, general concepts and definitions, contractor relationships, and relevant case studies.

courses.title: Real Estate Policy, Trends, Ethics
courses.description: The application of market, community, and policy factors to create new development while professionally managing potential conflicts between these factors.

courses.title: Trends & Pol For Res Dev
courses.description: An overview of development in the United States, current trends in residential development, and the impact of governmental regulations on residential development. This course is designed to help Building Construction students understand how their development impacts the social environment and quality of life of the community.

courses.title: Management of Design Phase as Owner
courses.description: Examination of the Program Manager's role and responsibilities as Owner during the design phase.

courses.title: Facility Planning, Project Management, and Benchmarking
courses.description: This course introduces the techniques of planning project management, benchmarking, and their applications to facility management.  Includes space forecasting, scheduling and control of projects, and benchmarking studies.

courses.title: Real Estate Development Law
courses.description: Comprehensive overview of legal, property, and entitlement issues associated with the real estate development process.

courses.title: Management of Preconstruction Phase as Owner
courses.description: This course covers the management and oversight activities of the owner and program manager conducted during the pre-design and design phases of a construction project.

courses.title: Real Estate Asset and Income Property Management
courses.description: This course covers real estate financial management and performance topics from a decision making and strategic planning orientation for facilities management professionals.

courses.title: Design and Construction Processes for Integrated Services
courses.description: Offers a framework for use and application of design, contract, and performance documents for successful execution of various forms of integrated project delivery systems.

courses.title: Real Estate Development Basic Finance
courses.description: Comprehensive overview of the business model and financing methodology to analyze and produce new real estate development.

courses.title: Real Estate Production Finance
courses.description: Business model and financing process required to produce new real estate developments through an investigation of land acquisition, development and construction financial management.

courses.title: Management of Construction as Owner
courses.description: Survey of construction management from the owner's perspective.

courses.title: Facilities Management Financial Analysis
courses.description: This course covers real property concepts, issues, and topics pertinent to the facility management professional.  The topics include site selection, property market analysis, legal documents, and land use control.

courses.title: Advanced Project Management
courses.description: A four-phased coverage of project management including organization, planning and scheduling, control, budgeting, and ending with project testing, evaluation, and termination.

courses.title: Residential Design and Construction
courses.description: Course will examine the application of market, community, and regulatory factors to single family housing design and construction; construction management process required for efficient delivery.

courses.title: Leadership and Communications in Design and Construction
courses.description: Framework and guidelines for effective leadership and communications during design and construction.

courses.title: Advanced Facility Management Practices
courses.description: Students apply specific methods and procedures from core courses to actual business situations in the facility and property management industry.

courses.title: Zero Energy Housing
courses.description: Design, analysis, operation, construction, and cost feasibility of so-called "zero energy" houses.  Credit not allowed for both BC 6731 and ARCH 6731.

courses.title: Facility and Property Management Capstone
courses.description: Designed to integrate the learning from basic topics through the use of actual case studies and situations found within the facility and property management industry.

courses.title: Building Construction and Facility Management Capstone
courses.description: Application of coursework covered in the Master of Science in Building Construction and Facility Management curriculum with a stimulated business construct from different perspectives: construction manager, program manager, or facility manager.

courses.title: Real Estate Development Capstone Project
courses.description: Formulation and exploration of a real estate development project. Topics include business plan, market analysis, site selection, regulations, finance, project delivery, design and engineering.

courses.title: Best Practices in Multi-Family Property
courses.description: A course designed to provide students with a broad range of the best practices related to the management of all types of multi-family residential property.

courses.title: Introduction to Residential Property Management
courses.description: A course designed to orient students to the basics of apartment management and includes the business functions of marketing, leasing, and financing.

courses.title: Intg Design Constr & Dev
courses.description: This course will focus on contemporary integrated approach to design, construction and development.  Course involves real-world project analysis from multiple points aof view. Examples to be selected from the Atlanta region.

courses.title: The Evolution of a Deal
courses.description: Presentations and site visits conducted by developers to expose students to design program implementation, financial structure, and project management.

courses.title: Quantitative Methods for Construction Research
courses.description: Introductory course in graduate research in the building construction industry.  Covers types of research, sampling methods, and basic analysis and evaluation techniques.

courses.title: Advanced Readings in BC in Preparation for the PhD Comprehensive Examination
courses.description: This course is designed around advanced readings in research and practice for PhD students working in the building construction area.

courses.title: PhD Seminar for Students with Building Construction Emphasis
courses.description: This is an introduction to PhD-level research in Building Construction.

courses.title: Research Methodology
courses.description: Research design course that teaches the basics of creating credible scientific research plans with examples from construction related research.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Topics of current interest in building construction.

courses.description: For graduate students holding graduate teaching assistantship.

courses.title: Research Assistantship
courses.description: For graduate students holding graduate research assistantship.

courses.title: Doctoral Thesis Preparation
courses.description: This course is designed to synthesize the knowledge and skills developed in previous research courses and apply them to the doctoral dissertation process for students in Building Construction.

courses.title: Doctoral Thesis
courses.description: Preparation of doctoral thesis for Ph.D. in Building Construction.

courses.title: Island Biogeography of New Zealand
courses.description: Introduction to theory of island biogeography focused on New Zealand's geological history and unique biota.

courses.title: Genomics and Applied Bioinformatics
courses.description: Retrieval and analysis of biological sequence, gene expression, and proteomics data from public databases and other sources; applying standard bioinformatics tools to investigate biological questions.  Credit not allowed for both BIOL 6150 and BIOL 4150.

courses.title: Biological Oceanography
courses.description: An introduction to the major biological processes in the ocean, including primary production, elemental cycling, food webs, and fisheries.

courses.title: Microbial Ecology
courses.description: Advanced studies of microbial ecosystems, the specific roles of bacteria in maintaining ecological balance, and the evolution of the ecosystem in response to changing environments.

courses.title: Marine Ecology
courses.description: An overview of the ecological and evolutionary patterns, processes, and mechanisms affecting the organization, structure, and function of a broad variety of marine communities.  Credit not allowed for both BIOL 6417 and BIOL 4417.

courses.title: Microbial Physiology
courses.description: Study of the physiology of growth and metabolic activities of microorganisms.

courses.title: Population Dynamics
courses.description: Students will examine the ecological factors that affect dynamics, regulation, and evolution of natural populations, emphasizing the connections with mathematical models, genetics, and ecology. Credit will not be awarded for both BIOL 6428 and BIOL 4428.

courses.title: Conservation Biology
courses.description: This course explores the broad diversity of disciplines in conservation, with emphasis on biological phenomena. Analyzes contemporary issues affecting biodiversity, extinction risk, and policymaking.

courses.title: Methods in Molecular Biophysics
courses.description: An introduction to biophysical methods that are employed to study biological macromolecules and their interaction to gain understanding of how they function.  Credit not allowed for both BIOL 6478 and BIOL 4478.

courses.title: Programming in Biological and Health Sciences
courses.description: This course introduces students to the basics of coding, applied to fundamental biological and medical questions.

courses.title: Immunology
courses.description: A survey of modern immunology and its applications, with emphasis on immunological methods used in molecular and cell biological research.

courses.title: Evolution
courses.description: An introduction to evolutionary patterns and processes, including the history of life, phylogenetics, population genetics, quantitative genetics, molecular evolution, and other important topics in evolutionary biology.

courses.title: Molecular Biology of Microbes: Disease, Nature, and Biotechnology
courses.description: Molecular genetics of bacteria with an emphasis on experimental approaches, regulatory mechanisms in disease-causing and environmental bacteria, and biotechnology applications derived from microbes. Credit will not be awarded for both BIOL 6607 and BIOL 4607, BIOL 4608, or BIOL 6608.

courses.title: Advanced Microbial Physiology
courses.description: Advanced studies of selected aspects of the physiololgy of prokaryotic and eukaryotic microorganisms.

courses.title: Aquatic Chemical Ecology
courses.description: The course focuses on understanding the chemical mechanisms of aquatic signaling and the cascading effects on population regulation, community organization, and ecosystem function.  Credit not allowed for both BIOL 6620 and BIOL 4620.

courses.title: Environmental Microbial Genomics
courses.description: To introduce advanced concepts and principles of contemporary environmental microbiological research and assosciated bioinformatics techniques through representative examples from recent literature.

courses.title: Foundations of Quantitative Biosciences
courses.description: Introduction to quantitative methods and logic that enable key advances in understanding living systems, spanning molecules, cells, organisms, and biomes.

courses.title: Discovery of Signaling Molecules
courses.description: The diversity of chemical signals between organisms and their structural specificities will be presented along with chemical and biological methods for isolating signaling molecules.  Crosslisted with CEE 6756 and CHEM 6756.

courses.title: Geomicrobiology
courses.description: Interactions between microorganisms and the geosphere, microbial energetics and genetics; geochemical controls on microbial diversity and activity.  Crosslisted with EAS 6765.

courses.title: Foundations in Molecular and Cell Biology
courses.description: The goal of this course is to provide new students with fundamental knowledge in the general areas of prokaryotic and eukaryotic molecular biology, biochemistry, structural biology, and bioinformatics.

courses.title: Advanced Cell Biology
courses.description: Current topics in eukarytotic cell biology including membrane functions, intracellular sorting and compartmentalization, cell signaling, cell cycle, cytoskeleton, cell adhesion, motility, and current experimental approaches.

courses.title: Cancer Biology and Technology
courses.description: This course covers the major concepts of cancer biology as well as to state-of-the-art technologies that are being applied to cancer research, detection and treatment.  Credit not allowed for both BIOL 7015 and BIOL 4015.

courses.title: Molecular Evolution
courses.description: Evolutionary processes at the molecular level, organizations of genomes and genetic systems. Students will read and present up-to-date research articles in various topics in molecular evolution.

courses.title: Programming for Bioinformatics
courses.description: This active-learning, project-based course provides a rigorous introduction to scientific computing for bioinformatics, including Linux utilities, shell scripting and bioinformatics programming.

courses.title: Computational Genomics
courses.description: In this active learning class, students will learn to convert sequence information into knowledge through the use of computational genomics tools, applications and databases.

courses.title: Advances in Bacteriology
courses.description: Topics of current interest in the physiology and ecology of bacteria and applications to practical problems.

courses.title: Advances in Ecology
courses.description: Topics of current interest in the general areas of population growth and limitation, and the structure and stability of ecosystems.

courses.title: Advances in Environmental Biology
courses.description: Topics of current interest in environmental biology.

courses.title: Advances in Molecular Biology
courses.description: Topics of current interest in molecular biology.

courses.title: Advances in Genetics
courses.description: Topics of current interest in genetics.

courses.title: Seminar
courses.description: Weekly seminars on current research presented by various scientists in the field of biology.

courses.title: Seminar
courses.description: Weekly seminars on current research presented by various scientists in the field of biology.

courses.title: Professional development in quantitative biosciences
courses.description: Enhance the professional development of Quantitative Biosciences PhD students in preparing and submitting fellowships and in organizing scientific workshops and events.

courses.title: Seminar in Quantitative Biosciences
courses.description: This course will introduce QBioS to QBioS Program Faculty, allowing them to learn about QBioS faculty members’ research and academic history.

courses.title: Current Research in the Quantitative Biosciences
courses.description: The overall objective of the course is to enable QBioS PhD students to attend seminars on advances across all areas of the life sciences, including those by 4th year QBioS students.

courses.title: Tools of Science Seminar
courses.description: This course addresses issues important to all successful scientists and engineers such as: research ethics; collaborations between industry, academics, and government; women and minorities in science; balancing research, teaching and service; writing, editing, and reviewing, presentations; job interviews; time management; speaking to the public and media; and scientific and university politics.

courses.title: Epigenetics
courses.description: This course will introduce the basic concepts and mechanisms in epigenetics, covering topics ranging from stem cell reprogramming, organismal development, social behaviors, to human diseases.

courses.title: Community Ecology
courses.description: An advanced ecology course that covers classic and contemporary concepts, patterns, and processes in the field of community ecology.

courses.title: Human Evolutionary Genomics
courses.description: An advanced course where students will discuss primary literature and use computational tools to investigate how evolution has shaped global patterns of human genetic variation.

courses.title: Origin of complex life: from cells to societies
courses.description: This course examines the evolutionary origins of complex life. We will examine the history of life on Earth and evolutionary process through which complexity arises.

courses.title: RNA Biology and Bitechnology
courses.description: The purpose of this course is to introduce students (graduate and upper level undergraduate) to the fundamental concepts of RNA biology and to state-of-the-art biotechnologies that use RNA for medical and industrial applications.

courses.title: Chromosome Biology and Human Diseases
courses.description: This course explores the fundamental mechanisms governing metabolism of eukaryotic chromosomes and human diseases resulting from malfunctioning of chromosomal maintenance.

courses.title: Microbial Symbiosis & Microbiomes
courses.description: This course explores how symbiotic interactions with microbes affect the biology of other organisms, focusing extensively on the beneficial microbes native to the human body.
