courses.title: Principles of Biology I
courses.description: Lecture part of a sequence designed for science majors. An introduction to biological principles, including biomacromolecules, bioenergetics, cell structure, genetics, evolution, and ecological relationships for STEM majors and prehealth students.

courses.title: Principles of Biology I Laboratory
courses.description: Laboratory exercises supplement the lecture material of BIOL 1107. A laboratory-based introduction to biological principles, including biomacromolecules, bioenergetics, cell structure, genetics, evolution, and ecological relationships for STEM majors and prehealth students.

courses.title: BIOS 1107 Recitation
courses.description: Recitation for BIOS 1107.

courses.title: Principles of Biology II
courses.description: Lecture part of a sequence designed for science majors. An introduction to organ and organismal biology, emphasizing physiological processes, growth/development, and biodiversity from an evolutionary perspective for STEM majors and prehealth students.

courses.title: Principles of Biology II Laboratory
courses.description: Laboratory exercises supplement the lecture material of BIOL 1108. A laboratory-based introduction to organ and organismal biology, emphasizing physiological processes, growth/development, and biodiversity from an evolutionary perspective for STEM majors and prehealth students.

courses.title: BIOS 1108 Recitation
courses.description: Recitation for BIOS 1108.

courses.title: Biological Principles for Majors
courses.description: An introduction to the basic principles of modern biology, including biomacromolecules, bioenergetics, cell structure, genetics, evolution, and ecological relationships.

courses.title: Biological Principles Project Laboratory
courses.description: A project-based laboratory introduction to the basic principles of modern biology, including biomacromolecules, bioenergetics, cell structure, genetics, evolution, and ecological relationships,

courses.title: BIOS 1207 Recitation
courses.description: Recitation for BIOS 1207.

courses.title: Organismal Biology for Majors
courses.description: An introduction to biology at the organ and organismal level, with emphasis on physiological processes, integration of growth and development, and biodiversity from an evolutionary perspective.

courses.title: Organismal Biology Project Laboratory
courses.description: A project-based laboratory introduction to biology at the organ and organismal level, with emphasis on physiological processes, integration of growth and development, and biodiversity from an evolutionary perspective.

courses.title: BIOS 1208 Recitation
courses.description: Recitation for BIOS 1208.

courses.title: Biology of Sex & Death
courses.description: Students learn biology through the lens of the formation and collapse of biological systems, organized around questions pertaining to life, sex, and death.

courses.title: Biology of Sex and Death Recitation
courses.description: A recitation period for BIOS 1220, an introduction to biology and scientific methodology organized around questions pertaining to life, sex, and death.

courses.title: Ecology
courses.description: Introduction to ecological processes at individual, population, and community levels that occur in plant, animal, and microbial taxa, and their relevance to current environmental problems.

courses.title: Ecology Laboratory
courses.description: The companion laboratory for BIOS 2300 (Ecology). This course stresses understanding ecological concepts through a combination of lab and field experiments, and computer simulations.

courses.title: Problems in Ecology
courses.description: Problem-based learning approach to modern ecology from populations to communities, stressing independent analysis, scientific thinking, communication and projects in local communities.

courses.title: Problems in Ecology Laboratory
courses.description: Companion lab to Problems in Ecology. Problem-based learning approach to modern ecology, stressing independent analysis, scientific thinking, communication and projects in local communities.

courses.title: Math Models in Biology
courses.description: Introductory probability and deterministic models in biology, including discrete and continuous probability distributions and dynamic models from molecular and cellular biology to ecology and epidemiology.

courses.title: Introduction to Sport Science
courses.description: Students will apply scientific principles to human performance related to sport and movement across an array of topics (e.g., rehabilitation, exercise physiology, locomotion biomechanics, prosthetics).

courses.title: Genetics
courses.description: Mendelian and molecular genetics: principles of inheritance, gene structure and function, foundations of recombinant DNA technology, genetic basis of variation and evolution.

courses.title: Genetics Laboratory
courses.description: A laboratory course in fundamental techniques of genetic analysis.

courses.title: Integrative Genetics
courses.description: Rigorous in-depth integrated coverage of rules and molecular basis of inheritance, incorporating primary literature and capitalizing on excellent prior knowledge of fundamentals of biology.

courses.title: Integrative Genetics Lab
courses.description: Hands-on introduction to practical techniques, critical thinking, and important concepts in genetics.  Students carry out laboratory experiments that explore transmission, population, and molecular genetics.

courses.title: Biology Intern Assistantship
courses.description: Biology Undergraduate Internship for pay for freshmen and sophomores, by permit only. The internship experience must be at a unit or agency approved by the School of Biological Sciences.

courses.title: Biology Internship
courses.description: Biology Undergraduate Internship for credit for freshmen and sophomores, by permit only. The internship experience must be at a unit or agency approved by the School of Biological Sciences.

courses.title: Research Assistantship
courses.description:
Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

Undergraduate research under the guidance of a faculty member for first years and sophomores, or for students with no previous undergraduate-level research experience.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.description:
Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

Undergraduate research under the guidance of a faculty member for first years and sophomores, or for students with no previous undergraduate-level research experience.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Lecture course in current special topics in biological sciences. Topics will vary from year to year.

courses.title: Microbiology
courses.description: Basic biology of bacteria, fungi, algae, and viruses, with emphasis on bacteriology.

courses.title: Microbiology Lab
courses.description: Fundamental laboratory techniques in microbiology.

courses.title: Mathematical Models in Biology
courses.description: Probability and deterministic models in biology, including discrete and continuous probability distributions and dynamic models from molecular and cellular biology to ecology and epidemiology.

courses.title: Cell and Molecular Biology
courses.description: An introduction to the structure and function of cells and their organelles with emphasis on eucaryotic cellular and molecular processes.

courses.title: Cell and Molecular Biology Lab
courses.description: An introduction to experimental methods of cell and molecular biology research that will cover some fundamental topics of cell biology.

courses.title: Evolutionary Biology
courses.description: A comprehensive overview of evolutionary biology, including processes (e.g., natural selection, genetic drift) and resulting patterns (e.g., genome organization, phylogeny, and the fossil record).

courses.title: Human Anatomy
courses.description: Detailed study of human body structures using a regional and systems approach.  Emphasis is placed on structural relationships and the integration of body systems.

courses.title: Laboratory in Human Anatomy
courses.description: A detailed hands-on study of human structure using high resolution models, specialized specimens and dissection of selected mammalian organs and tissues.

courses.title: Human Physiology
courses.description: Students will explore the function and adaptation of the human body emphasizing neuromuscular, cardio-respiratory, gastrointestinal, endocrine, and urinary systems to maintain homeostasis and human health.

courses.title: Physiology Laboratory
courses.description: Course focuses on non-invasive human experiments supplemented with in vitro tissues experiments to explore fundamental physiological concepts and learn basic methods of physiological measurements.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Lecture course in current special topics in biological sciences. Topics will vary from year to year.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special Topics course in the School of Biological Sciences.

courses.title: Protein Biology
courses.description: Biological view of proteins, including protein biosynthesis, processing, modification, folding, trafficking, interactions, degradation, natural and directed evolution, assembly diseases, amyloids, prions and protein-based inheritance.

courses.title: Cancer Biology and Biotechnology
courses.description: This course covers basic concepts of cancer biology and new technologies that are being developed to understand, detect, treat and prevent cancer.

courses.title: Exercise Physiology
courses.description: Physiology of human movement with emphasis on metabolic, cardiorespiratory, and musculoskeletal aspects; associated topics include body composition, thermoregulation, and ergogenic aids.

courses.title: Genomics and Applied Bioinformatics
courses.description: Retrieval and analysis of biological sequence, gene expression, and proteomics data from public databases and other sources; applying standard bioinformatics tools to investigate biological questions.

courses.title: Kinesiological Basis of Human Movement
courses.description: This course teaches principles related to the biomechanics, energetics and motor control of movement as it applies to human and animal movement, rehabilitation, and sports performance.

courses.title: Biological Oceanography
courses.description: An introduction to the major biological processes in the ocean including primary production, elemental cycling, food webs, and fisheries.

courses.title: Molecular Evolution
courses.description: Evolutionary processes at molecular level, organization of genomes and genetic systems. Students will read and present up-to-date research articles in various topics in molecular evolution.

courses.title: Ion Channels in Health and Disease
courses.description: We will examine the basic biophysical properties, structure-function relationships, physiological regulation, pathology and pharmacological manipulation of ion channels with heavy reliance on recent literature.

courses.title: Medical Microbiology
courses.description: Advanced study of bacteria, protozoa, fungi, and viruses that cause human diseases; emphasis on epidemiology, mechanisms of disease causation, prevention, and treatment.

courses.title: Human Neuroanatomy
courses.description: The purpose of this course is to learn the anatomical makeup of the human nervous system.  In this course we will closely examine details of central and peripheral neuroanatomy with links to function.  As well, comparisons with non-human vertebrate neuroanatomy will be made.

courses.title: Experimental Design and Statistical Methods in Biological Sciences
courses.description: Introductory course on experimental design, hypothesis testing and basic statistical techniques commonly applied in biosciences research. Exercises based on statistical software packages.

courses.title: Microbial Ecology
courses.description: Advanced studies of microbial ecosystems, the specific roles of bacteria in maintaining ecological balance, and the evolution of the ecosystem in response to changing environments.

courses.title: Marine Ecology
courses.description: An overview of the physical forces and biotic interactions structuring marine communities and of the major threats to these communities.

courses.title: Microbial Physiology
courses.description: Study of the physiology of growth and metabolic activities of microorganisms.

courses.title: Population Dynamics
courses.description: Students will examine the ecological factors that affect dynamics, regulation, and evolution of natural populations, emphasizing the connections with mathematical models, genetics, and ecology.

courses.title: Conservation Biology
courses.description: This course explores the broad diversity of disciplines in conservation, with emphasis on biological phenomena. Analyzes contemporary issues affecting biodiversity, extinction risk, and policymaking.

courses.title: Human Pathology
courses.description: The course provides a comprehensive overview of clinical human anatomic pathology. The course will focus on select diseases and their etiologies, pathogenesis, morphological changes, and clinical manifestations.

courses.title: Communicating Biological Research
courses.description: Students learn to convey the importance of research findings in the biological sciences and to critically evaluate research results through discussions and scientific presentations.

courses.title: Developmental Biology
courses.description: Investigation of cell differentiation and development, using the tools of molecular genetics and cell biology.

courses.title: Behavioral Biology
courses.description: An introduction to the study of the principles of behavior of all kinds of organisms, from microbes to mammals.

courses.title: Evolutionary Developmental Biology – How to Build an Organism
courses.description: This course teaches students how the process of development from embryo to adult impacts evolutionary diversity and human health.

courses.title: Drug Discovery
courses.description: You will learn about the drug discovery process by identifying a disease and disease target,  and then design a therapy to treat the disease.

courses.title: Programming in Biological and Life Sciences
courses.description: This course introduces students to the basics of coding, applied to fundamental biological and medical questions.

courses.title: Epigenetics,  Stem Cells, and Development
courses.description: This course will introduce the basic concepts and mechanisms in epigenetics, covering topics ranging from stem cell reprogramming, organismal development, social behaviors, to human diseases.

courses.title: Community Ecology
courses.description: An advanced ecology course that covers classic and contemporary concepts, patterns, and processes in the field of community ecology.

courses.title: Health Genes Society
courses.description: Capstone project based investigation of the roles that genes and culture play in shaping health, including an introduction to personalized medicine.

courses.title: Human Evolutionary Genomics
courses.description: An advanced course where students will discuss primary literature and use computational tools to investigate how evolution has shaped global patterns of human genetic variation.

courses.title: Human Motor Control
courses.description: Course provides in-depth review of biomechanics and neurophysiology of human motion and discusses how human movements are planned, executed and corrected by the nervous system.

courses.title: Genetics of Complex Human Traits and Diseases
courses.description: Introduction to the genetics and evolution of complex human traits, focusing on contemporary approaches to understanding susceptibility to malignant, metabolic, immune and psychological diseases.

courses.title: Origin of complex life: from cells to societies
courses.description: This course examines the evolutionary origins of complex life. We will examine the history of life on Earth and evolutionary process through which complexity arises.

courses.title: RNA Biology and Biotechnology
courses.description: This course covers fundamental concepts of RNA biology as well as state-of-the-art biotechnologies that make use of RNA.

courses.title: Chromosome Biology and Human Diseases
courses.description: This course explores the fundamental mechanisms governing metabolism of eukaryotic chromosomes and human diseases resulting from malfunctioning of chromosomal maintenance.

courses.title: Immunology
courses.description: A survey of modern immunology and its applications.

courses.title: Research Project Lab
courses.description: Experience in designing, implementing, and communicating a biology research project, and practical training in modern approaches for biological research.

courses.title: Molecular Biology of Microbes: Disease, Nature, and Biotechnology
courses.description: Molecular genetics of bacteria with an emphasis on experimental approaches, regulatory mechanisms on disease-causing and environmental bacteria, and biotechnology applications derived from microbes.

courses.title: Aquatic Chemical Ecology
courses.description: The course focuses on understanding the chemical mechanisms of aquatic signaling and the cascading effects on population regulation, community organization, and ecosystem function.

courses.title: Bioethics
courses.description: This course examines important bioethical issues in research, policy, medicine, and the environment in light of ethical theory and the process of scientific inquiry.

courses.title: Independent Research Project
courses.description: Independent research with proposal and manuscript writing, conducted with the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Research Thesis
courses.description: Writing and submission of an Undergraduate Research Thesis describing research accomplishments with a Georgia Tech faculty member.

courses.title: Biology Intern Assistantship
courses.description: Biology Undergraduate Internship for pay for juniors and seniors, by permit only. The internship experience must be at a unit or agency approved by the School of Biology.

courses.title: Biology Internship
courses.description: Biology Undergraduate Internship for credit for juniors and seniors, by permit only. The internship experience must be at a unit or agency approved by the School of Biology.

courses.title: Biology Undergraduate Teaching Assistantship
courses.description: Biology teaching carried out under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Biology Undergraduate Teaching Experience
courses.description: An introduction to teaching biology for undergraduate teaching assistants, with a focus on effective teaching, active engagement of students, and development of innovative classroom activities.

courses.title: Research Assistantship
courses.description: Undergraduate research under the guidance of a faculty member for juniors and seniors.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Undergraduate research under the guidance of a faculty member for juniors and seniors.

courses.title: Biologically-Inspired Design
courses.description: We examine evolutionary adaptation as a source for engineering design inspiration, utilizing principles of scaling, adaptability, and robust multifunctionality that characterize biological systems.

courses.title: Microbial Symbiosis & Microbiomes
courses.description: This course explores how symbiotic interactions with microbes affect the biology of other organisms, focusing extensively on the beneficial microbes native to the human body.

courses.title: Signaling Molecules
courses.description: The diversity of chemical signals between organisms and their structural specifications will be presented along with chemical and biological methods for isolating signaling molecules.

courses.description: Special Topics.

courses.description: Special Topics in the School of Biological Sciences.

courses.description: This designation enables the School of Biology to provide new lecture courses dealing with areas of current interest in biological science.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special Topics offered by the School of Biological Sciences.

courses.title: Introduction to Biomedical Engineering
courses.description: An introduction to the field of biomedical engineering, with an emphasis on career preparation.

courses.title: Problems in Biomedical Engineering I
courses.description: Biomedical engineering problems from industrial and clinical applications are addressed and solved in small groups using problem-based learning methodologies.

courses.title: Introduction to Bioengineering
courses.description: An introduction to the field of bioengineering, including the application of engineering principles and methods to problems in biology and medicine, the integration of engineering with biology, and the emerging industrial opportunities.  Crosslisted with AE, CHE, ECE, ME, and MSE 1750.

courses.title: Conservation Principles in Biomedical Engineering
courses.description: A study of material and energy balances applied to problems in biomedical engineering.

courses.title: Problems in Biomedical Engineering
courses.description: Biomedical engineering problems from industrial and clinical applications are addressed and solved in small groups using problem-based learning methodologies. Credit will not be awarded for both BMED 2250 and BMED 1300.

courses.title: Problems in Biomedical Engineering II
courses.description: Biomedical engineering problems from industrial and clinical applications are addressed and solved in small groups using problem-based learning methods.

courses.title: Intro to Biomedical Engineering Design
courses.description: In small teams students will apply problem-based learning and human centered design to reverse engineer, analyze, and redesign medical devices. Credit will not be awareded for both BMED 2310 and BMED 2300.

courses.title: Introduction to Bioengineering Statistics
courses.description: Introduction to statistical modeling and data analysis in bioscientific and bioengineering applications. Topics include estimation, testing, regression, and experimental design.

courses.title: Systems Physiology
courses.description: An introduction to human physiology emphasizing biomedical engineering aproaches to the understanding of basic organ function, disease states, and medical intervention.

courses.title: Introduction to Biomedical Data Science and Engineering
courses.description: Practical/hands-on experience in performing biomedical-related data processing/computation/analysis with a variety of computer tools, platforms, and applications.

courses.title: Quantitative Engineering Physiology Laboratory I
courses.description: A hands-on lab providing an active learning team environment to reinforce selected engineering principles of physiology, emphasizing a quantitative model-oriented approach to physiological systems.

courses.title: Introduction to Machine Learning for Biomedical Engineers
courses.description: This course is designed to provide biomedical engineering undergraduates with a solid foundation in the principles and applications of machine learning.

courses.title: Introduction to Bioinformatics
courses.description: Students will be introduced to the field of bioinformatics, an interdisciplinary field that combines computer science, statistics, machine learning and mathematics to analyze biological data.

courses.title: Introduction to Neuroengineering
courses.description:
An introduction to the intersection between neuroscience and neurotechnology, including identification of key aspects of the
nervous system as the basis for measurement and intervention.

courses.title: Biotransport
courses.description: Fundamental principles of fluid, heat, and mass transfer with particular emphasis on physiological and biomedical systems.

courses.title: Biotransport
courses.description: Fundamental principles of fluid, heat, and mass transfer with particular emphasis on physiological and biomedical systems. Credit will not be awarded for both BMED 3310 and BMED 3300.

courses.title: Introduction to Biomechanics
courses.description: An introduction to the basic concepts and methods in biomechanics, including statistics and the mechanics of biomaterials.  The biomedical applications of mechanics will be illustrated.

courses.title: Introduction to Biomechanics
courses.description: Introduces concepts and approaches for biomedical deformation and dynamics problems using the application of simple models from statics, mechanics of materials, kinematics, and dynamics.

courses.title: Biomedical Sensors and Instrumentation
courses.description: A study of basic concepts and design of electronic sensors and instrumentation used in biomedical measurements. Standard clinical measurement techniques will also be examined.

courses.title: Biomedical Systems and Modeling
courses.description: Basic concepts, modeling tools and analysis techniques for the study of biochemical, bioelectrical and biomedical systems.

courses.title: Biomedical Systems and Modeling
courses.description: Introduction of computational systems biology, including the modeling process, various types of models, standard analysis and simulation of systems, and applications in real-world biological systems. Credit will not be awarded for both BMED 3520 and BMED 3510.

courses.title: Physiology of Cellular and Molecular Systems
courses.description: In depth cell and molecular physiology focused on cellular responses to stimuli, including cell organization/ reorganization, membrane transport/kinetics, cell signaling/ molecular biology, mechanobiology and energy requirements.

courses.title: Quantitative Engineering Physiology Laboratory II
courses.description: This lab provides an active learning team environment, incorporating common cell/molecular biology techniques, to reinforce selected engineering principles in an in vitro cell culture setting.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special Topics in Biomedical Engineering.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special topics in BMED.

courses.title: The Art of Telling Your Story
courses.description: Students will create a professional portfolio and develop the ability to pitch themselves to an audience to prepare themselves to begin their professional careers.

courses.title: Neuroengineering Fundamentals
courses.description: Lab and lecture on current topics in Neuroengineering, including electrophysiology, clinical and diagnostic neuroengineering, neural prosthetics, sensory-motor integration, neuromorphic VLSI, neurodynamics and neurorobotics.

courses.title: Biological Networks and Genomics
courses.description: Introduction to modeling of biological networks involved in gene regulation, cell signaling and metabolism. Mathematical modeling of cellular processes, such as gene expression, using genomic data.

courses.title: Biomed-AI and Health Informatics
courses.description: The course will introduce commonly used informatics pipelines driven by current biomedicine and health care challenges and opportunities.

courses.title: Cell and Tissue Engineering Laboratory
courses.description: The principles of cell and tissue engineering will be presented as a laboratory course to give students a hands-on experience.  Cell engineering topics include receptor/ligand interactions, cell cycle/metabolism, cell adhesion, cellular mechanics, cell signal transduction, and cell transfection.  Tissue engineering topics include applications, biomaterials/scaffolds and cells for reparative medicine, bioreactors and bioprocessing, functional assessment, in vivo issues.

courses.title: Senior Design Project I
courses.description: Team-oriented major design project in biomedical engineering, incorporating engineering standards and realistic design constraints.  Credit not allowed for BMED 4600 and BMED 4603 (or BMED 4601).

courses.title: Senior Design Project II
courses.description: Team-oriented major design project in biomedical engineering, incorporating engineering standards and realistic design constraints.  Credit not allowed for both BMED 4601 and BMED 4603 (or BMED 4600).

courses.title: Capstone Design
courses.description: Team-oriented design project in biomedical engineering, incorporating engineering standards and realistic design constraints.  Includes introduction to relevant regulatory, intellectual property, and business management topics.

courses.title: Advanced Design
courses.description: Continuation of a team-oriented design experience initiated in BMED 4602 Capstone Design.  Includes more advanced relevant regulatory. intellectual property, and business management topics.  Credit not allowed for both BMED 4603 and BMED 4600 (or BMED 4601).

courses.title: Undergraduate Research Assistantship
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Interdisciplinary Capstone Design
courses.description: Interdisciplinary Capstone Design, Industry projects or CREATE-X section.

courses.title: Medical Robotics
courses.description: An interdisciplinary course focusing on fundamental understanding of robot kinematics and dynamics as well as the design, development, and evaluation of a medical robotic system.

courses.title: Biologically Inspired Design
courses.description: We examine evolutionary adaptation as a source for engineering design inspiration, utilizing principles of scaling, adaptability, and robust multifunctionality that characterize biological systems.

courses.title: Diagnostic Imaging Physics
courses.description: Physics and image formation methods for conventional X-ray, digital X-ray CT, nuclear medicine, and magnetic resonance and ultrasound imaging.  Crosslisted with MP 4750 and NRE 4750.

courses.title: Introduction to Biomaterials
courses.description: Introduction to different classes of biomaterials (polymers, metals, ceramics) and physiological responses to biomaterial implantation. Topics include material properties, host response, and biomaterial characterization techniques. Crosslisted with MSE 4751.

courses.title: Introductory Neuroscience
courses.description: Goals are to understand the components of the nervous system and their functional interactions, and appreciate the complexity of higher order brain functions and pathways. Crosslisted with BIOL 4752.

courses.title: Frontiers in Neuroengineering
courses.description: Neuroengineering issues related to measurement and manipulation of the nervous system for basic scientific discovery and treatment of neurological disorders.

courses.title: Computational Biomaterial and Tissue Mechanics
courses.description: Computational tissue and biomaterial mechanics modeling utilizing finite element software with elastic and inelastic material models.  Patient image data models creation using image modeling software.

courses.title: Biofluid Mechanics
courses.description: Introduction to the study of blood flow in the cardiovascular system. Emphasis on modeling and the potential of flow studies for clinical research application. Crosslisted with AE, CHE and ME 4757.

courses.title: Biosolid Mechanics
courses.description: The mechanics of living tissue, e.g., arteries, skin, heart muscle, ligament, tendon, cartilage, and bone. Constitutive equations and some simple mechanical models. Mechanics of cells.  Applications. Crosslisted with AE, CHE, and ME 4758.

courses.title: Drug Design, Development and Delivery
courses.description: Introduction to the pharmaceutical development process, including design of new drugs, synthesis and manufacturing issues, and methods for delivery into the body. Includes student presentations. Crosslisted with CHEM and CHBE 4765.

courses.title: Translational Microsystems
courses.description: Learn how to design biomedical microsystems ready for clinical and biomedical translation. Course blends theory with examples of successful biomedical research, clinical translation, and case studies.

courses.title: Biomedical Instrumentation
courses.description: A study of medical instrumentation from a systems viewpoint. Pertinent physiological and electro-physiological concepts will be covered.  Credit not allowed for both BMED 4781 and (CHE 4781 or ME 4781 or CHBE 4781 or ECE 4781).

courses.title: Biosystems Analysis
courses.description: Analytical methods for modeling biological systems, including white-noise protocols for characterizing nonlinear systems. Crosslisted with CHE, ECE, and ME 4782.

courses.title: Introduction to Medical Image Processing
courses.description: A study of mathematical methods used in medical image acquisition and processing. Concepts, algorithms, and methods associated with acquisition, processing, and display of two- and three-dimensional medical imaged are studied. Crosslisted with ECE 4783.

courses.title: Engineering Electrophysiology
courses.description: Basic concepts of electrophysiology from an engineering perspective. Functionality of relevant organs and systems; instrumentation tools which monitor electrophysiology function. Crosslisted with ECE 4784.

courses.title: Optical Microscopy
courses.description: The course will cover the fundamental principles of optical imaging and detail the inner workings of key microscopy technologies.

courses.title: Medical Imaging Systems: Physics, Engineering, and Applications
courses.description: Introduce major biomedical and clinical imaging modalities including X-ray radiography, computed tomography (CT), nuclear medicine (SPECT and PET), magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and ultrasound.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special Topics in BMED.

courses.title: Special Problems
courses.description: Individualized studies in certain specialized areas of interest in biomedical engineering.

courses.title: Special Problems
courses.description: Individualized studies in certain specialized areas of interest in biomedical engineering.

courses.title: Special Problems
courses.description: Individualized studies in certain specialized areas of interest in biomedical engineering.

courses.title: Special Problems
courses.description: Individualized studies in certain specialized areas of interest in biomedical engineering.

courses.title: Analytical Methods for Biomedical Engineering
courses.description: Basic analytical approaches to solve mathematical problems involved in biomedical engineering applications. Course focuses on ordinary and partial differential equations and on integral transform methods.

courses.title: Systems Physiology
courses.description: Regulation of physiological functions in the cardio-respiratory-renal, musculoskeletal, and gastrointestinal systems, and their interactions with the neural, endocrine, and immune systems.

courses.title: Magnetic Resonance Imaging
courses.description: This course covers the basic physics and engineering principles, advanced techniques and major applications of magnetic resonance imaging.

courses.title: Biomed-AI and Health Informatics
courses.description: This course uses lectures, homework, programming practical, exam, and team-based problem-based learning to teach Biomedical AI concepts and methods with applications to health informatics.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Biomedical Innovation and Development Processes
courses.description: Key steps, multiple stakeholders and interdependencies in the design and commercialization process for medical products.

courses.title: BioID Clinical Literacy and Experience
courses.description: Education in interfacing with medical healthcare professionals, medical terminology, on-site clinical observations, needs-finding, case analysis, creating design solutions for improved methods, products and procedures.

courses.title: Medical Markets and Clinical Specialties
courses.description: Introduction to medical device and biologics industries, interdependencies of commercial companies, vendors and suppliers required for development, commercialization and sales of products and equipment.

courses.title: Financial Planning for Development Projects
courses.description: Finance planning for development projects including: costing, forecasting, time value of money, breakeven analysis, return on investment analysis, capital budgeting, risk and return, working capital management.

courses.title: Product Planning and Project Management
courses.description: Strategy and analysis techniques to evaluate and manage new product innovations, product improvements and product line extensions in context of an entity's mission and goals.

courses.title: Professional Communications for Biomedical Innovation and Development
courses.description: Techniques and practice of effective oral presentations project/grant proposal writing, technical and project report writing to support medical device engineering, design and business.

courses.title: Medical Device Regulatory Requirements
courses.description: FDA Regulations for medical devices including clearance-approval pathways to commercialization, Quality Systems Regulations and ISO Standards for medical devices in the European Economic Community.

courses.title: BioID Team Masters Project I
courses.description: Team project to address an unmet medical need and develop an innovative solution including the engineering design document package and proof-of-concept prototyhpe.

courses.title: BioID Masters Project II
courses.description: Teams will construct prototypes for Course I biomedical device project solution, conduct and analyze performance testing, prepare FDA 510(k) submission, and prepare project commercialization plan.

courses.title: Machine Learning in Biosciences
courses.description: Introduces machine learning concepts and methods, including supervised and unsupervised learning, dimension reduction and visualization. Topics are accompanied by bioinformatics and systems biology applications.

courses.title: Biostatistics
courses.description: An introduction to fundamental ideas and techniques in Biostatistics, with an emphasis on conceptual understanding and on the analysis of real data sets.

courses.title: Rational Design of Biomaterials
courses.description: The goal of this course is to give graduate students the ability to rationally design new biomaterials by integrating organic chemistry concepts with molecular biology.

courses.title: Rational Design of Biomaterials Lab
courses.description: The goal of this course is to teach students the laboratory skills needed to design and synthesize new biomaterials.

courses.title: Biotransport
courses.description: This graduate level course covers the analysis of fluid flow phenomena in the human body, cardiovasculature, respiratory system and other organ systems.

courses.title: Materials Science of Cellular Components
courses.description: Addresses structure-property relationship of cellular components.  Credit not allowed for both BMED 6730 and MSE 6730.

courses.title: Medical Robotics
courses.description: This interdisciplinary course focuses on a fundamental understanding of robot kinematics and dynamics as well as the design, development, and evaluation of a medical robotic system.

courses.title: Living System Modeling & Analysis
courses.description: The purpose of this course is to introduce graduate students to living system models as pre-clinical test beds for a wide variety of biotechnologies.

courses.title: Biosolid Mechanics
courses.description: Structure-function relationships and constitutive models for a variety of biological tissues, with an emphasis on understanding the mechanical behaviors of normal and pathological tissues. Credit not given for both BMED/ME 6783 and BMED/ME 6743. Crosslisted with ME 6743.

courses.title: Principles of Management for Engineers
courses.description: The course will provide an introduction to selected topics needed to be successful in the technology industries. Cannot count toward major area requirements in M.S. or Ph.D. programs of study.

courses.title: Computational Biomaterial and Tissue Mechanics
courses.description: Computational tissue and biomaterial mechanics modeling utilizing finite element software with elastic and inelastic material models.  Patient image data models creation using image modeling software.

courses.title: Information Processing Models in Neural Systems
courses.description: This course will examine "top down" modeling approaches for sensorineural systems, where an optimal computational principle used in engineering (e.g., information theory, Bayesian inference, control theory) explains observed information processing.

courses.title: Drug Design, Development and Delivery
courses.description: Introduction to the pharmaceutical development process, including design of new drugs, synthesis and manufacturing issues, and methods of delivery into the body. Includes student presentations.  Crosslisted with BMED 6765 and CHBE 6765.

courses.title: Biomaterials: Structure and Function
courses.description: Structure-function relationships of biomaterials and biomaterial characterization will be covered. Materials for medial implants, tissue engineering, biosensing, imaging, and drug delivery will be covered. Crosslisted with CHE, ME, and MSE 6774.

courses.title: Translational Microsystems
courses.description: Learn how to design biomedical microsystems ready for clinical and biomedical translation. Course blends theory with examples of successful biomedical research, clinical translation, and case studies.

courses.title: Advanced Biomaterials
courses.description: Advanced topics of biomaterials performance and engineering, including biointerfaces, host reactions to materials, and bio-inspired/smart-materials strategies. Crosslisted with CHE, ME, and MSE 6777.

courses.title: Bioprocess Engineering
courses.description: Study of enzymes and microbial and mammalian cells for production of biochemicals and protein therapeutics in bioreactors; downstream separation and purification; integrated view of bioprocesses. Crosslisted with CHE 6779.

courses.title: Medical Image Processing
courses.description: A study of methods for enhancing, analyzing, interpreting, and visualizing information from two- and three-dimensional data obtained from a variety of medical imaging modalities. Crosslisted with ECE and CS 6780.

courses.title: Clinical Neurology
courses.description: Clinical bioscience course that teaches the fundamentals of neuropathology, namely diagnostics, prognostics, therapeutics, and rehabilitative technology for neurological patient management and care.

courses.title: Cellular Engineering
courses.description: Engineering analysis of cellular systems.  Crosslisted with CHE and ME 6782.

courses.title: Cardiovascular Biomechanics
courses.description: Mechanical analysis of the cardiovascular system emphasizing the normal and pathologic function in relation to clinical cardiovascular medicine.  Crosslisted with CHE and ME 6784.

courses.title: Optical Microscopy
courses.description: The course will cover the fundamental principles of optical imaging and detail the inner workings of key microscopy technologies.

courses.title: Medical Imaging Systems
courses.description: A study of the principles and design of medical imaging systems such as X-ray, ultrasound, nuclear medicine, and nuclear magnetic resonance. Crosslisted with ECE 6786.

courses.title: Quantitative Electrophysiology
courses.description: A quantitative presentation of electrophysiological systems in biological organisms, emphasizing the electrical properties and modeling of neural and cardiac cells and systems.  Crosslisted with PHYS and ECE 6787.

courses.title: Technology Ventures
courses.description: Team discussion and case studies in biomedical engineering technology transfer, including licensing, financial capital, safety and efficacy studies, clinical trials, and strategic planning.  Crosslisted with ECE, CHE, ME, and MGT 6789.

courses.title: Information Processing Models in Neural Systems
courses.description: Examines "top-down" modeling approaches for sensorineural systems, where optimal computational principles used in engineering(e.g., information theory, Bayesian inference, control theory) explain observed information processing.

courses.title: Translational Neuroengineering
courses.description: Application of engineering, data science/AI, and neuroscience to improve diagnostics, prognostics, therapeutics, or devices/technology for solving problems in neuroengineering.

courses.title: Systems Pathophysiology
courses.description: Overview of human pathophysiology from a quantitative perspective.  A brief introduction to the application of quantitative models to the understanding of biological systems.  Crosslisted with CHE, ECE, and ME 6793.

courses.title: Tissue Engineering
courses.description: Biological, engineering, and medical issues in developing tissue engineered constructs. Emphasis in the integration of these disciplines at a basic molecular and cell biology level.  Crosslisted with CHE and ME 6794.

courses.title: Legal Issues in Technology Transfer
courses.description: Study and analysis of U.S. law as it applies to the patenting and licensing processes. Crosslisted with CHE, ME, and MGT 6799.

courses.title: Biomedical Engineering Seminar
courses.description: Graduate students of the Biomedical Engineering department (all programs) participate in seminars involving current research projects presented by faculty and invited speakers.

courses.title: Teaching Practicum I
courses.description: This course provides discipline-specific training that addresses intellectual problems and teaching strategies from the perspective of the discipline.  Credit not allowed for both BMED 7002 and BMED 8696.

courses.title: Teaching Practicum II
courses.description: This course provides discipline-specific training that addresses intellectual problems and teaching strategies from the perspective of the discipline.  Credit not allowed for both BMED 7003 and BMED 8697.

courses.title: Teaching & Research Practicum I
courses.description: This course provides the practicial framework for understanding challenges faced during teaching, research, and academic life. This course includes topical materials required for BME RCR requirements.

courses.title: Teaching & Research Practicum II
courses.description: This course provides the practical framework for understanding challenges faced during teaching, research, and academic life.

courses.title: Integrative Core: Introduction to Modeling and Experimentation in Biomedical Engineering
courses.description: An introduction to how engineers approach problems - via conceptual models that are then used to create wet lab models and in silico models.

courses.title: Integrative Core: Experimental Design-Measurements at the Right Spatial and Temporal Scales
courses.description: This integrative core course focuses on the design of experiments to answer scientific questions, with an emphasis on the spatial and temporal scales of measurements.

courses.title: Integrative Core: Problem Solving with Computational Models
courses.description: An introduction to computational model methodologies for complex biomedical/biological systems.  Emphasis is placed on developing well-posed scientific hypotheses through the use of simulations.

courses.title: Advanced Seminar: Biomaterials & Regenerative Medicine
courses.description: This course is intended to promote critical review of the "State-of-the-art" biomaterial technologies to identify knowledge gaps that must be overcome to further biomaterials development.

courses.title: Advanced Seminar: Cardiovascular Biology & Biomechanics
courses.description: To review current topics in cardiovascular engineering, biology and diseases through critical literature review.  In addition, each student will develop and present a "Proposal" by the end of the class.

courses.title: Advanced Seminar: Cellular & Biomolecular Engineering
courses.description: This seminar course illustrates the development of micro- and nano-scale engineering approaches for studies of biomolecules and cells and their applications to medicine.

courses.title: Stem Cell Engineering
courses.description: Fundamentals for the application of analytical engineering approaches to the quantitative study of stem cell biology and translation into cell therapies and diagnostics.

courses.title: Introduction to Multiscale Analysis in Systems
courses.description: The class explores modeling analyses spanning multiple levels of biological organization at different resolutions of detail.  Emphasis is placed on control in complex biological systems.

courses.title: Mathematical Models in Biology & Medicine
courses.description: The course introduces the student to a representative set of models that elucidate the nature of biological and medical phenomena.

courses.title: Biochemical Systems Analysis
courses.description: The course introduces BME students interested in mathematical modeling and systems biology to the computational analysis of metabolic and other dynamic systems in biology.

courses.title: 3D Bioprinting
courses.description: Principal concepts underpinning 3D bioprinting (a rapidly growing tissue/organ manufacturing technology), various printing strategies, and their applications in the biomedical field.

courses.title: Advanced Seminar: Neuroengineering and Neuropathology
courses.description: Current issues in neuroengineering.  Focus is placed on neuropathological complexity across cellular and organ level scales through literature reading, discussion, and independent study.

courses.title: Quantitative Neuroscience
courses.description: A quantitative presentation of neural signal processing and information coding, emphasizing the circuitry of sensory and motor pathways of the brain.

courses.title: Robotics Professional Preparation
courses.description: Preparation for a professional career in Robotics. Local & visiting speakers. Program introduction. Technical resume preparation. GT Robotics labs & resources.

courses.title: Robotics Professional Preparation 2
courses.description: Preparation for a professional career in Robotics. Local & visiting speakers. Selecting and applying for Internship. Developing capstone project proposal. Public speaking practice and preparation.

courses.title: Robotics Professional Preparation 3
courses.description: Preparation for a professional career in Robotics. Local & visiting speakers. Interview preparation & career search. Technical report writing and presentation.

courses.title: Introduction to Robotics Research
courses.description: Familiarizes students with the core of robotics: mechanics, control, perception, AI, and autonomy.  Provides an introduction to the mathematical tools required in robotics research. Cross-listed with AE 7785, ECE 7785, and CS 7785.

courses.title: Robotics Internship
courses.description: Graduate Internship at a partner company, GTRI or a GT Robotics lab.

courses.title: Robotics Capstone Project
courses.description: Teams or individuals apply the knowledge and skills acquired throughout the MS program to a faculty supervised robotics project.

courses.title: Multidisciplinary Robotics Research I
courses.description: Multidisciplinary research course supervised by two robotics faculty from different schools participating in the robotics Ph.D. program. Cross-listed with AE, CS, and ECE 8750.

courses.title: Multidisciplinary Robotics Research II
courses.description: Continuation of BMED 8750 (Multidisciplinary Robotics Research I). Cros-listed with AE, CS, and ECE 8751.

courses.description: Topics of current interest in biomedical engineering.
