courses.description: Addresses how today's construction industry is organized and its particular characteristics, how it evolved from early times and where it may be heading in the future.

courses.title: Urban Design Laboratory
courses.description: Urban design laboratory problems focusing on analysis, design, and implementation strategies for contemporary urban problems.

courses.title: Art and Architecture in Classical Greece
courses.description: An intensive on-site investigation of the role that the arts and architecture have played in the development of classical Greek civilization.

courses.title: Art and Architecture in Italy I
courses.description: Investigations of the painting, sculpture, and architecture of the Classical, Early Christian, Byzantine, and Medieval periods in Italy with special emphasis on Rome.

courses.title: Art and Architecture in Italy II
courses.description: Investigations of the painting, sculpture, and architecture of the Renaissance and Baroque periods in Italy with special emphasis on the works of Rome.

courses.title: Retrofitting the Suburbia
courses.description: Study of suburban redevelopment trends, projects, and policies that improve environmental, social, and economic sustainability, with an emphasis on urban design strategies.

courses.title: History of Urban Form
courses.description: History of the city as a collective work of architecture with an emphasis on the city's physical form and space.  Credit not allowed for both COA 6151 and ARCH 4151.

courses.title: Design of Design Environments
courses.description: Analysis of design processes; analysis of current design tools at both the user interface and functional levels; procedures for developing better design tools.  Credit not allowed for both COA 6763 and ID 6763 or CS 6763.

courses.title: Geometric Modeling
courses.description: Software development course focusing on 3D geometric constructions and modeling;  emphasizes solid modeling and its role in design.  Crosslisted with CS 6764.

courses.title: Urban Design Studio I
courses.description: Advanced urban design problems emphasizing the application of contemporary urban design research and multidisciplinary collaboration into the design process.

courses.title: Urban Design Studio II
courses.description: Advanced urban design problems emphasizing the application of contemporary urban design research and multidisciplinary collaboration into the design process.

courses.title: PhD Planning Seminar
courses.description: Discussion of research and pedagogy topics and methodologies for city and regional planning.

courses.title: The Genesis of Architecture
courses.description: The nature of architecture illustrated from those of all cultures; determinist theories; its social values and its meanings to the individual- material, physical, anthropological, and cognitive.

courses.title: Thought and Interpretation in Architecture from the Hellenic Period to the 1830's
courses.description: A survey of architectural thought and theory taking account of other fields; paralleled by a review of major critical texts and assessments to the present day.

courses.title: Thought and Interpretation in Architecture from the 1830's to the Twentieth Century
courses.description: A survey of architectural thoughts and theory taking account other fields; paralleled by a review of major critical texts and assessments to the present day.

courses.title: The Design and Evolution of American Space
courses.description: Topical seminar on the development of urban, suburban, and rural American spatial forms, with emphasis on the relationship between public order and vernacular settlement.

courses.title: Theories of Inquiry in Architecture
courses.description: Introduction to research paradigms and their assumptions. The formulation of questions and frameworks of description, representation, analysis, interpretation, and data control.

courses.title: Theories of Architecture, Space and Culture
courses.description: Accounts of the social functions of architectural space and associated design choices, across a variety of building types and scales of environmental design. Credit will not be awarded for both COA 8630 and ARCH 4630.

courses.title: Architecture and Policy:  Linking Theory and Practice
courses.description: Methods and theories of planning, design, facilities management, and evaluation as they relate to organizational policy and development.

courses.title: Theories of Psychology for Architecture
courses.description: An examination of social and psychological theory as it is applied to the creation and use of space.

courses.title: Analytical Models of Built Space and Its Functions
courses.description: Introduction to analytical ideas and methodologies for the quantitative description of built space, form, building use, and functions.  Layouts as configurations: boundaries, accessibility, visibility, extensions.

courses.title: Formal Descriptions of Designs: Analyses of Space, Shape, and Form
courses.description: Introduction to the form and computational description of designs, with an emphasis on spatial patterns. Geometrical constructions, combinatorial approaches, analyses of shape.

courses.title: Research Seminar in Design Computation
courses.description: Seminar review of developments in computing applied to architecture; current major research issues.

courses.title: Structuring Multimedia Design Knowledge
courses.description: Theories and tools for structuring multimedia knowledge for design and designers.

courses.title: Design and Engineering Databases
courses.description: Survey of database use in design and engineering; surveys relational, object-oriented database technology, and ISO-STEP methods of integration.

courses.title: Performance Aspects of Building Systems Design
courses.description: Engineering analysis of building (sub) systems based on a performance ontology.  Criteria, metrics, and tools for performance aspect evaluations in different building technology domains.

courses.title: Computational Building Simulation
courses.description: Numerical simulation of performance characteristics of whole buildings.  Review of the finite element method for uniform treatment of transport phenomena in different building technology domains.

courses.title: Integrated Design and Engineering Environments for Buildings
courses.description: Surveys of issues for effective integration of heterogeneous design tools for building; previous efforts, current approaches; advanced techniques, including ISO-STEP and IAI.

courses.description: Introduction to microelectronics and nanotechnology: the communications revolution, Moore's law, semiconductors, transistors, MEMS, photonics, analylsis of common technological objects, global impact on technology and society.

courses.title: Introduction to Urban and Regional Planning
courses.description: This course provides an overview of how cities and metropolitan regions are planned including discussions of urban history, current events, and future prospects for cities.

courses.title: Atlanta Past, Present, and Future
courses.description: This community-engaged course will cover 19th, 20th, and 21st century urban history and theory, seen through the lens of Atlanta’s unique history and character.

courses.title: Cities of Tomorrow
courses.description: This course explores how the forces shaping 21st-century cities compare to the dynamics that shaped cities of the past and present.

courses.title: Sustainable Urban Development
courses.description: This course introduces students to the theory and practice of sustainability as applied to the built environment at scales from the site to the megaregion.

courses.title: World Cities
courses.description: This class explores the past evolution of world cities, the enormous challenges they face in the present, and the opportunities for innovative, sustainable urban solutions.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. Undergraduate research under the guidance of a faculty member for the first years and sophmores.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. Undergraduate research under the guidance of a faculty member for first years and sophomores.

courses.title: Qualitative Analysis and Research Design
courses.description: This course is about enabling community engagement through survey design and data analysis, and other participatory methods.

courses.title: Quantitative Analysis in Planning
courses.description: Analytical methods in planning including inferential statistics, linear regression, and analysis of variance and how they are applied to planning problems.

courses.title: Foundations of Urban and Regional Development
courses.description: The course describes the economic function of cities and the significant factors that shape their growth and development.

courses.title: Introduction to Urban and Regional Planning
courses.description: This course provides an overview of the planning of cities and metropolitan regions.  The legal and historical context as well as substantive areas of urban planning are addressed.

courses.title: The City and Its Technology
courses.description: This course places urban infrastructure technology within the larger context of planning and development. The social and economic aspects of these systems are highlighted.

courses.title: The City in Fiction and Film
courses.description: Examines images and perceptions of the urban environment as portrayed in literature and cinema.  Explores the social, economic, and cultural contexts that impact on conception of the city.

courses.title: Negotiation, Facilitation, and Conflict Management
courses.description: Theoretical and practical instruction on techniques of negotiation and consensus building using case studies and training exercises.

courses.title: Sustainable Cities Studio
courses.description: This course provides students with a faculty-supervised community engagement experience in developing a sustainability-related project for a non-profit, business, or government agency.

courses.title: Urban Data Science
courses.description: This course explores the intersection of data analytics, big data, and artificial intelligence in the context of urban environments.

courses.title: Land Conservation
courses.description: This course considers the distinctive American view of land and history of the conservation movement, then discusses the why and how of modern land conservation.

courses.title: Introduction to Climate Change Planning
courses.description: This course equips students with the knowledge and methods necessary to undertake the next generation of state, local, corporate, and enterprise climate action planning.

courses.title: Environmental Planning and Impact Assessment
courses.description: Covers the principles of environmental planning and decision making. Examines the methods and processes, and environmental impact assessment and regulation.

courses.title: Urban Transportation and Planning
courses.description: This course is designed to introduce the fundamentals of urban transportation planning and policy and is applicable to students in a variety of concentrations of study. The purpose of the course will be to acquaint students with transportation planning as a profession and the types of projects that transportation planners are required to conduct.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Geographic Information Systems
courses.description: The course provides a basic understanding of the tools for collecting, storing, and analyzing spatially distributed data. Basic issues of software design and application are covered.

courses.title: Environmental Geographic Information Systems
courses.description: This course focuses on the application of geographic information systems (GIS) to environmental problems. It highlights the types and sources of data appropriate to those applications.

courses.title: Climate Change Analytics
courses.description: This course addresses the global problem of climate change using powerful, recently-developed tools from the fields of data science and geospatial analytics.

courses.title: Socioeconomic Geographic Information Systems
courses.description: This GIS course addresses the collection, management, analysis, and interpretation of spatial social, economic, housing, and demographic information.

courses.title: Introduction to Real Estate Investment
courses.description: Introduction to real estate analysis and utilization. Subjects include attributes of real property, value determinations, appraisal, investment analysis, market analysis, asset management, and public aspects.

courses.title: Housing and Real Estate Economics
courses.description: Examination of private and public sector approaches to housing.  Economic theory of durable goods, demand elasticities, applied market research analyses, and history of public intervention.

courses.description: Topics of current interest not covered in other courses in the department.

courses.title: Introduction to Fields of Planning
courses.description: Introduction to the various subfields of planning through reading, discussion, and guest lectures by practicing planners.  Course also covers professional ethics and career planning and development.

courses.title: Freehand Drawing for Planners
courses.description: This courses teaches planning students through drawing to record, analyze, conceptualize, and represent commonly recurring physical and diagrammatic relationships that occur in the physical environment.

courses.title: Visualization for Planners
courses.description: Explores visual and representational techniques and methods for physical planning, introducing a common set of computer applications designed to enhance visual representation and communication.

courses.title: Theory and History of Planning
courses.description: Examines theories of planning and the public interest. Considers the roles of planners within the American political system and the historical development of the planning profession.

courses.title: Growth Management Law and Implementation
courses.description: Study of legal framework of planning focusing on managing development to achieve desired outcomes for the economy, society, and the environment.

courses.title: Quantitative and Computer Methods
courses.description: Introduction to computing and quantitative methods in planning. Discusses commonly used data sources, data management, presentation techniques, and planning analytical models.

courses.title: Advanced Planning Methods
courses.description: Analytical methods in planning including inferential statistics, linear regression, and analysis of variance and how they are applied to planning problems.

courses.title: Economic Analysis for Planning
courses.description: Applications of economic principles to planning, including market theory, public goods, externalities, cost benefit analysis, and project economics.

courses.title: Urban and Regional Development Theory
courses.description: Study of theories in the structure and function of cities and regions.  Emphasis on the economic forces shaping urban development.

courses.title: Demographic and Economic Analysis of Urban Areas
courses.description: This course considers the social and economic structure of urban areas from a demographic perspective.  Population structure, population change, and migration are explored.

courses.title: Theory and History of Planning
courses.description: Examines theories of planning and the public interest, the intellectual and historical development of the planning profession, and the roles of planners within political systems.

courses.title: Community Dynamics and Engagement
courses.description: Study of theories and dynamics of community-building, with a focus on working in communities, equity and inclusive community engagement.

courses.title: Planning Law, Regulation and Implementation
courses.description: Study of legal framework of planning focusing on managing development and increasing opportunity to achieve desired outcomes for the economy, society, and the environment.

courses.title: Applied Planning Studio
courses.description: Analysis and preparation of alternatives for an existing neighborhood, community, or region.  Emphasis on application of planning skills in a real-world situation.

courses.title: Applied Planning Studio (Urban Design)
courses.description: The studio investigates urban physical settings. It emphasizes processes from visual representation, performanece evaluations to design decision making of future sustainable urban systems.

courses.title: Planning Studio
courses.description: Analysis and preparation of alternatives for an existing neighborhood, community, or region. Emphasis on application of planning skills in a real-world situation.

courses.title: Land Conservation
courses.description: This course considers the distinctive American view of land and history of the conservation movement, then discusses the why and how of modern land conservation.

courses.title: Introduction to Land Use Planning
courses.description: This course introduces students to land use planning.  The basic rationale for land use planning and its form in different states is covered.

courses.title: Land Use Planning Methods
courses.description: This course explores the techniques of land use planning and applies them to specific land use types.

courses.title: Introduction to Climate Change Planning
courses.description: This course equips students with the knowledge and methods necessary to develop the next generation fo state, local, corporate, and enterprise climate action planning.

courses.title: Urb Env Plan & Design
courses.description: This course introduces students to the basic theoretical and analytical underpinnings of urban environmental planning and design.

courses.title: Environmental Planning and Impact Assessment
courses.description: Examines the principles, processes, and methods of environmental planning.  Focus on environmental science and its use in impact assessment and project evaluation.

courses.title: Climate Change and the City
courses.description: The course explores land use and urban design strategies for adapting to climate change in cities and on local hazard mitigation policy.

courses.title: Policy Tools for Environmental Management
courses.description: The course covers the regulatory, market, and procedural tools used to manage the environment. It examines the strengths and weaknesses of alternative techniques.

courses.title: Sustainable Urban Development
courses.description: Explores the principles and practice of sustainable urban development and the role of planning.

courses.title: Water Resources Planning
courses.description: Fundamentals of water resources planning and watershed management. Emphasis on urban water resources problems, policies, and practices.

courses.title: Health Impact Assessment
courses.description: Students conduct an HIA, evaluate a completed HIA and propose approaches to institutionalizing HIA in institutions that traditionally do not focus on health outcomes.

courses.title: Hazardous Waste Planning and Management
courses.description: Examines the planning tools and management techniques for the proper use, storage, transport, and disposal of hazardous material and waste products.

courses.title: Environmental Law
courses.description: This course introduces students to the framework of legislation that shapes environmental planning and policy, including NEPA, Clean Air Act, and Clean Water Act.

courses.title: Introduction to Transportation Planning
courses.description: Overview course in transportation planning including basic principles to understanding transportation, current transportation problems, transportation policy, and decision-making processes and methods.

courses.title: Transportation Planning Methods and Investment Decisions
courses.description: Review of transportation methods and how they interface with investment decisions.  How transportation planners at the local, regional, state, and federal levels employ methods.

courses.title: Urban Transportation Planning Methods and Investment Decisions
courses.description: Review of methods employed by transportation planners to estimate and predict travel flows, design transport systems, and inform local, regional and national investment decisions.

courses.title: Land Use and Transportation Interaction
courses.description: Overview of land use and transportation planning principles, how development impacts transportation, how transportation investments impact development patterns and air quality.

courses.title: Urban Design and Non-Motorized Accessibility
courses.description: Examines role and opportunity to make walking and biking viable travel options in urban environments and how urban environments need to be designed to encourage non-motorized travel.

courses.title: Transportation and Economic Development
courses.description: Impact of transportation infrastructure investments on economic outcomes at a range of geographic scales including neighborhood, municipality, regional, and statewide.

courses.title: Regional Transportation Planning and Administration
courses.description: This course will address the administrative, political, methodological, and social issues underlying the regional transportation planning process.

courses.title: Foundations of Local Economic Development Planning and
courses.description: Policy Introduction to local economic development planning, examining theory, process and practice, international and regional factors, public and private roles.

courses.title: Economic Development Analysis and Practice
courses.description: This course focuses on strategy development, methods of analysis, and approaches to practice for urban and regional economic development policy and planning.

courses.title: Industrial Restructuring and Its Planning Implications
courses.description: Examines industrial restructuring trends and theoretical frameworks; develops industry case studies; and considers economic development planning's role in industrial restructuring.

courses.title: Equity, Social Justice, and Economic Development
courses.description: Explores concepts and theories of equity and social justice, analysis of indicators of (in)justice/equity, and economic development planning's role in promoting equity and social justice.

courses.title: Urban Development Policy
courses.description: Introduces elements of urban policy and economic development by examining them historically, nationally, and locally. Approaches to urban development and redevelopment are analyzed.

courses.title: Introduction to Geographic Information Systems
courses.description: This course introduces students to spatial analysis using geographic information systems.  Fundamentals of software design and geographic data are covered.

courses.title: Advanced Geographic Information Systems
courses.description: The course provides students with advanced spatial analysis techniques including network analysis, three-dimensional surface modeling, and GIS application development.

courses.title: Introduction to Remote Sensing
courses.description: This course introduces students to the collection and use of satellite imagery and other remote sensing data.

courses.title: Environmental Analysis Using GIS
courses.description: This course focuses on the application of geographic information systems (GIS) to environmental problems. It highlights the types and sources of data appropriate to those applications.

courses.title: Transport & GIS
courses.description: Transportation data models, data processing, modeling, and service delivery in geographical information systems.

courses.title: Public Health Analytics
courses.description: Presents a comprehensive socioecological framework for conducting healthy places research and practice, and metrics and analytical methods to measure and model health determinants and outcomes.

courses.title: Climate Change Analytics
courses.description: This course addresses the  global problem of climate change using powerful, recently-developed tools from the fields of data science and geospatial analytics.

courses.title: Spatial Analysis of Socioeconomic Data
courses.description: This course provides students with an in-depth study of the spatial distribution of human activity, including population, housing, and employment.  Credit not allowed for both CP 6551 and CP 6570.

courses.title: Design of Smart Urban Systems
courses.description: The course integrates data analytics, systems science and urban design. It covers theories, methods, modeling tools and case studies in the context of smart cities.

courses.title: Geodemographics: Data Sources and Methods
courses.description: Explores important secondary data sources used by planners and analysts working with smaller geographic areas. Experience with hardware and software used to analyze data.

courses.title: Socioeconomic GIS
courses.description: This advanced GIS course addresses the collection, management, analysis, and interpretation of spatial social, economic, housing, and demographic information.  Credit not allowed for both CP 6570 and CP 6551.

courses.title: Programming for Geographic Information Systems
courses.description: This course teaches fundamental programming skills for geoprocessing and data presentation in a geographic information system environment. The primary languages used are Python and Javascript.

courses.title: GIS Professionalization
courses.description: This course provides MSGIST students with a bridge from the academic world to the professional GIS world.

courses.title: Capstone Project Research
courses.description: This course allows students to select a MSGIST capstone project topic, conduct a professional and academic literature review, and assemble required spatial datasets.

courses.title: GIS Systems Design and Management
courses.description: This course equips students to address a range of issues related to GIS data acquisition, database design, system configuration, and project management.

courses.title: GIS Capstone Project
courses.description: Students plan and execute a major professional project using standard GIS methodologies, and communicate the project results in written, graphic, and public presentation formats.

courses.title: Principles of Real Estate Finance and Development
courses.description: Introduction to principles of real estate finance, focusing on the role the public sector plays in making desirable development projects financially feasible.

courses.title: Community Development
courses.description: This course will examine neighborhood-based efforts, public policy, trends and practices that have shaped community development in American inner city communities since 1950.

courses.title: Real Estate Market Research
courses.description: Introduction to real estate market research with particular focus on analyses of housing and office markets.

courses.title: Government and Housing Markets
courses.description: Examination of the operation of local housing markets and national, state, regional, and local housing policies.

courses.title: Applied Real Estate Development Methods
courses.description: Application of the development process, market and financial feasibility analyses, and public policy to large development projects.  Extensive use of case studies involving professional developers.

courses.title: Asset-Based Community Development in Practice
courses.description: Introduces and reviews the basics of Asset-Based Community Development (ABCD): working with communities based on their assets, or strengths. In collaboration with community partners, students explore ABCD in action via campus and community site visits.

courses.title: Citizen Participation and Community Engagement
courses.description: This course discusses planners' reasons fro engaging communitites in the planning process, evaluates various engagement methods, and produces a guide to direct future practice.

courses.title: Urban Transportation Planning
courses.description: An overview course on the history, finance, operations, modeling, politics, environmental impacts, and planning of urban transportation systems in the United States.

courses.title: Urban Transportation Planning Laboratory
courses.description: Transportation planning/engineering laboratory and field experience.

courses.title: Introduction to Global Development
courses.description: Introduces the goals, theories and key institutional actors involved in Global Development.

courses.title: Negotiation and Conflict Management
courses.description: Practical and theoretical instruction on techniques of negotiation and consensus building using training exercises and case studies.  Emphasizes environmental, policy, planning, and development disputes.  Crosslisted with PUBP 6760.

courses.title: Negotiation, Facilitation, and Conflict Management
courses.description: Theoretical and practical instruction on techniques of negotiation and consensus building using case studies and training exercises.

courses.title: Cinema City
courses.description: Explores people's response to cities, augmenting the empirical analysis that is urban studies domain with the subjective perspectives of cinematic artists.

courses.title: Basic Methods of Policy Analysis and Planning
courses.description: Synthesizes elements of the program core's analytic techniques and employs them in a case study context. Cases address urban policy, planning, and management.

courses.title: Public Sector Finance and Budgeting
courses.description: Theory and practice of public finance. Emphasis on applications in local government revenue collection, budgeting, and expenditure analysis.

courses.title: Urban Growth and Infrastructure Systems
courses.description: This course provides students with a basic understanding of urban infrastructure systems and their role in shaping urban growth and development.

courses.title: Introduction to Urban Design
courses.description: An introduction to the study, research, and practice of urban design examining traditional design principles and their application to the contemporary city.

courses.title: Urban Design Policy: Analysis and Implementation
courses.description: Urban design policy making and its implementation including an analysis of the behavioral basis for policies that promote quality in built form.  Credit not allowed for both CP 6834 and ARCH 6303.

courses.title: Urban Ecological Design
courses.description: This course engages the contemporary issues of urban ecology and its articulation to design.  It explores relationship between urban forms, and flows of ecology, energy, material, water and information.  Credit not allowed for both CP 6836 and ARCH 6447.

courses.title: Public Health and the Built Environment
courses.description: This interdisciplinary course examines how cities and neighborhoods can have both positive and adverse effects on human health, and produces recommendations to improve these outcomes.

courses.title: Urban Analytics Capstone Project
courses.description: Students prepare to execute a major professional project using urban analytics methodologies and communicate the project results in written, graphic, and public presentation formats.

courses.title: Urban Analytics Capstone Project
courses.description: Students plan and execute a major professional project using urban analytics methodologies, and communicate the project results in written, graphic, and public presentation formats.

courses.title: Master's Thesis
courses.description: Provides students with an opportunity to pursue advanced research under the guidance of a faculty committee.

courses.title: Preparation for Ph.D. Qualification Exam
courses.description: Preparation for the Ph.D. Qualification Exam.

courses.title: Doctoral Planning Seminar
courses.description: This course provides students and faculty an opportunity to present and discuss planning research.

courses.title: PhD Foundations Seminar
courses.description: Incoming City and Regional Planning doctoral students reflect upon research, assess opportunities afforded by doctoral education, and develop a plan of study for the program.

courses.title: PhD Seminar in Research and Pedagogy
courses.description:
Students conceptualize and share ongoing research with their peers, develop professional and pedagogical skills, and explore issues of student and career
development.

courses.title: Advanced Planning Theory
courses.description: Seminar on planning theory, including philosophy of science, political philosophy and ethical theory.  The course explores the theoretical basis for planning as a social activity.  Credit not allowed for both CP 8200 and COA 8520.

courses.title: Advanced Urban and Regional Development Theory
courses.description: Examines principal urban-regional economic, and spatial theories for explaining economic, social and physical forces influencing locations, growth and decline of cities and regions. Credit not allowed for both CP 8300 and COA 8540.

courses.title: Research Design and Qualitative Methods
courses.description: Examines issues associated with the design and methodological implementation of planning and applied social research, with a focus on techniques for qualitative inquiry.  Credit not allowed for both CP 8400 and COA 8510.

courses.title: Advanced Quantitative Research Methods for Planning, Policy and Design
courses.description: This course addresses two complementary topics: the design of quantitative research related to planning, design, and policy; and advanced statistical techniques for accomplishing such research.  Credit not allowed for both CP 8505 and COA 8510.

courses.description: Topics of current interest in land use planning.

courses.description: For graduate students holding graduate teaching assistantships.

courses.title: Research Assistantship
courses.description: For graduate students holding graduate research assistantships.

courses.title: Doctoral Dissertation
courses.description: For City Planning Ph.D. candidates writing their dissertations.

courses.title: Freshman Leap Seminar
courses.description: Small group discussions with first year students are led by one or more faculty members and include a variety of foundational, motivational, and topical subjects for computationalist.

courses.title: Introductory Computing in MATLAB
courses.description: For students with a solid introductory computing background needing to demonstrate proficiency in the MATLAB language.

courses.title: Introduction to Computing
courses.description: Introduction to computing principles and programming practices with an emphasis on the design, construction and implementation of problem solutions use of software tools.

courses.title: Introduction to Computing for Computer Science Recitation
courses.description: Recitation for CS 1301.

courses.title: Introduction to Media Computation
courses.description: Introduction to computation (algorithmic thinking, data structures, data transformation and processing, and programming) in a media and communication context. Credit not awarded for both CS 4452 and CS 1315.

courses.title: CS 1315 Recitation
courses.description: Recitation for CS 1315.

courses.title: Representing Structure and Behavior
courses.description: Modeling the structure of media (e.g., music, graphical scenes) using dynamic data structures. Designing objects as encapsulations of structure and behavior. Algorithms for simulating objects. May not be taken for credit by students who have credit for CS 1322.

courses.title: Introduction to Object Oriented Programming
courses.description: Introduction to techniques and methods of object-oriented programming such an encapsulation, inheritance, and polymorphism. Emphasis on software development and individual programming skills.

courses.title: CS 1331 Recitation
courses.description: Recitation for CS 1331.

courses.title: Data Structures and Algorithms for Applications
courses.description: Computer data structures and algorithms in the context of object-oriented programming. Focus on software development towards applications.

courses.title: CS 1332 Recitation
courses.description: Recitation for CS 1332.

courses.title: Computing for Engineers
courses.description: Foundations of computing with an introduction to design and analysis of algorithms and an introduction to design and construction of programs for engineering problem-solving.

courses.title: CS 1371 Recitation
courses.description: Recitation for CS 1371.

courses.title: Structured Program Design for Engineers
courses.description: Design, analysis and implementation of programs for engineering problem-solving using ANSI Standard C, with an introduction to C++.

courses.title: Introduction to Discrete Mathematics for Computer Science
courses.description: Proof methods, strategy, correctness of algorithms over discrete structures.  Induction and recursion.  Complexity and order of growth.  Number theoretic principles and algorithms.  Counting and computability.  Credit not allowed for both CS 2050 and CS 2051.

courses.title: CS 2050 Recitation
courses.description: Recitation for CS 2050.

courses.title: Honors - Induction to Discrete Mathematics for Computer Science
courses.description: Proof methods, strategy, correctness of algorithms over discrete structures.  Induction and recursion.  Complexity and order of growth.  Number theoretic principles and algorithms.  Counting and computability.  Credit not allowed for both CS 2051 and CS 2050.

courses.title: Computer Organization and Programming
courses.description: An introduction to basic computer hardware, machine language, assembly language, and C programming.

courses.title: Computer Systems and Networks
courses.description: A broad exposure to computer system structure and networking including software abstractions in operating systems for orchestrating the usage of the computing resources.

courses.title: Media Device Architectures
courses.description: Controlling the interface between hardware and software in media devices. Machine-level programming (e.g., in C) to create graphics, generate sound, and support user interaction.

courses.title: Data Manipulation for Science and Industry
courses.description: Reading, manipulating, and exporting data for engineering, business, and scientific applications.  Covers GUI's, File I/O, basic SQL, and web scraping.  Emphasis on software development.

courses.title: CS 2316 Recitation
courses.description: Recitation for CS 2316.

courses.title: Software Practicum
courses.description: Methods for solving large programming problems. Techniques for quality assurance, managing programs, working in teams, analyzing problems, and producing effective solutions.

courses.title: Objects and Design
courses.description: Object-oriented programming methods for dealing with large programs.  Focus on quality processes, effective debugging techniques, and testing to assure a quality product.

courses.title: Advanced Practical Object-Oriented Programming
courses.description: This course presents important programming principles that should be considered when using a non-automatic memory management complex language (such as C++). Templating, generic programming, resource acquisition is initialization (RAII), and smart pointers are a few examples. Credit not awarded for both CS 2345 and ECE 2036.

courses.title: Knowledge Representation and Processing
courses.description: Introduction to the representation and manipulation of complex symbolic and sub-symbolic information.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research Assistantship
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Startup Lab: Introduction to Technology Ventures
courses.description: Elements of technology venture creation including opportunity identification and validation, ideation, customer discovery, markey analysis, minimum viable product development, business models, intellectual property, and capital raises. Cross-listed with COE 2701.

courses.title: CS 2701 Recitation
courses.description: Recitation for CS 2701.

courses.title: Foundations of Mathematics and Computing
courses.description: This course introduces the essential mathematical concepts and computational techniques that form the basis of modern computing.

courses.title: Computing, Society, and Professionalism
courses.description: Examines the role and impact of information and communication technology in society, with emphasis on ethical, professional, and public policy issues.

courses.title: Computer Science Ventures
courses.description: Students will learn how computer-science-based ventures are developed.  The course is project-based.  Students propose, analylze, pitch, design, implement, package and market web-2.0 and virtual-world-based products and services.

courses.title: Design of Operating Systems
courses.description: Operating systems concepts, including multi-threading, scheduling, synchronization, communication, and access control.  Projects will cover design and implementation of several operating systems components.

courses.title: Computer Structures: Hardware/Software Codesign of a Processor
courses.description: Principles in pipelined processor design, with emphasis on the need for a close interaction between code generation and architecture.

courses.title: Introduction to Information Security
courses.description: Terms/concepts for threats; controls; problem definition; comprehensive information security model; security for operating systems, databases, network/distributed systems; administering security.

courses.title: Human Dimension of Cybersecurity: People, Organizations, Societies
courses.description: This course will illuminate the human dimension of cybersecurity, and explore the attitudes, behaviors and perceptions associated with different stakeholders in cybersecurity.

courses.title: Languages and Computation
courses.description: Interpreters as abstract machines and the tools used to construct them, such as scanners and parsers. An introduction to models of computation as embodied by different programming languages.  Limits of and relationships between these models.

courses.title: Computer Networking I
courses.description: Introduction to problems in computer networking, including error recovery, medium access, routing, flow control, and transport. Emphasis on current best practice.  Includes programming of networked applications.

courses.title: Introduction to Software Engineering
courses.description: Team-based project class to introduce and apply software engineering principles and practices.

courses.title: Part 1 of a 2 semester project design and implementation sequence conjoined with Tech Communications
courses.description: Part 1 of a 2 semester project design and implementation sequence conjoined with Technical Communications. Prepare requirements, design and project plans.  Develop a basic prototype of the desired system. Project is completed in CS 3312-Project Implementation. Credit will not be awared for CS 3311 and CS 4911.

courses.title: Project Implementation
courses.description: The second part of a 2 semester project design and implementation sequence conjoined with Technical Communications. Implement a project designed in CS 3311. Credit will not be awarded for CS 3312 and CS 4911.

courses.title: Computer Graphics
courses.description: Geometric constuctions; transformations; perception; reflection models; photorealistic; non-photorealistic, and image-based rendering; rendering software and API's; triangle-mesh processing; graphic acceleration; user-interaction, design and animation.

courses.title: Design and Analysis of Algorithms
courses.description: Basic techniques of design and analysis of efficient algorithms for standard computational problems. NP-Completeness.  Credit not allowed for both CS 3510 and CS 3511.

courses.title: Design and Analysis of Algorithms, Honors
courses.description: Techniques of design and analysis of efficient algorithms for standard computational problems.  NP-Completeness Project.  Credit not allowed for both CS 3511 and CS 3510.

courses.title: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence
courses.description: An introduction to artificial intelligence and machine learning. Topics include intelligent system design methodologies, search and problem solving, supervised and reinforced learning.

courses.title: Introduction to Perception and Robotics
courses.description: Covers fundamental problems and leading solutions for computer and robot perception and action from the point of view of autonomous robot navigation.

courses.title: Prototyping Intelligent Devices
courses.description: Hands-on course teaching the fundamentals of electronics of electrical and mechanical prototyping.

courses.title: CS 3651 Recitation
courses.description: Recitation for CS 3651.

courses.title: Analysis of Emerging Technologies
courses.description: Analysis of emerging technologies and their impacts for firm practice, market practice, policy, and society. Credit not allowed for both CS 3743 and MGT 3743 or ME 3743.

courses.title: Managing Product, Service & Technology Development
courses.description: Analysis of the managerial challenges of the product development process.

courses.title: Human Computer Interface Design and Evaluation
courses.description: Human computer interface is considered in terms of user-system compatibility. Concepts in human factors and interface design are covered in relation to capabilities of both humans and computers. Crosslisted with PSYC 3750.

courses.title: Introduction to User Interface Design
courses.description: Describes the characteristics of interaction between humans and computers and demonstrates techniques for the design and evaluation of user interfaces and computational systems.

courses.title: Introduction to Cognitive Science
courses.description: Multidisciplinary perspectives on cognitive science. Interdisciplinary approaches to issues in cognition, including memory, language, problem solving, learning, perception, and action. Crosslisted with PST, PSYC, and ISYE 3790.

courses.title: Computing, Society, and Professionalism
courses.description: Examines the role and impact of information and communication technology in society, with emphasis on ethical, professional, and public policy issues. Credit not allowed for both CS 4001 and 4002.

courses.title: Robots and Society
courses.description: Examines the role and impact of robotics, distributed sensing and actuation, ubiquitous computing and related technology in society, emphasizing ethical, professional and public policy issues. Credit not allowed for both CS 4001 and 4002.

courses.title: AI, Ethics, and Society
courses.description: This course covers various Artificial Intelligence and bias mitigation techniques that can be used to counterbalance the potential misuse and abuse of learning from data.

courses.title: Next-Generation Computing Technologies
courses.description: Students will explore new paradigms in how content is created, distributed, and consumed, with hands-on demos of next-generation computing technologies.

courses.title: Introduction to Computer Law
courses.description: Provides an introduction to copyrights, patents, trade secrets, trademarks, and commercial law pertaining to computer software and hardware.

courses.title: Systems Analysis and Design
courses.description: An introductory course on the development life cycle of business information systems.  It covers analysis and design tools and methodology.  Credit not allowed for both CS 4052 and MGT 4045.

courses.title: Business Process Analysis and Design
courses.description: Business processes are the mechanisms by which work is organized and performed. This course covers the analysis of business technology. Credit will not be awarded for both CS 4057 and MGT 4057.

courses.title: Introduction to Malware Reverse Engineering
courses.description: This course exposes students to an immersive, hands-on experience in the dissection and analysis of the code, structure, and functionality of malicious software.

courses.title: Advanced Operating Systems
courses.description: Operating system abstractions and their implementations, multi-threading, efficient inter-address communication, high-level synchronization, introduction to multi-processor and distributed operating systems, real-time systems. Credit is not awarded for both CS 4210 and CS 6210.

courses.title: Programming Embedded Systems
courses.description: Design principles, programming techniques, and case studies of embedded real-time systems.  Interface techniques and devices.  Representations and reasoning about physical processes.Credit not awarded for both CS 4220 and CS 6235.

courses.title: CS 4220 Recitation
courses.description: Recitation for CS 4220.

courses.title: Parallel Computer Architecture
courses.description: The objective of this course is to develop an in-depth understanding of the design, implementation, and evaluation of modern parallel computers.  Credit not allowed for both CS 4233 and CS 7110.

courses.title: Introduction to Information Security
courses.description: Terms/concepts, threats, controls; problem definition; comprehensive information security model; security for operating systems, databases, network/distributed systems; administering security; legal/ethical/policy issues.  Credit not allowed for both CS 4235 and CS 6035.

courses.title: Computer and Network Security
courses.description: Fundamental concepts and principles of computer security, operating system and database security, secret key and public key cryptographic algorithms, hash functions, authentication, firewalls and intrusion detection systems, IPSec ad VPN, and wireless security.

courses.title: Computer Systems Security
courses.description: Trusted computing base, hardware support for protection and virtualization, authentication, access control and authorization, discretionary and mandatory security policies, secure kernel design, and secure databases. Students cannot receive credit for CS 4238 and CS 6238.

courses.title: Enterprise Cybersecurity Management
courses.description: The duties and concerns of an enterprise Chief Information Security Officer including strategy, cybersecurity operations, risk management, and governance.

courses.title: Compilers, Interpreters, and Program Analyzers
courses.description: Study of techniques for the design and implementation of compilers, interpreters, and program analyzers, with consideration of the particular characteristics of widely used programming languages.

courses.title: Cyber Warfare
courses.description: This course provides students with a framework for understanding cyber warfare from a technological and political standpoint.

courses.title: Introduction to Data Mining and Analysis
courses.description: Computational techniques for analysis of large, complex datasets, covering fundamental aspects as well as modern data mining and analysis techniques. Cross-listed with ISYE 4245.

courses.title: Computer Networking II
courses.description: Principles of computer networks, including medium access, ARQ protocols, routing, congestion avoidance, and control. Emphasis on design options and tradeoffs. Includes significant network application programming.

courses.title: Introduction to Network Management
courses.description: Introduction to SNMP-based network management.  Practical application to network and system management including hands-on lab practice.

courses.title: Telecommunications Systems
courses.description: Study of telecommunication systems emphasizing functional roles of the various portions of the system and how various functional components support and interact with one another.

courses.title: Mobile Applications and Services for Converged Networks
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to mobile applications and services with an emphasis on voice and data service integration in modern commercial networks.

courses.title: Network Security
courses.description: Fundamental concepts of network information security, including applied cryptography, secure access methods, and vulnerabilities in network protocols and network applications. Students cannot receive credit for CS 4262 and CS 6262.

courses.title: Psychology of Cybersecurity
courses.description: This course will explore psychological processes relevant to cybersecurity. Students will gain an appreciation for psychological influence factors inherent in the current cyberspace environment.

courses.title: Technical Introduction to Blockchain and Cryptocurrencies
courses.description: Undergraduate Introduction to Blockchain and cryptocurrencies, building on formal crypto and distributed systems.  Cover fundamental and practical aspects.  Includes programming projects and a report.

courses.title: Critical Infrastructures Security and Resilience
courses.description: Critical infrastructures are large cyber-physical networks essential to the well-being of the societies they serve. We study their resilience and security against a range of disruptions.

courses.title: Data Communications Laboratory
courses.description: Detailed study of the principles of data transmission systems and their performance, reinforced by laboratory exercises.

courses.title: Survey of Telecommunications and the Law
courses.description: Overview of telecommunication regulation at the federal, state, and judicial levels; review of FCC policies and restrictions on Bell operating companies under the AT&T Consent Agreement.

courses.title: Advanced Computer Organization
courses.description: Topics concerning the hardware design of computer systems. Advanced techniques in high-performance pipelined central processing units. Memory and I/O systems. Parallel processors including shared-memory multiprocessors and cluster computers.  Credit is not allowed for both CS 4290 and any of the following courses:  CS 6290, ECE 4100, ECE 6100.

courses.title: Introduction to Software Processes
courses.description: The course will provide students with an overall context in which software systems are developed from the viewpoint of processes that support development.  Software engineering is described as the set of activities developers engage in to create high-quality products within schedule and budget constraints.

courses.title: Software Engineering Applications
courses.description: Software engineering methods specific to classes of applications or systems, including information systems and embedded, real-time systems.

courses.title: Software Generation, Testing, and Maintenance
courses.description: Methods and principles for program generation, testing, and managing the evolution of software systems.

courses.title: Introduction to Enterprise Computing
courses.description: A survey of basic software tools and techniques used in mission-critical systems and applications, combined with in-depth study of fundamental principles underlying enterprise computing.  Credit not allowed for both 4365 and CS 6365.

courses.title: Programming Languages
courses.description: Fundamentals of programming language design and theory. Topics include formal semantics and type systems for imperative, functional, and parallel languages; lambda calculus and its variants; the Curry-Howard Correspondence; techniques for proving language properties and verifying program specifications.

courses.title: Introduction to Database Systems
courses.description: Comprehensive coverage of mainstream database concepts such as the entity-relationship model, relational databases, query languages, and database design methodology. Includes a project.  Credit not allowed for both CS 4400 and CS 6402.

courses.title: Database System Implementation
courses.description: Study of fundamental software components/algorithms of a database system, including the file manager, query engine, lock manager, and recovery manager.  Includes a project component.  Credit not allowed for both CS 4420 and CS 6422.

courses.title: Advanced Database System Implementation
courses.description: Study of advanced topics in implementing a database system, including the query optimizer, concurrency control and recovery protocols. Includes a project component.

courses.title: Information Systems Design
courses.description: The analysis, design, and implementation of information systems.  Topics include requirements analysis, design representations, implementation techniques, and evaluation of systems.

courses.title: Emerging Database Technologies and Applications
courses.description: The course will cover current developments including distributed, object-oriented, temporal-spatial, Web-based, mobile, and active database technologies, and data warehousing and mining applications.

courses.title: Human-Centered Computing Concepts
courses.description: Introduction to programming and human-centered principles of computing based on a communications and media computation context. Introduces user interface programming. Credit not awarded for both CS 4452 and CS 1315.

courses.title: Video Game Design and Programming
courses.description: Techniques for electronic game design and programming, including graphics game engines, motion generation, behavioral control for autonomous characters, interaction structure, social and interface issues of multi-user play, and the business aspects of game development.  Credit not allowed for both CS 4455 and CS 6457.

courses.title: Introduction to Information Visualization
courses.description: Introduction to principles and techniques of information visualization, the presentation of primarily abstract data to help people understand, analyze and make sense of data. Students cannot receive credit for both CS 4460 and CS 6730.

courses.title: CS 4460 Recitation
courses.description: This recitation supports the information visualization (CS 4460) course. Sessions will focus on introducing students to technical work with visualization programming languages and grammars important to the course.

courses.title: Computational Journalism
courses.description: A study of computational and technological advancements in journalism with emphasis on technologies for developing new tools and their potential impact on news and information.  Credit not allowed for both CS 4464 and CS 6465.

courses.title: Introduction to User Interface Software
courses.description: Concepts, techniques, structures, and strategies for implementation of interactive software. Credit not awarded for both CS 4470 and CS 6456.

courses.title: Design of Online Communities
courses.description: Introduction to the design of online communities.  Students study an existing community in depth.  Credit not allowed for both CS 4472 and CS 6470.

courses.title: Computational Photography
courses.description: An introductory course on the scientific, technical, perceptual, and aesthetic principles of pictures. Emphasis is on the techniques of image formation, analysis, merging, modification and their use for depiction of reality on a 2D medium of photographs.

courses.title: Introduction to Computer Vision
courses.description: Introduction to computer vision including fundamentals of image formation, camera imaging geometry, feature detection and matching, stereo, motion estimation and tracking, image classification and scene understanding. Credit will not be awarded for both CS 4476 and CS 4495 or CS 6476.

courses.title: Digital Video Special Effects
courses.description: A study of digital multimedia and the analysis and synthesis of digital video.  Special attention paid to techniques for generating video special effects.

courses.title: Procedural Content Generation
courses.description: Students will learn algorithmic techniques for creating geometric models and images that can be used for games, feature films or virtual reality.

courses.title: Computer Vision
courses.description: An introduction to computer vision and machine perception. An intensive study of the process of generating a symbolic description of the scene by interpretation of images(s).

courses.title: Computer Animation
courses.description: Motion techniques for computer animation and interactive games (keyframing, procedural methods, motion capture, and simulation) and principles for storytelling, composition, lighting, and interactivity.

courses.title: Computational Aesthetics
courses.description: Aesthetics plays a key role in society and economy.  Students will invent and test beautification algorithms for colors, music, and animations and more.

courses.title: Automata and Complexity Theory
courses.description: Computational machine models and their language classes. Undecidability. Resource-bounded computations. Central complexity-theoretic concepts such as complexity classes, reducibility and completeness.

courses.title: Approximation Algorithms
courses.description: Approximation algorithms for NP-hard optimization problems, design and analysis techniques for such algorithms.  Credit not allowed for both CS 4520 and CS 7520.

courses.title: Randomized Algorithms
courses.description: Efficient randomized algorithms with improved performance over deterministic algorithms, or for NP-hard optimization problems, design and analysis techniques for such algorithms.  Credit not allowed for both CS 4530 and CS 7530.

courses.title: Advanced Algorithms
courses.description: Advanced techniques for designing and analyzing efficient algorithms for combinatorial, algebraic, and number theoretic problems.  Credit not allowed for both CS 4540 and CS 6505 or CS 4540 and CS 6515.

courses.title: Scientific Data Processing and Visualization
courses.description: Foundations and algorithms underlying the development and application of tools for the efficient transmission, analysis, filtering, and visualization of large scientific data sets.

courses.title: Verification of Systems
courses.description: Technique for verifying, validating and testing software and hardware systems. Topics covered will include modeling, abstraction methods, evaluation and certification, and computer-aided verification methods.

courses.title: Principles and Applications of Computer Audio
courses.description: A well-rounded exploration of digital audio and its importance in current research and applications. Exposes students to the principles, technology, and current research of computer audio.

courses.title: Mobile and Ubiquitous Computing
courses.description: Investigates the infrastructure required to develop mobile and ubiquitous computing applications and establishes major research themes and experimental practices.Credit not awarded for both CS 4605 and CS 7470.

courses.title: Artificial Intelligence Problem Solving
courses.description: Basic concepts and methods of AI problem solving, knowledge representation, reasoning, and learning.

courses.title: Knowledge Systems Engineering
courses.description: Techniques for constructing large knowledge-based systems. Advanced symbolic AI techniques. Constraint systems.

courses.title: Knowledge-Based Modeling and Design
courses.description: Information-processing theories of modeling and design; topics include design decision-making, problem-solving and learning, and knowledge-based modeling and design.

courses.title: Pattern Recognition
courses.description: An introductory course on pattern classification and decision problems with applications to character recognition, image analysis, and speech recognition.

courses.title: Case-Based Reasoning
courses.description: Based on human problem-solving, CBR has had many successes in industry and research.  Topics include case representation, indexing and retrieval, similarity assessment, adaptation, learning.  Credit not allowed for both CS 4622 and CS 7620.

courses.title: Intelligent and Interactive Systems
courses.description: Explores how human-computer interaction and machine learning can interact to create personalized information environments. Emphasis on current research efforts from both fields.

courses.title: Advanced Intelligent Robotics
courses.description: Hands-on course in which students program autonomous mobile robots and solve complex tasks for robot teams.

courses.title: Knowledge-Based Artificial Intelligence
courses.description: Structured knowledge representation; knowledge-based methods of reasoning and learning; problem-solving, modeling and design.

courses.title: Machine Learning
courses.description: Machine learning techniques and applications. Topics include foundational issues; inductive, analytical, numerical, and theoretical approaches; and real-world applications. Credit not awarded for both CS 4641 and CS 7641/CSE 6740/ISYE 6740/ECE 4252.

courses.title: Deep Learning
courses.description: This course will cover the fundamental underpinnings and practice of deep learning, including neural network architectures, optimization algorithms, and applications to perception and Artificial Intelligence.

courses.title: Machine Learning for Trading
courses.description: This course introduces students to the real world challenges of implementing machine learning based strategies including the algorithmic steps from information gathering to market orders.Credit not awarded for both CS 4646 and CS 7646.

courses.title: Robot Intelli Planning
courses.description: We investigate algorithms for robots and complex systems that make intelligent decisions.  Emphasis on the theoretical and empirical properties of classical, geometric, stochastic/dynamic planning.

courses.title: Natural Language Understanding
courses.description: Methodologies for designing systems that comprehend natural language. Topics include lexical analysis, parsing, interpretation of sentences, semantic representation, organization of knowledge, and inference mechanisms.  Credit not allowed for both CS 4650 and CS 7650.

courses.title: Introduction to Educational Technology
courses.description: Introduction to the theory and practice of educational technology. Covers learning theory applicable to educational technology, explains major research findings. Credit not awarded for both CS 4660 and CS 6460.

courses.title: Educational Technology: Design and Evaluation
courses.description: Intensive project class in which students design, implement, and evaluate a piece of educational technology, applying the theory learned in Introduction  to Educational Technology.

courses.title: Computer-Supported Collaborative Learning
courses.description: Research and practice in computer-supported collaborative learning. Review of existing systems and research, as well as evaluation and design methods.

courses.title: Internet Computing Systems, Services and Applications
courses.description: Focusing on fundamental issues, concepts, techniques, and technical challenges that are critical for designing and developing Internet systems, services and applications.  Credit not allowed for both CS 4675 and CS 6675.

courses.title: Pervasive Systems and Networking
courses.description: In-depth study of systems and wireless networking issues in enabling pervasive computing environments and applications using a hand-on approach.

courses.title: Empirical Methods for User Interface Design and Evaluation
courses.description: Introduction to empirical methods for gathering requirements and evaluating the end-user and usability of software systems.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research Assistantship
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Introduction to Computing Concepts for Bioinformatics
courses.description: Introduction to programming concepts and computing tools such as formal models and algorithms with applications from conceptual biology.  May not be used by computer science majors for degree credit.

courses.title: Inter Capstone Design
courses.description: Entrepreneurial Junior Design. Teams comprised of CS, ECE, and ME students will design and build prototypes of their invention ideas and explore market fit.

courses.title: Information Security Strategies and Policies
courses.description: Information security vulnerabilities and risks; legal, cost, privacy, and technology constraints; derivation of strategies; technical and procedural means of achieving desired results. Credit will not be awarded for both CS 4725 and CS 6725 or MGT 4725 or MGT 6725 or PUBP 4725.

courses.title: Privacy, Technology, Policy, and Law
courses.description: This course takes a multi-disciplinary approach to privacy, a topic of great interest in the technology, policy, ethics, law, and business realms. Credit will not be awarded for both CS 4726 and MGT 4726 or MGT 6726 or CS 6726.

courses.title: Game AI
courses.description: Examines the expressive possibilities of artificial intelligence techniques in computer games. Students learn AI programming techniques, and how they strongly interface with game design.

courses.title: Integrative Management Development-Project Preparation
courses.description: Individual and group-based experiential learning activities to develop integrated human system management skills that prepare students for more successful capstone collaboration and learning.  Credit not allowed for both CS 4741 and MGT 4741 or ME 4741.

courses.title: Integrated Computing and Management Capstone Project
courses.description: Project-based course for students in Computing and Management minor to work in interdisciplinary teams on projects provided by corporate affiliates.  Credit not allowed for both CS 4742 and MGT 4742 or ME 4742.

courses.title: Information and Communication Technologies and Global Development
courses.description: Focus on technology design, adoption, and use as seen through the lens of global development.

courses.title: Mixed Reality Experience Design
courses.description: Focuses on informal design, integration of  media theory, HCI and technology issues. Significant group design projects. Credit not awarded for both CS 4770 and LMC 4733/6340/CS 6770.

courses.title: Integrative Project in Cognitive Science
courses.description: An integrative course in cognitive science focusing on the integration and use of concepts and skills from cognitive science.  A different integrative project or set of projects will be taken on each semester; students will contribute on the basis of their background and skill.  Crosslisted with PST, PSYC, and ISYE 4791.

courses.title: Design Project in Cognitive Science
courses.description: Individual project with a cognitive science faculty member, designed as a supplement to the student's senior design project or thesis in their major area.  Crosslisted with PST, PSYC, and ISYE 4792.

courses.title: Integrative Perspectives in Cognitive Science
courses.description: An integrative course in cognitive science which uses a focus topic to deepen interdisciplinary perspective and develop cognitive science knowledge and skills.

courses.title: GPU Programming for Video Games
courses.description: 3-D graphics pipelines. Physically-based rendering. Game engine architectures. GPU architectures. Graphics APIs. Vertex and pixel shader programming. Post-processing effects. Deferred rendering.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Courses of timely interest to the profession, conducted by resident or visiting faculty.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Courses of timely interest to the profession, conducted by resident or visiting faculty.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Courses of timely interest to the profession, conducted by resident or visiting faculty.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Courses of timely interest to the profession, conducted by resident or visiting faculty.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Courses of timely interest to the profession, conducted by resident or visiting faculty.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special Topics.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special Topics in CS - Lab.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special Topics in CS (lecture and supervised lab)

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special Topics.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special Topics for CS (lecture + lab).

courses.title: Special Problems
courses.description: An investigation of significant areas of information in computer science. Guided study and research.

courses.title: Special Problems
courses.description: An investigation of significant areas of information and computer science. Guided study and research.

courses.title: Special Problems
courses.description: An investigation of significant areas of information and computer science. Guided study and research.

courses.title: Design Capstone Project
courses.description: Team-based capstone experience allowing students to analyze a problem for a customer and manage the solution development through the full project life cycle.

courses.title: Design Capstone Project
courses.description: Team-based capstone experience allowing students to analyze a problem for a customer and manage the solution development through the full project life cycle.

courses.title: Principles of Design
courses.description: This is an interactive hands-on course that will teach students the principles of design at the individual level.

courses.title: Introduction to Information Security
courses.description: A broad spectrum of information security: threats, basic cryptography, software vulnerabilities, programming for malice, operating system protections, network security, privacy, data mining, computer crime.

courses.title: Computing For Good
courses.description: Exploring challenges faced by underserved populations and developing countries from a computing perspective.

courses.title: Graduate Introduction to Operating Systems
courses.description: This course teaches operating system abstractions, mechanisms, and their implementations, including for concurrency (threads) and synchronization, resource management (CPU, memory, I/O), and distributed services.

courses.title: Advanced Operating Systems
courses.description: Introduction to graduate-level topics in operating systems using research papers, textbook excerpts, and projects. Provides students thorough comprehension of distributed and parallel computer systems. Credit is not awarded for both CS 4210 and CS 6210.

courses.title: System Design for Cloud Computing
courses.description: Through in-depth presentations and hands-on projects for each layer of the full stack of cloud technologies, learners acquire the systems design skills for cloud computing.

courses.title: Big Data Systems and Analytics
courses.description: This course will cover the concepts, techniques, algorithms, and systems of big data systems and data analytics, with strong emphasis on big data processing systems, fundamental models and optimizations for data analytics and machine learning, which are widely deployed in real world big data analytics and applications.

courses.title: High-Performance Parallel Computing: Tools and Applications
courses.description: Introduction to MIMD parallel computation, using textbook excerpts, research papers, and projects on multiple parallel machines.  Emphasizes practical issues in high-performance computing.

courses.title: Real-Time System Concepts and Implementation
courses.description: Principles of real-time systems, as occurring in robotics and manufacturing, interactive, and multimedia applications. Reviews and uses real-time operating systems.Credit not awarded for both CS 6235 and CS 4220.

courses.title: Secure Computer Systems
courses.description: Design principles of secure systems, authentication, access control and authorization, discretionary and mandatory security policies, secure kernel design, and secure databases.

courses.title: Enterprise Cybersecurity Management
courses.description: The duties and concerns of an enterprise Chief Information Security Officer including strategy, cybersecurity operations, risk management, and governance.

courses.title: Design and Implementation of Compilers
courses.description: Design and implementation of modern compilers, focusing upon optimization and code generation.

courses.title: Compiling for Parallelism
courses.description: Design and implementation of compilers for parallel and distributed computers, focusing upon optimization and code generation.

courses.title: Object-Oriented Systems and Languages
courses.description: Design and implementation of object-oriented systems.  Aspect-oriented programming, type systems, OO language implementation (virtual dispatch, GC), OO language design (genericity, reflection, mixins).

courses.title: Computer Networks
courses.description: Principles and practice of computer networks, including signaling and framing, error control, medium access, routing, congestion control, end-to-end transport, and network APIs.

courses.title: Principles of Network Management
courses.description: Focus on network, system, and applications management. Principles and practice of various network management standards will be presented.  Course includes project assignment.

courses.title: Applied Cryptography
courses.description: Cryptographic algorithms, cryptanalysis, symmetric cryptography, public key cryptography, DES, AES, RSA, hash and MAC functions, digital signatures, pseudo-random generators, cryptographic protocols, SSL//TLS, SET. Credit not allowed for both CS 6260 and ECE 6280.

courses.title: Security Operations and Incident Response
courses.description: The course covers the principles and technologies utilized in and the processes followed in responding to cybersecurity incidents and crises. The course utilizes real-life case studies to develop how these technologies and processes are applied within the cybersecurity industry.

courses.title: Network Security
courses.description: Design principles of secure network protocols and systems, authentication, integrity, confidentiality, privacy, information hiding, digital watermarking, access control, firewall, intrusion detection, and case studies.

courses.title: Intro to Cyber-Physical Systems Security
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to security issues relating to various cyber-physical systems including industrial control systems and those considered critical infrastructure systems.

courses.title: Information Security Lab: System and Network Defenses
courses.description: This course will help students develop both in-depth knowledge and hands-on skills in a number of important cybersecurity areas, including software security, malware and threat analysis, end-point security, network security, web security, mobile security, and machine learning based security analytics.

courses.title: Information Security Lab: Binary Exploitation
courses.description:
This course covers advanced techniques for writing exploits, taught
through an intense, hands-on security laboratory, following a
cyberspace war game called Capture-The-Flag.

courses.title: Information Security Practicum
