courses.description: Capstone independent study placing each student in a commercial, industrial, academic, or government setting where they must solve real-world security problems.

courses.title: Critical Infrastructures Security and Resilience
courses.description: Critical infrastructures are large cyber-physical networks essential to the well-being of the societies they serve. We study their resilience and security against a range of disruptions.

courses.title: Psychology of Cybersecurity
courses.description: This course will explore psychological processes relevant to cybersecurity. Students will gain an appreciation for psychological influence factors inherent in the current cyberspace environment.

courses.title: Formal Models and Methods for Information Assurance
courses.description: Logical foundations of high-assurance systems, formal models for access control, authentication, and trust; techniques for constructing high-assurance systems.

courses.title: Technical Introduction to Blockchain and Cryptocurrencies
courses.description: Graduate Introduction to Blockchain and cryptocurrencies, building on formal crypto and distributed systems.  Cover fundamental and practical aspects.  Includes programming projects and research presentation.

courses.title: Cybersecurity of Drones
courses.description: The course covers introductory topics in the security and privacy of cyber-physical systems especially unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) or drones. The goal is to expose students to fundamental security primitives specific to cyber-physical systems.

courses.title: Performance Evaluation of Communication Networks
courses.description: Methods for evaluating the performance of communication networks with emphasis on modeling, mathematical analysis, computer simulation, and measurement.

courses.title: High-Performance Computer Architecture
courses.description: Topics concerning very high-performance computers including techniques exploiting parallelism in single and multiple processor systems.  Credit not allowed for both CS 6290 and any of the following courses: CS 4290, ECE 4100, ECE 6100.

courses.title: Embedded Software Optimizations
courses.description: First, this course introduces the student to embedded domain-specific processor and instruction set design issues.  Next, machine-specific optimizations for performance and for energy consumption are discussed.

courses.title: Software Development Process
courses.description: The process of developing software systems. Includes development and assessment of processes, their instantiation in actual product development, and techniques ensuring quality of developed products.

courses.title: Advanced Topics in Software Engineering
courses.description: This project-based course will cover fundamental principles, advanced techniques, and tools for the development of high-quality, industrial-strength software.

courses.title: Software Architecture and Design
courses.description: Principles and concepts involved in the design and analysis of large software systems.

courses.title: Software Requirements Analysis and Specification
courses.description: Methods and principles for determining, documenting, analyzing, and formally specifying requirements for software systems.

courses.title: Software Generation, Testing, and Maintenance
courses.description: Introduction to methods and principles for programming, testing, and managing the evolution of software systems.

courses.title: Advanced Topics in Software Analysis and Testing
courses.description: Fundamental prinicples and advanced techniques for static and dynamic program analysis and software testing. Software reliability, resilience, and trustworthiness.

courses.title: Introduction to Enterprise Computing
courses.description: Survey of basic software concepts and techniques used in mission-critical systems and applications, combined with in-depth study of fundamental principles underlying enterprise computing.  Credit not allowed for both CS 6365 and CS 4365.

courses.title: Programming Language Design
courses.description: Design, structure, and goals of programming languages. Object-oriented, logic, functional, and traditional languages.  Semantic models.   Parallel programming languages.

courses.title: Database Systems Concepts and Design
courses.description: Study of fundamental concepts with regard to relational databases. Topics covered include database design, query processing, concurrency control, and recovery. Credit not given for both CS 6400 and CS 6754.

courses.title: Databases and Information Security
courses.description: Fundamentals of designing and using databases:  conceptual data models to database-specific models, SQL, storage structures.  Security-related topics include privacy, access control, backup, recovery, SQL injection.  Credit not allowed for both CS 6402 and CS 4400.

courses.title: Object-Oriented Database Models and Systems
courses.description: Study of advanced database concepts as they apply to object-oriented database systems.  Topics include semantic data models, object-oriented query languages, tools, and applications.

courses.title: Temporal, Spatial and Active Databases
courses.description: Study of advanced database concepts for temporal databases with emphasis on storage structure, processing and query languages, as well as active database concepts and implementation.

courses.title: Database System Implementation
courses.description: Design and implementatuion of a databse system covering: storage manager, query optimizer, transaction manager, and recovery manager.  Study of the advantages of different implementation algorithms.  Credit not allowed for both CS 6422 and CS 4420.

courses.title: Advanced Database System Implementation
courses.description: Study of advanced topics in implementing a database system, including the query optimizer, concurrency control and recovery protocols. Includes a project component.

courses.title: Parallel and Distributed Database Systems and Applications
courses.description: Study of algorithms and performance in advanced databases. Systems include parallel, distributed, and client-server databases. Applications include data mining and on-line analytical processing.

courses.title: Digital Health Equity
courses.description: This course introduces individual, interpersonal, and societal influences on health; how these create health disparities, and how digital health technologies can help achieve health equity.

courses.title: Information to Health Informatics
courses.description: A broad review of the US health system and the application of informatics to the clinical practice of medicine, digital imaging, public health and bioinformatics.

courses.title: Personal Health Informatics
courses.description:
This course will cover the design of personal health technologies. Students will apply the taught design issues to a semester-long
health application design project.

courses.title: Introduction to Human-Centered Computing
courses.description: Introduction to the range of issues across the HCC disciplines, including design and research methodologies: cognitive, social, and cultural theories; assessment and evaluation: ethical issues.

courses.title: Prototyping Interactive Systems
courses.description: Introduction to design, prototyping and implementation of systems for human-centered computing. Focuses on core concepts in computer science and implications for interactive systems.

courses.title: Qualitative Methods for Design of Human Computer Interaction
courses.description: Qualitative methods for HCI including data collection through interviews, observations and design, analysis using research and industry standards, and methods for communicating findings to industry.

courses.title: User Interface Design and Evaluation
courses.description: Examines usability in the software development process with an emphasis on usability, requirements, methodology, design, and evaluation.

courses.title: Principles of User Interface Software
courses.description: Considers the architectural and algorithmic principles behind the implementation of interactive software systems and the tools that support them. Credit not awarded for CS 6456 and CS 4470.

courses.title: Video Game Design and Programming
courses.description: Techniques for electronic game design and programming, including graphics, game engines, animation, behavioral control for autonomous characters, interaction, social and interface issues of multi-user play.  Credit not allowed for both CS 6457 and CS 4455.

courses.title: Educational Technology: Conceptual Foundations
courses.description: Introduction to educational technology, with an emphasis on theoretical foundations.  Introduces basic philosophies, approaches, and technologies.  Analyzes issues surrounding technology's impact on education. Credit not awarded for both CS 4660 and CS 6460.

courses.title: CS Education Research
courses.description: Introduction to computing education research (CER). History and influential early work. Learning goals for different populations. Design of research studies in CER.

courses.title: Computational Journalism
courses.description: Technology is rapidly affecting how news information is gathered, reported, visualized, aggregated, summarized, distributed, and consumed.  This class studies the computational technologies that impact journalism.  Credit not allowed for both CS 6455 and CS 4464.

courses.title: Design of Online Communities
courses.description: Introduction to the design of online communities. Students study an existing community in depth, and then develop a new community design.  Credit not allowed for both CS 6470 and CS 4472.

courses.title: Computational Social Science
courses.description: This graduate seminar focuses on text and network analysis of data with applications to domains such as political science, sociolinguistics, and public health.

courses.title: Social Computing
courses.description: Design and prototype new social computing systems, as well as analyze social media data.

courses.title: Computational Photography
courses.description: This class explores the impact of computation on the entire workflow of photography, from how light is captured by a camera, to how the images are processed, enhanced, and improved to generate novel photographs.

courses.title: Introduction to Computer Vision GR
courses.description: Introduction to computer vision including fundamentals of image formation, camera imaging geometry, feature detection and matching, stereo, motion estimation and tracking, image classification and scene understanding. Credit not awarded for both CS 6476 and CS 4495 or CS 4476.

courses.title: Computer Visualization Techniques
courses.description: Principles, techniques, and practice in data, information, multivariate, and scientific visualization. Includes visualization methods, data structures, examples, and tools.

courses.title: Visualization Methods for Science and Engineering
courses.description: Algorithms, software, and practical applications of visualization techniques in science, engineering, business, and medicine. Includes data structures, multivariate visualization, interactive visualization, and visual representations and examples. Computer science students cannot receive credit for this course.

courses.title: Foundations of Computer Graphics
courses.description: Mathematical/physical/perceptual principles and modeling/rendering techniques used to create, represent, display, and animate models of 3D shapes and their properties.

courses.title: Shape Grammars
courses.description: Shape grammars are production systems using shape rewriting rules to perform computations with shapes.

courses.title: Computational Aesthetics
courses.description: Aesthetics play a key role in society and economy. Students will invent and test beautification algorithms for colors, music, and animations and more.

courses.title: Computability, Algorithms, and Complexity
courses.description: Important concepts from computability theory; techniques for designing algorithms for combinatorial, algebraic, and number-theoretic problems; basic concepts such as NP-Completeness from computational complexity theory. Credit not awarded for both CS 6505 and CS 4540/6515.

courses.title: Introduction to Graduate Algorithms
courses.description: Design and analysis of algorithms on a graduate level, including dynamic programming, divide and conquer, FFT, graph and flow algorithms, RSA, linear programming, and NP-completedness.

courses.title: Computational Complexity Theory
courses.description: Introduction to resource-bounded computations, central complexity-theoretic concepts such as complexity classes, reducibility, completeness, and intractability.

courses.title: Design and Analysis of Algorithms
courses.description: Advanced techniques for designing and analyzing efficient algorithms for combinatorial, algebraic, and number-theoretic problems.

courses.title: Artificial Intelligence
courses.description: Basic concepts and methods of artificial intelligence including both symbolic/conceptual and numerical/probabilistic techniques.

courses.title: AI, Ethics, and Society
courses.description: This course covers various Artificial Intelligence and bias mitigation techniques that can be used to counterbalance the potential misuse and abuse of learning from data.

courses.title: Distributed Control Algorithms
courses.description: Algorithms for synchronous, asynchronous, and partially synchronous networks; analysis, control, and implementation of distributed systems such as robot fleets, animal groups.

courses.title: Advanced Internet Computing Systems and Applications
courses.description: Survey of basic Internet computing concepts and techniques used in Internet systems and applications, combined with in-depth study of fundamental principles underlying Internet computing.  Credit not allowed for both CS 6675 and CS 4675.

courses.title: Applications of Artificial Intelligence
courses.description: A study of the principles and practice of artificial intelligence in areas other than computer science, with particular focus on engineering, science, and business applications. Computer science majors cannot receive credit for this course.

courses.title: Information Security Strategies and Policies
courses.description: Information security vulnerabilities and risks; legal, cost, privacy, and technology constraints; derivation of strategies; technical and procedural means of achieving desired ends. Credit not awarded for both CS 6725 and CS 4725/MGT 4725/6725/PUBP 4725/6725.

courses.title: Privacy, Technology, Policy, and Law
courses.description: This course takes a multi-disciplinary approach to privacy, a topic of great interest in the technology, policy, ethics, law, and business realms. Credit will not be awarded for both CS 6726 and CS 4726 or MGT 4726 or MGT 6726.

courses.title: Cyber Security Practicum
courses.description: Capstone independent study project placing each student in a commercial, academic or government setting where he or she identifies a major cyber security problem, and explores and evaluates a solution that addresses it with realistic assumptions about the organizational context. The chose problem must be approved by course instructor. Cross-listed with ECE and PUBP 6727.

courses.title: Data Visualization: Principles and Applications
courses.description: Introductory course on design principles and applications of data visualization. This course teaches best practices for visualizing datasets from diverse domains intended to help people make sense of data. Students cannot receive credit for both CS 6730 and CS 4460.

courses.title: Information and Communication Technologies and Global Development
courses.description: Focus on technology design, adoption, and use as seen through the lens of global development.

courses.title: Advanced Topics in Malware Analysis
courses.description: This course covers advanced approaches for the analysis of malicious software and explores recent research and unsolved problems in software protection and forensics.

courses.title: Human-Computer Interaction
courses.description: Describes the characteristics of interaction between humans and computers and demonstrates techniques for the evaluation of user-centered systems. Crosslisted with PSYC 6750.

courses.title: Human-Computer Interaction-Professional Preparation and Practice
courses.description: Preparation for a professional career in HCI. Hands-on workshops in resume and portfolio building, interviewing, public speaking, team work. HCI career choices and trajectories.

courses.title: Engineering Database Management Systems
courses.description: Modeling and managing engineering information systems, integration of design and manufacturing functions in engineering product development, logical models of engineering product and processes. Credit not given for CS 6400 and CS 6754.  Crosslisted with ME  6754.

courses.title: Human-Computer Interaction Foundations
courses.description: Describes the theory and practice of designing effective and efficient interactions between people and technology. Students do not receive credit for both CS 6755 and PSYC 6755.

courses.title: Human-Computer Interaction Applications
courses.description: This course supports MS-HCI students in a semester-long team project that is research-focused and results in portfolio-ready artifacts.

courses.title: Design of Design Environments
courses.description: Analysis of design processes; analysis of current design tools at both the user interface and functional levels; procedures for developing better design tools. Credit not allowed for both CS 6763 and ID 6763 or COA 6763.

courses.title: Geometric Modeling
courses.description: Software development course focusing on 3D geometric constructions and modeling; emphasizes solid modeling and its role in design. Crosslisted with COA 6764.

courses.title: Mixed Reality Experience Design
courses.description: Introduction to the design of Mixed Reality experiences. Focuses on informal design, integration of media theory, HCI and technology issues. Significant group design projects.Credit not awarded for both CS 6770 and CS 4770/LMC 4733/6340.

courses.title: Medical Image Processing
courses.description: A study of methods for enhancing, analyzing, interpreting, and visualizing information from two- and three-dimensional data obtained from a variety of medical image modalities. Crosslisted with ECE and BMED 6780.

courses.title: Introduction to Cognitive Science
courses.description: Multidisciplinary perspectives on cognitive science. Interdisciplinary approaches to issues in cognition, including memory, language, problem solving, learning, perception, and action. Crosslisted with ISYE and PSYC 6795.

courses.title: Master's Project
courses.description: Final project for students completing a master's degree in the College of Computing.  Repeatable for multi-semester projects.

courses.title: Overview of Graduate Studies in Computing
courses.description: Research tools including computer systems, as well as fundamental problem-solving skills, are introduced. Lectures on current computing research are presented and projects are required. Credit not allowed in a program of study for a graduate degree.

courses.title: Parallel Computer Architectures
courses.description: Issues in the design, implementation, and programming of parallel machines.  Credit not allowed for both CS 7110 and CS 4233.

courses.title: Distributed Computing
courses.description: Fundamental concepts in distributed systems, including global states, logical clocks, and failure models. Distributed algorithms and their implementations using advanced distributed programming systems.

courses.title: Systems Software Design, Implementation, and Evaluation
courses.description: Design, implementation, and evaluation of systems software. Distributed/parallel applications will be constructed and evaluated using the systems support that is developed.

courses.title: Broadband Networking Systems
courses.description: Focus on the data link layer and its relationship to layers below and above.  Gigabit Ethernet, SONTET, fibre channel; media including wireless, satellite, xDSL, cable.

courses.title: Internetworking Architectures and Protocols
courses.description: Detailed discussion of the problems and solution techniques that arise in internetworking. Topics include routing, addressing, quality of service, and security.

courses.title: Networked Applications and Services
courses.description: End-to-end functional building blocks and their use in adaptive and non-adaptive applications, including multimedia: coding, compression, security, directory services.

courses.title: Network Science: Methods and Applications
courses.description: Characteristics of real networks in nature and technology, network measurement methods, network analysis, evolving networks, dynamic network processes, co-evolution of structure and function.

courses.title: Advanced Topics in Microarchitecture and organization of high-performance processors.
courses.description: Low-level organization and hardware algorithms for the implementation of modern high-performance microprocessors including concept designs and real-world case studies.

courses.title: Reliability and Security in Computer Architecture
courses.description: Hardware support for process isolation, virtualization, debugging, and protection from side-channel attacks. Faults and failures, error tolerance, error rate budgeting, lifetime realiability of devices.

courses.title: Introduction to Quantum Computing
courses.description: Provide background on quantum computing and equip students with the skills to write code and optimize quantum programs on real quantum computers.

courses.title: Information Visualization
courses.description: Study of computer visualization principles, techniques, and tools used for explaining and understanding symbolic, structured, and/or hierarchical information. Includes data and software visualization.

courses.title: Human-Centered Data Analysis
courses.description: This course covers the role of people in data science and visual data analysis, including cognitive processes, bias, perception, and decision-making theories and frameworks.

courses.title: Issues in Human-Centered Computing
courses.description: In-depth focus on theoretical, methodological, conceptual, and technical issues across the HCC disciplines associated with humans (cognitive, biological, socio-cultural); design; ethics; and analysis and evaluation.

courses.title: Collaborative Computing
courses.description: Introduction to computer-supported collaborative work, workflow automation, and meeting augmentation. The course deals with models, enabling technology, systems, and applications.

courses.title: Animal-Centered Computing
courses.description: Explores current research, techniques, and methods in computing as applied to animals, both domestic and wild.  Covers technology for understanding animal cognition and behavior, animal communication, animal welfare and enrichment, and conservation, as well as ethics of computing for animals.

courses.title: Educational Technology:  Design and Evaluation
courses.description: Intensive project class in which students design, implement, and evaluate a piece of educational technology, applying the theory learned in Educational Technology: Conceptual Foundations.

courses.title: Computer-Supported Collaborative Learning
courses.description: Computer-supported collaborative learning is the use of Internet-based technologies to support learning in social settings.  Focus on issues of implementation and evaluation.

courses.title: Mobile and Ubiquitous Computing
courses.description: Investigates the infrastructure required to develop mobile and ubiquitous computing applications and establishes major research themes and experimental practices. Credit not awarded for both CS 7470 and CS 4605.

courses.title: Advanced Computer Vision
courses.description: Advanced topics in computer vision, which includes a deep dive into both the theoretical foundations of computer vision to the practical issues of building real systems that use computer vision. Credit will not be awarded for CS 7476 and CS 7495.

courses.title: Advanced Image Synthesis
courses.description: Advanced techniques in realistic image synthesis based on the physics of light.  Anti-aliasing, textures, surface reflectance, distribution ray tracing, volume rendering, radiosity, and image-based rendering.

courses.title: 3D Complexity Techniques for Graphics, Modeling, and Animation
courses.description: Multiresolution,  compression, collision, morphing, visibility, and computational geometry techniques for accessing, rendering, and animating complex 3D models in engineering, scientific, business, or entertainment applications.

courses.title: Simulation of Biological Systems
courses.description: Study different computer simulation methods for use in investigating biological systems, including bio-molecules, cells and full organisms.

courses.title: Computer Vision
courses.description: An introduction to computer vision and machine perception. An intensive study of the process of generating a symbolic description of the scene by interpretation of images(s). Credit will not be awarded for both CS 7495 and CS 7476.

courses.title: Computer Animation
courses.description: Motion techniques for computer animation and interactive games (keyframing, procedural methods, motion capture, and simulation) and principles for storytelling, composition, lighting, and interactivity.

courses.title: Virtual Environments
courses.description: An introduction to virtual reality and virtual environments. Issues covered will include VR technology, software design, 3D human-computer interaction, and applications for VR.

courses.title: 3D Reconstruction and Mapping in Computer Vision, Robotics, and Augmented Reality
courses.description: In this course we study the principles and algorithms underlying 3D Reconstruction and Mapping in Computer Vision, Robotics, and Augmented Reality.

courses.title: Graph Algorithms
courses.description: Algorithms for graph problems such as maximum flow, matching, network reliability, minimum cuts, covering, coloring, planarity, shortest paths, and connectivity. Crosslisted with MATH 7510 and ISYE 7510.

courses.title: Approximation Algorithms
courses.description: Approximation algorithms for NP-hard optimization problems, design and analysis techniques for such algorithms.  Credit not allowed for both CS 7520 and CS 4520.

courses.title: Algorithmic Game Theory and Economics
courses.description: Algorithmic aspects of game theory covering topics at the intersection of computer science, economics, and game theory with applications to domains such as internet.

courses.title: Randomized Algorithms
courses.description: Techniques for designing and analyzing randomized algorithms, derandomization techniques.  Credit not allowed for both CS 7530 and CS 4530.

courses.title: Markov Chain Monte Carlo Algorithms
courses.description: This course studies Markov Chain Monte Carlo algorithms, widely-used in a variety of scientific fields, focusing on mathematical techniques for analyzing their convergence rates.

courses.title: Spectral Algorithms and Representations
courses.description: Spectral methods mathematics and algorithmic insights driving applications with large data sets in domains such as web-search, information-retrieval, and medical diagnosis and prediction.

courses.title: Theoretical Foundations of Machine Learning
courses.description: This course provides a basic arsenal of powerful mathematical tools for the analysis of learning algorithms, focusing on both statistical and computational aspects.

courses.title: Theoretical Foundations of Cryptography
courses.description: One-way functions, pseudorandomness, public-key and identity-based cryptography, commitment and zero knowledge.

courses.title: Modeling and Design
courses.description: Information-processing theories of modeling and design; topics include design decision making, problem solving and learning, and knowledge-based modeling and design.

courses.title: AI Problem Solving
courses.description: Basic concepts and methods of AI problem solving, knowledge representation, reasoning, and learning.

courses.title: Artificial Intelligence Planning
courses.description: Symbolic numerical techniques that allow intelligent systems to decide how they should act in order to achieve their goals, including action and plan representation, plan synthesis and reasoning, analysis of planning algorithms, plan execution and monitoring, plan reuse and learning, and applications.

courses.title: Knowledge Systems Engineering
courses.description: Techniques for constructing large knowledge-based systems.  Advanced symbolic AI techniques. Constraint systems.

courses.title: Knowledge Agents
courses.description: Knowledge-based interactive systems, knowledge-based autonomous agents, agent architectures, learning and adaptation, agent evolution.

courses.title: Pattern Recognition
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to the theory and practice of pattern recognition.  It emphasizes unifying concepts and the analysis of real-world datasets.

courses.title: Case-Based Reasoning
courses.description: Topics include case representation, indexing and retrieval, adaptation, interpretive CBR, the cognitive model that CBR implies, and its implications for creativity, decision aiding, and education.  Credit not allowed for both CS 7620 and CS 4622.

courses.title: Introduction to Behavioral Imaging
courses.description: An introduction to the use of sensor data and machine learning methods to measure and model human behavior objectively and automatically for health applications.

courses.title: Autonomous Robotics
courses.description: The principles and practice of autonomous robotics including behavior-based design and architectures, adaptive learning and team behavior, and the role of perception within robotic systems.

courses.title: Autonomous Multi-Robot Systems
courses.description: In-depth examination of the current research on multi-robot systems.  Students develop and critically analyze a multi-robot system.

courses.title: Game Artificial Intelligence
courses.description: An exploration of how artificial intelligence is used in modern digital computer games. Credit will not be awarded for CS 7632 and CS 4731, CS 7632 and LCC 4731 or CS 7632 and LMC 4731.

courses.title: Human-Robot Interaction
courses.description: Survey of the state of the art in HRI research, introduction to statistical methods for HRI research, research project studio.

courses.title: AI Storytelling in Virtual Worlds
courses.description: An exploration of how artificial intelligence can enable us to use stories in virtual worlds for the purpose of entertaining, educatintg, and training human users.

courses.title: Computational Perception
courses.description: Study of statistical and algorithmic methods for sensing people using video and audio.  Topics include face detection and recognition, figure tracking, and audio-visual sensing.

courses.title: Knowledge-Based AI
courses.description: Structured knowledge representation; knowledge-based methods of reasoning and learning; problem-solving, modeling and design.

courses.title: Artificial Intelligence Techniques for Robotics
courses.description: AI techniques with applications to autonomous vehicles. Extensive programming exercises. Topics include probabilistic inference, Kalman/particle filters, planning/search algorithms, PID control, SLAM.

courses.title: Cyber Physical Design and Analysis
courses.description: Cyber Physical Systems (CPS), including examples. Design methods. Formalisms: Different equations, finite-state machines. Analysis. Formal methods. Design processes, Model-Based Systems Engineering, Reference documents and regulations.

courses.title: Learning in Autonomous Agents
courses.description: An in-depth look at agents that learn, including intelligent systems, robots, and humans. Design and implementation of computer models of learning and adaptation in autonomous intelligent agents.

courses.title: Machine Learning
courses.description: Machine learning techniques and applications. Topics include foundational issues; inductive, analytical, numerical, and theoretical approaches; and real-world applications. Credit not awarded for both CS 7641 and CS 4641/CSE 6740/ISYE 6740.

courses.title: Reinforcement Learning and Decision Making
courses.description: Efficient algorithms for multiagent planning, and approaches to learning near-optimal decisions using possibly partially observable Markov decision processes; stochastic and repeated games; and reinforcement learning.

courses.title: Deep Learning
courses.description: This course will cover theory and practice of deep learning, including neural network and structured models, optimization algorithms, and applications to perception and Artificial Intelligence.

courses.title: Machine Learning for Robotics
courses.description: Overview of a portfolio of machine learning techniques useful for robotic application: from regression to deep learning, applied on simulated real-time mobile robotic applications.

courses.title: Numerical Machine Learning
courses.description: This course explores problems in classification/pattern recognition (OCR, speech, vision, fault detection, medical diagnosis), regression/function approximation, robot control, and reinforcement learning.

courses.title: Machine Learning for Trading
courses.description: Introduces machine learning based trading strategies. Topics:  Information processing, probabilistic analysis, portfolio construction, generation of market orders, KNN, random forests. Credit not awarded for both CS 4646 and CS 7646.

courses.title: Machine Learning with Limited Supervision
courses.description: Explore advanced techniques in learning from visual data with limited human supervision through study of recently published research papers and completing a semester-long research project.

courses.title: Interactive Robot Learning
courses.description: This course combines lectures in CS (Machine and Reinforcement Learning) and CogSci with a research seminar to enable students to develop learning from demonstration systems.

courses.title: Robot Intelligence: Planning
courses.description: We investigate algorithms for robots and complex systems that make intelligent decisions.  Emphasis on the theoretical and empirical properties of classical, geometric, stochastic/dynamic planning.

courses.title: Natural Language
courses.description: Topics include lexical analysis, parsing, interpretation of sentences, semantic representation, organization of knowledge, inference mechanisms.  Newer approaches combining statistical language processing and information retrieval techniques.  Credit not allowed for both CS 7650 and CS 4650.

courses.title: Human and Machine Learning
courses.description: Explores the gap between empirical research on human learning and models from machine learning. Covers symbolic, statistical, semantic space, neural network, unsupervised, and other approaches.

courses.title: Philosophy of Cognition
courses.description: Examines problems in the foundations of cognition in relation to current issues in cognitive sciences. Topics include meaning, mental imagery, consciousness, and mind/body problem.

courses.title: Cognitive Models of Science and Technology
courses.description: Examines how models of reasoning and representation developed in the cognitive sciences can provide a basis for an enriched understanding of scientific theories and research practices in science and technology.

courses.title: Robotics Professional Preparation
courses.description: Preparation for a professional career in Robotics. Local & visiting speakers. Program introduction. Technical resume preparation. GT Robotics labs & resources.

courses.title: Robotics Professional Preparation 2
courses.description: Preparation for a professional career in Robotics. Local & visiting speakers. Selecting and applying for Internship. Developing capstone project proposal. Public speaking practice and preparation.

courses.title: Robotics Professional Preparation 3
courses.description: Preparation for a professional career in Robotics. Local & visiting speakers. Interview preparation & career search. Technical report writing and presentation.

courses.title: Mathematical Foundations of Machine Learning
courses.description: Provides the mathematical background for two of the pillars of modern data science: linear algebra and applied probability.

courses.title: Probabilistic Graphical Models in Machine Learning
courses.description: The course provides an introduction to theory and practice of graphical models in machine learning. It covers three main aspects; representation, probabilistic inference, and learning.

courses.title: Introduction to Robotics Research
courses.description: Familiarizes students with the core areas of robotics; mechanics, control, perception, AI, and autonomy. Provides an introduction to the mathematical tools required in robotics research.

courses.title: Cognitive Modeling
courses.description: A hands-on course covering a range of cognitive modeling methodologies.  It explores the analysis, development, construction, and evaluation of models of cognitive processing. Crosslisted with ISYE and PSYC 7790.

courses.title: Preparation for Doctoral Qualifying Exams
courses.description: Consent of the College required.

courses.title: Seminar
courses.description: Group discussion of advanced topics in information and computer science. May not be used by computer science majors for degree credit.

courses.title: Seminar
courses.description: Group discussion of advanced topics in information and computer science.  May not be used by computer science majors for degree credit.

courses.title: Seminar
courses.description: Group discussion of advanced topics in information and computer science. May not be used by computer science majors for degree credit.

courses.title: Seminar
courses.description: Group discussion of advanced topics in information and computer science. May not be use by computer science majors for degree credit.

courses.title: Seminar
courses.description: Group discussion of advanced topics in information and computer science. May not be used by computer science majors for degree credit.

courses.title: Seminar
courses.description: Group discussion of advanced topics in information and computer science. May not be used by computer science majors for degree credit.

courses.title: Software Engineering Seminar
courses.description: This seminar provides students with an opportunity to explore contemporary topics in software engineering.

courses.title: Robotics Internship
courses.description: Graduate Internship at a partner company, GTRI or a GT Robotics lab.

courses.title: Robotics Capstone Project
courses.description: Teams or individuals apply the knowledge and skills acquired throughout the MS program to a faculty supervised robotics project.

courses.title: Robotics Research Foundation I
courses.description: Multidisciplinary research course supervised by two robotics faculty from different schools participating in the robotics Ph.D. program.

courses.title: Robotics Research Foundation II
courses.description: Continuation of AE 8751 (Robotics Research Foundation I).

courses.title: Colloquium in Cognitive Sciences
courses.description: Reading of research papers by leading cognitive scientists, attendance at their colloquia and meeting with them to discuss research. Crosslisted with ISYE and PSYC 8795.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special topics of current interest. Treatment of new developments in various areas of computing.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special topics of current interest.  Treatment of new developments in various areas of computing.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special topics of current interest.  Treatment of new developments in various areas of computing.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special topics of current interest.  Treatment of new developments in various areas of computing.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special topics of current interest.  Treatment of new developments in various areas of computing.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special topics of current interest.  Treatment of new developments in various areas of computing.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special Topics in CS - Lab.

courses.title: Special Topics in Cognitive Science
courses.description: Topics of current interest in cognitive science.

courses.title: Special Problems
courses.description: Small-group or individual investigation of advanced topics in computing. Guided study and research.

courses.title: Special Problems
courses.description: Small-group or individual investigation of advanced topics in computing. Guided study and research.

courses.title: Special Problems
courses.description: Small-group or individual investigation of advanced topics in computing.  Guided study and research.

courses.title: Teaching Assistantship
courses.description: For graduate students holding graduate teaching assistantships.

courses.title: Research Assistantship
courses.description: For graduate students holding graduate research assistantships.

courses.title: Introduction to Computational Science and Engineering
courses.description: This course will introduce students to major research areas in computational science and engineering.

courses.title: Computational Problem Solving for Scientists and Engineers
courses.description: Computing principles, computer architecture, algorithms and data structure; software development, parallelism. No credit for graduate students or undergraduates in Computer Science or Computational Media.

courses.title: Computing for Data Analysis: Methods and Tools
courses.description: Computational techniques needed for data analysis; programming, accessing databases, multidimensional arrays, basic numerical computing, and visualization; hands-on applications and case studies. Credit is will not be awarded for both CSE 6040 and CX 4240.

courses.title: Computational Science and Engineering Algorithms
courses.description: This course will introduce students to designing high-performance and scalable algorithms for computational science and engineering applications. The course focuses on algorithms design, complexity analysis, experimentation, and optimization, for important science and engineering applications.

courses.title: Massive Graph Analysis
courses.description: Algorithms and data structures for massive graphs; programming, parallelism; principles, challenges, opportunities in graph analysis; hands-on application, case studies.

courses.title: High Performance Computing
courses.description: This course will introduce students to the design, analysis, and implementation of high performance computational science and engineering applications.

courses.title: Multicore Computing: Concurrency and Parallelism on the Desktop
courses.description: This course will introduce students to the design and analysis of real-world algorithms on multicore computers.

courses.title: High Performance Parallel Computing: Tools and Applications
courses.description: Introduction to MIMD parallel computation, using textbook excerpts, resesarch papers, and projects on multiple parallel machines. Emphasizes practical issues in high-performance computing.

courses.title: Parallel and Distributed Simulation
courses.description: Algorithms and techniques used in parallel/distributed discrete event simulation systems. Synchronization algorithms, data distribution, applications to high performance analytic simulations and distributed virtual environments.

courses.title: Web Search and Text Mining
courses.description: Basic and advanced methods for Web information retrieval and text mining: indexing and crawling, IR models, link and click data, social search, text classification and clustering.

courses.title: Pattern Matching Algorithms
courses.description: Foundations and algorithms underlying the development and application of tools for the efficient searching, matching and discovery of discrete.

courses.title: Data and Visual Analytics
courses.description: The course introduces students to analysis and visualization of complex high dimensional data.  Both theory and applications will be covered including several practical case studies.

courses.title: Advanced Topics in Machine Learning
courses.description: Advanced machine learning topics including graphical models, kernel methods, boosting, bagging, semi-supervised and active learning, and tensor approach to data analysis.

courses.title: Big Data Analytics for Healthcare
courses.description: Big data systems, scalable machine learning algorithms, health analytic applications, electronic health records.

courses.title: Algorithms for Bioinformatics and Computational Biology
courses.description: Foundations and algorithms underlying the development and application of tools for the efficient management and processing of biomolecular data.

courses.title: Numerical Linear Algebra
courses.description: Introduction to numerical solutions of the classical problems of linear algebra including linear systems, least squares, singular value decomposition, and eigen value problems. Crosslisted with MATH 6643.

courses.title: Iterative Methods for Systems of Equations
courses.description: Iterative methods for linear and nonlinear systems of equations including Jacobi, G-S, SOR, CG, multigrid, Newton, quasi-Newton, updating, and gradient based methods. Crosslisted with MATH 6644.

courses.title: Numerical Methods in Computational Science and Engineering I
courses.description: Introduction to numerical algorithms widely used in computational science and engineering. Numerical linear algebra, linear programming, and applications. Crosslisted with MATH 6710.

courses.title: Numerical Methods in Computational Science and Engineering II
courses.description: Efficient numerical techniques for solving partial differential equations and large-scale systems of equations arising from discretization of partial differential equations or variational problems in applications in science and engineering. Crosslisted with MATH 6711.

courses.title: Modeling and Simulation: Foundations and Implementation
courses.description: Foundations and algorithms concerning the development of conceptual models for systems, and their realization in the form of computer software; discrete and continuous models. Crosslisted with ECE 6730.

courses.title: Computational Data Analysis: Learning, Mining, and Computation
courses.description: Theoretical/computational foundations of analyzing large/complex modern datasets, including the fundamental concepts of machine learning and data mining needed for both resesarch and practice. Crosslisted with ISYE 6740. Credit not awarded for both CSE 6740 and CS 4641/7641/ISYE 6740.

courses.title: Modeling, Simulation and Military Gaming
courses.description: Focuses on the creation and use of modeling and simulation tools to analyze and train students regarding strategic events in international relations. Crosslisted with INTA 6742.

courses.title: Applied Analytics Practicum
courses.description: Practical analytics project experience applying ideas from the classroom to a significant project of interest to a business, government agency, or other organization.

courses.title: Mathematical Foundations of Machine Learning
courses.description: Provides the mathematical background for two of the pillars of modern data science: linear algebra and applied probability.

courses.title: Probabilistic Graphical Models in Machine Learning
courses.description: The course provides an introduction to theory and practice of graphical models in machine learning. It covers three main aspects; representation, probabilistic inference, and learning.

courses.title: Machine learning in computational biology
courses.description: Introduction to modern machine learning techniques in computational biology.

courses.description: Group discussion concerning advanced topics in Computational Science and Engineering.

courses.description: Introductory probability and statistics for computing and machine learning, from random variables, joint distribution and concentration inequalities to parameter estimation, statistical models and Bayesian simulation.

courses.title: Computational Problem Solving for Scientists and Engineers
courses.description: Computing principles, computer archietecture, algorithms and data structures; software development, parallelism. No credit for graduate students or undergraduates in Computer Science or Computational Media.

courses.title: Computational Modeling Algorithms
courses.description: Design, analysis and implementation of algorithms for modeling natural and engineered systems; algorithm experimentation, and optimization.

courses.title: Introduction to High Performance Computing
courses.description: Design of algorithms and software for high performance computing platforms used in computational science and engineering. Topics include parallelism, locality, machine architectures, and programming.

courses.title: Computer Simulation
courses.description: Algorithms and techniques for creating computer simulations and their realization in software.

courses.title: Simulation and Military Gaming
courses.description: Creation and use of modeling and simulation tools to analyze and train students regarding strategic events in international relations.

courses.title: Distributed Simulation
courses.description: Algorithms and techniques used to execute simulations on parallel/distributed computing platforms. Simulations for analysis, virtual environments, and computer gaming.

courses.title: Introduction to Computing for Data Analysis
courses.description: Computational techniques needed for data analysis; programming, accessing databases, multidimensional arrays, basic numerical computing, and visualization; hands-on applications and case studies.

courses.title: Data and Visual Analytics
courses.description: Introduction to the analysis of complex data; theory, applications and practical case studies.

courses.title: Numerical Analysis I
courses.description: Introduction to numerical algorithms for some basic problems in computational mathematics. Discussion of both implementation issues and error analysis.

courses.title: Numerical Analysis II
courses.description: Introduction to the numerical solution of initial and boundary value problems in differential equations.

courses.title: Computational Methods for Simulation and Machine Learning
courses.description: Introduction to numerical methods which are fundamental in modeling, simulation, and machine learning.

courses.title: Introduction to Parallel and Vector Scientific Computing
courses.description: Scientific computational algorithms on vector and parallel computers. Speed-up and algorithm complexity, interprocess communication, synchronization, modern algorithms for linear systems, programming techniques, code optimization.

courses.title: Special Topics in Computational Science and Engineering
courses.description: Course topics will vary. This course number will be used to prototype new courses and/or offer courses on topics of timely interest. The final digit in the course number indicates the number of units offered awarded for the course.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special Topics for CX (lecture + lab).

courses.title: Special Problems in Computational Science and Engineering
courses.description: An investigation of significant areas of computational science and engineering. Guided study and research.

courses.title: Preparation for Work in a Global Economy
courses.description: Preparation for work in a global economy.  May be used as free elective credit with departmental approval.

courses.title: Introduction to Environmental Science
courses.description: Introduction to environmental field science. Case study approach. Exposure to basic field equipment and techniques, analysis of data.

courses.title: Habitable Planet
courses.description: Introduction to the origin and evolution of Planet Earth, creation of the universe and the elements, early history of Earth, radioisotope geochemistry and the timing of events in the universe, the galaxy, and on Earth. Formation of the atmosphere and oceans. Climate.

courses.title: Environmental Measures of Urban and Regional Change
courses.description: Identify and quantify nature's physical and chemical contributions to human-made urban environments, and measure the impacts of urban area feedback on these natural systems.

courses.title: Introduction to Meteorological Analysis
courses.description: An introduction to analysis of forecasting data and moel output.

courses.title: Earth Processes
courses.description: An introduction to earth materials and processes.

courses.title: Earth Through Time
courses.description: Dynamic processes affecting the Earth system on all time scales.

courses.title: Quantitative Techniques in Earth and Atmospheric Sciences
courses.description: Integrated course in mathematical, physical, and computing techniques for applications in earth and atmospheric sciences.

courses.title: Internship Assistantship
courses.description: Earth & Atmospheric Sciences Undergraduate Internship for pay for freshmen and sophomores, by permit only. The internship experience must be at a unit or agency approved by the School of Earth & Atmospheric Sciences.

courses.title: Undergraduate Internship
courses.description: Earth & Atmospheric Sciences Undergraduate Internship for credit for freshmen and sophomores, by permit only. The internship experience must be at a unit or agency approved by the School of Earth & Atmospheric Sciences.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Physics of the Weather
courses.description: An introductory treatment of the application of the basic physical laws to the understanding of weather phenomena. Crosslisted with PHYS 2750.

courses.title: Energy, Environment, and Society
courses.description: This course analyzes the path towards alternative energy infrastructures for the 21st century with careful consideration of economic, environmental, technological, and political factors.

courses.title: Thermodynamics of Earth Systems
courses.description: Introduction to the principles of equilinrium thermodynamics and physical chemistry with applications to the atmosphere, ocean, and solid earth.

courses.title: Introduction to Geophysics
courses.description: An introduction to visualizing and understanding earth history, structure, and dynamics through geophysical methods including seismology, gravity, magnetism, heat flow, geochronology, and geodesy.

courses.title: Geochemistry
courses.description: A quantitative treatment of geochemical processes in the Earth and natural waters, with emphasis on chemical reactions among atmospheric gases, minerals, and aqueous solutions.

courses.title: Resources, Energy and the Environment
courses.description: Learn about the science behind the nature, occurrence and extraction of earth resources used by humans and the environmental impacts of that use.

courses.title: Structural Geology and Continuum Mechanics
courses.description: Structural geology and continuum mechanics for scientists and civil engineers. Stress and strain in rocks; faults, joints, and folds; basic field mapping; laboratory exercises.

courses.title: Geomorphology
courses.description: Overview of the mechanical, chemical, and biological processes that shape topography.

courses.title: Environmental Geochemistry
courses.description: An exploration of the chemical, biological, and geological processes controlling the distribution of chemical nutrients and pollutants in aquatic and soil environments.

courses.title: Environmental Geochemistry Lab
courses.description: Lab and field exploration of the chemical, biological, and geological processes controlling the distribution of chemical nutrients and pollutants in aquatic and soil environments.

courses.title: Mineral Surface Geochemistry
courses.description: Fundamental principles concerning mineral surface properties, element distribution at the mineral-water interface and analytical techniques relevant to interfacial reactions.

courses.title: Introduction to Physical and Chemical Oceanography
courses.description: Chemistry and physics of the ocean. Distributions of temperature, salinity, and density. Equations of state and motion. Surface and deep-water circulation.  Waves and tides. Composition of seawater: dissolved sales, gases, and nutrients. Biological processes. Marine sediments.

courses.title: Physical and Chemical Oceanography
courses.description: Study of the dynamics of large-scale ocean circulation, air-sea interaction and their roles in biogeochemical cycling of carbon and nutrients.

courses.title: Geodynamics
courses.description: Quantitative discussion of dynamic processs in the solid Earth; lithospheric dynamics, continuum mechanics, lithospheric flexure and elasticity, heat transfer, viscous rheology, fluid mechanics, and earthquake dynamics.  Credit not allowed for both EAS 4312 and EAS 6312.

courses.title: Tectonics. Climate, and Landscape Evolution
courses.description: Introduction to the interactions and feedbacks between tectonics and climate that act to shape landscapes. Includes field- and computer-based data collection and analysis.  Credit not allowed for both EAS 4313 and EAS 6313.

courses.title: Seismology
courses.description: Introduction to elastic wave propagation, and studies of the solid Earth's interior and earthquake source from seismic waves.  Credit not allowed for both EAS 4314 and EAS 6314.

courses.title: Geofluids
courses.description: This course focuses on the fundamental concepts of fluid dynamics merged with geophysical applications.

courses.title: Earthquake Physics
courses.description: Fundamental physics of processes that control fault slips and earthquakes with a focus on the latest emerging research topics in the field.

courses.title: Physical Volcanology
courses.description: This class examines the dynamics and thermodynamics of planetary volcanism.  The course material covers the generation and transport of magma in the mantle and crust, and the fluid dynamics of eruptions and their impact on the landscape and atmosphere.  Credit not allowed for both EAS 4331 and EAS 6331.

courses.title: Paleoclimatology and Paleoceanography
courses.description: This course will explore the history of the Earth's climate, covering methods for reconstructing past climate and the mechanisms behind these climate changes.

courses.title: Space Physics and Space Instrumentation
courses.description: This course will explore the interaction of the solar wind with the Earth's magnetosphere using a combination spacecraft observations and fundamental plasma physics.  Credit not allowed for both EAS 4360 and EAS 6360.

courses.title: Physics of Planets
courses.description: In this course we will study the forces and influences that determine the composition, structure and evolution of the planets in our solar system.

courses.title: Earth and Planetary Materials
courses.description: Fundamental principles and applications of mineralogy and petrology for understanding the composition of surface and subsurface materials on Earth and other planetary bodies.

courses.title: Land Remote Sensing
courses.description: Techniques for making remote measurements of the composition, morphology, and thermophysical properties of solid surfaces on Earth and other planetary bodies.

courses.title: Climate and Global Change
courses.description: The physics behind the climate and its potential changes, as well as an introduction to the policy issues in global change.

courses.title: Environmental Field Methods
courses.description: Semester-long focus on single environmental project in the local area.  Chemical and physical techniques for parameterizing environmental problems, data analysis, report writing, and interpretation of results in societal context.

courses.title: Remote Sensing and Data Analysis
courses.description: Introduction to the remote sensing of the atmosphere and the Earth. Laboratory examples of data and image analysis for remote sensing applications.

courses.title: Synoptic Meteorology
courses.description: A description of physical and mathematical procedures used in weather forecasting.  Students will practice forecasting.

courses.title: Satellite and Radar Meteorology
courses.description: Interpretation of satellite and radar data for meteorological forecasting based on understanding radiative transfer and the resulting strengths and limitations of the imagery.

courses.title: Large-scale Atmospheric Circulations
courses.description: Structure and dynamics of phenomena including weather regimes, storm tracks, El Nino-Southern Oscillations, teleconnections, monsoons, Arctic Oscillation, stratospheric polar vortex, and stratosphere-troposphere coupling.

courses.title: Environmental Data Analysis
courses.description: Data Analysis methods used in environmental research are taught through examples.  Students learn to implement these methods to areas of their own interests.

courses.title: Exploration Geophysics
courses.description: Methods of exploration geophysics, including refraction and reflection seismology, resistivity, gravity, magnetics, and ground penetrating radar.  Includes laboratory work and introduction to operation of field equipment.

courses.title: Fluids in the Earth's Crust I
courses.description: Fundamentals of porosity and permeability in soils, sediments, and crystalline rocks; basic physics of fluid flow through interconnected pore spaces and cracks; introductory analysis of fluid flow as an agent of heat and chemical transport in geological systems.

courses.title: Seismic Methods in Exploration Geophysics
courses.description: A study of seismic reflection exploration methods and theory.  Examples are taken from oil industry exploration and production and near-surface environmental imaging.

courses.title: Weather Risk and Catastrophe Modeling
courses.description: Overview of the physics and dynamics behind different types of hazardous weather and the mathematical tools to model the risks associated with these events.

courses.title: Biogeochemical Cycles
courses.description: An investigation of global change focusing on the chemical, physical, geological, and biological processes that cycle the elements through the Earth system.

courses.title: Earth System Modeling
courses.description: An introduction to computer modeling in Earth system science.

courses.title: Water Quality Modeling
courses.description: Gain hands-on experience using geochemical software and understanding governing geochemical principles pertaining to transformation of contaminants and other subsurface species through case studies.

courses.title: Physics of the Earth
courses.description: Introduction to methods and observational data used to determine solid Earth structure and to understand the dynamical processes driving surface deformation and plate tectonics.

courses.title: Atmospheric Chem Lab
courses.description: A hands-on laboratory course in which students will learn basic concepts and techniques used by atmospheric chemists including analysis, data quality and experimental design.

courses.title: Practical Internship
courses.description: Faculty-supervised and approved independent internship, employment, or research project related to earth and atmospheric sciences.

courses.title: Atmospheric Dynamics
courses.description: An introduction to the atmospheric physical and dynamic processes that control weather and climate.

courses.title: Atmospheric Dynamics Practicum
courses.description: Students learn to apply meteorological analysis tools to atmospheric observations to interpret the structure and dynamics of historical and real-time weather events.

courses.title: Atmospheric Dynamics II
courses.description: This course emphasizes physical concepts and analytic techniques for solving problems in atmospheric instabilities and wave dynamics at various temporal and spatial scales.

courses.title: Internship Assistantship
courses.description: Earth & Atmospheric Sciences Undergraduate Internship for pay for junior and seniors, by permit only. The internship experience must be at a unit or agency approved by the School of Earth & Atmospheric Sciences.

courses.title: Undergraduate Internship
courses.description: Earth & Atmospheric Sciences Undergraduate Internship for credit for juniors and seniors, by permit only. The internship experience must be at a unit or agency approved by the School of Earth & Atmospheric Sciences.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research Assistantship
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Atmospheric Chemistry Laboratory
courses.description: This course provides a general chemical description of the Earth's atmospheric system with a major focus on the two lowest layers of the atmosphere, i.e., the troposphere and the stratosphere. Crosslisted with CHEM 4740.

courses.title: Groundwater Hydrology
courses.description: Dynamics of flow and solute transport in groundwater, including theory, implementation, and case studies. Crosslisted with CEE 4795.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special Topics in Earth and Atmospheric Sciences.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special Topics in EAS (1-credit hour supervised lab).

courses.title: Intro Research & Ethics
courses.description: Identify and discuss ethical challenges that will be confronted in research, and give an overview of the research areas of the faculty in EAS.

courses.title: Preparing Future Faculty
courses.description: A guide to a career in academia for scientists. Learn about getting a faculty position, establishing a successful research.

courses.title: The Earth System
courses.description: Exploration of processes linking the Earth and atmosphere.

courses.title: Environmental Field Methods
courses.description: Environmental site characterization through a field-based project that advances student's research.  Theory, field data acquisition, and data fusion using geochemical, geophysical, hydrologic, and related methods.

courses.title: Modeling and Computer Programming for Geosciences
courses.description: This course gives students first-hand experience on the development process of problem solving in Earth and Atmospheric Sciences from mathematically describing a problem to solving it by parallel programming on a high performance computer.

courses.title: Biogeochemical Cycles
courses.description: A multidisciplinary exploration of the chemical, physical, geological, and biological processes that cycle the nutrient elements through the Earth system and thereby maintain a habitable planet.

courses.title: Principles of Oceanography
courses.description: Chemistry and physics of the ocean.  Distributions of temperatures, salinity, and density.  Equations of state and motion.  Surface and deep-water circulation, waves, and tides.  Composition of seawater: dissolved salts, gases, and nutrients.  Biological processes. Marine sediments.

courses.title: Water Quality Modeling
courses.description: Gain hands-on experience using geochemical software and understanding governing geochemical principles pertaining to transformation of contaminants and other subsurface species through case studies.

courses.title: Fluids in the Earth's Crust
courses.description: Advanced treatment of fluid flow, heat transfer, and reactive transport in porous and cracked rocks; stability of flow; double-diffusive systems; evolution of permeability in geologic systems; introduction to multiphase flow.

courses.title: Earth System Modeling
courses.description: An introduction to computer modeling in earth system science.

courses.title: Ocean Modeling
courses.description: Developing and using ocean models from the simple shallow water to the full primitive equation model. Includes hands-on programming.

courses.title: Introduction to Climate Change
courses.description: The climate of the Earth, its radiation budget, greenhouse gases and their sources and sinks, potential changes due to anthropogenic activities, detection of climate changes.

courses.title: Marine Ecosystem Modeling
courses.description: Modeling population dynamics in the context of ocean circulation. Numerical techniques and simulation development.

courses.title: Inverse Methods and Time Series Analysis in Earth and Atmospheric Sciences
courses.description: Theory of data acquisition, time series analysis, and discrete inverse theory, with applications in the earth and atmospheric sciences.

courses.title: Introduction to Complex Environmental Systems
courses.description: Introduction to the concepts of environmental complexity through the inter-relationships between natural, human, and built systems.

courses.title: Paleoclimatology and Paleoceanography
courses.description: This course will explore the history of the Earth's climate, covering methods for reconstructing past climate and the mechanisms behind these climate changes.

courses.title: Thermodynamics of Atmospheres and Oceans
courses.description: The instabilities and flows created by exchanges of heat.

courses.title: Atmospheric Radiative Tranfser
courses.description: Fundamentals of the interaction of electromagnetic radiation with atmospheric constituents, including absorption and scattering processes by the atmospheric gases, aerosols, and clouds.

courses.title: Remote Sensing of the Atmosphere and Oceans
courses.description: Provides a foundation for understanding the physical principles of remote sensing and its applications to the study of atmospheric gases, clouds, and ocean surfaces.

courses.title: Advanced Geophysical Fluid Dynamics
courses.description: Fundamental mathematical tools for graduate students interested in Geophysical Fluid Dynamics (GFD) and related disciplines.

courses.title: Environmental Geochemistry
courses.description: An exploration of the chemical, biological, and geological processes controlling the distribution of chemical nutrients and pollutants in aquatic and soil environments.

courses.title: Environmental Geochemistry Lab
courses.description: Lab and field exploration of the chemical, biological, and geological processes controlling the distribution of chemical nutrients and pollutants in aquatic and soil environments.

courses.title: Geochemical Thermodynamics
courses.description: Fundamental principles of chemical equilibria in geochemical systems with emphasis on solution properties and mineral water equilibria.

courses.title: Geochemical Kinetics
courses.description: Fundamental principles of biogeochemical kinetics and mathematical treatment of coupled transport and reaction in natural environments.  Interpretation of field and experimental data using kinetic theory.

courses.title: Aqueous Geochemistry
courses.description: Chemical processes that regulate compositions of natural waters at or near the Earth's surface, with emphasis on quantitative calculations of acid-base, solubility, and redox equilibria.

courses.title: Isotope Geochemistry
courses.description: Biogeochemical significance of nuclear isotopes, both radioactive and stable.

courses.title: Mineral Surface Geochemistry
courses.description: Fundamental principles concerning mineral surface properties, element distribution at the mineral-water interface, and analytical techniques relevant to interfacial reactions.

courses.title: Organic Geochemistry
courses.description: Origin and transformation of organic matter in the Earth's environments, with emphasis on properties and reactions of highly complex mixtures such as humic substances.

courses.title: Physical and Chemical Oceanography
courses.description: Study of the dynamics of large-scale ocean circulation, air-sea interaction and their roles in biogeochemical cycling of carbon and nutrients.

courses.title: Physics of the Earth
courses.description: Physics of the Earth's interior. Composition and structure of core, mantle, crust. Introduction to seismic wave propagation, gravitational, geomagnetic, and temperature fields.

courses.title: Geodynamics
courses.description: Quantitative discussion of dynamical processes in the solid Earth; viscous flow, glacial rebound, fluid dynamical instabilities, thermal convection; lithospheric dynamics; evolution of the core.

courses.title: Tectonics, Climate, and Landscape Evolution
courses.description: Introduction to the interactions and feedbacks between tectonics and climate that act to shape landscapes. Includes field- and computer-based data collection and analysis.  Credit not allowed for both EAS 6313 and EAS 4313.

courses.title: Seismology
courses.description: The propagation of seismic waves, the description of earthquake motion, and evaluation of earthquake damage. Examples provide experience in the interpretation of seismic data.

courses.title: Geofluids
courses.description: This course focuses on the fundamental concepts of fluid dynamics merged with geophysical applications.

courses.title: Earthquake Physics
courses.description: Fundamental physics of processes that control fault slips and earthquakes with a focus on the latest emerging research topics in the field.

courses.title: Structural Geology and Continuum Mechanics
courses.description: Structural geology and continuum mechanics for scientists and civil engineers.  Stress and strain in rocks; faults, joints, and folds; basic field mapping, laboratory exercises.

courses.title: Geomorphology
courses.description: Overview of the mechanical, chemical, and biological processes that shape the topography.

courses.title: Physical Volcanology
courses.description: This class examines the dynamics and thermodynamics of planetary volcanism.  The course material covers the generation and transport of magma in the mantle and crust, and the fluid dynamics of eruptions and their impact on the landscape and atmosphere.  Credit not allowed for both EAS 6331 and EAS 4331.

courses.title: Field Methods in Volcanic Terrain
courses.description: A field based course to connect process-based models and field observations related to volcanic, eruptions, subsurface magma interaction, and crustal heat flow and tectonics.

courses.title: Space Physics and Space Instrumentation
courses.description: This course will explore the interaction of the solar wind with the Earth's magnestophere using a combination spacecraft observation and fundamental plasma physics.  Credit not allowed for both EAS 6360 and EAS 4360.

courses.title: Physics of Planets
courses.description: In this course we will study the forces and influences that determine the compostition, structure, and evolution of the planets of our solar system.

courses.title: Earth and Planetary Materials
courses.description: Fundamental principles and application of mineralogy and petrology for understanding the composition of surface and subsurface materials on Earth and other planetary bodies.

courses.title: Land Remote Sensing
courses.description: Techniques for making remote measurements of the composition, morphology, and thermophysical properties of solid surfaces on Earth and other planetary bodies.

courses.title: Introduction to Atmospheric Chemistry
courses.description: Introduction to basic chemical principles related to chemical processes in the atmosphere.

courses.title: Introduction to Atmospheric and Aqueous Chemistry
courses.description: An introduction to the basics of atmospheric and aqueous chemistry for first semester graduate students. The class goes over photochemistry, thermodynamics, kinetics, redox systems, carbon chemistry, radioactive and stable isotopes, and gas/solid reactions.

courses.title: Atmospheric Chemistry
courses.description: Application of fundamental principles of chemistry to understanding the critical factors controlling the levels and distributions of atmospheric trace gases and their variation in time.

courses.title: Introduction to Physical Meteorology
courses.description: Application of the fundamental principles of thermodynamics to the atmosphere; including hydrostatic equilibrium and static stability, derivation of Claussius-Clapeyron Equation, cloud microphysics, radiative transfer, and the Earth's energy budget.

courses.title: Introduction to Principles of Atmospheric Chemical
courses.description: Introduction to the mechanical, electrical, and optical aspects of modern instrumentation used in atmospheric chemical research.

courses.title: Experimental Methods in Air Quality
courses.description: Presents experimental and field methods through a focus on measurements of atmospheric gases and particulates associated with poor air quality. Experiments will involve laboratory measurements and an air quality filed experiment on the order of one week duration.

courses.title: Advanced Environmental Data Analysis
courses.description: A unified view of the theories and applications underlying the statistical analysis of environmental data in the space, time and spectral domain.

courses.title: Climate and Global Change
courses.description: The physics behind the climate and its potential changes, as well as an introduction to the policy issues in global change.

courses.title: Introduction to Atmospheric Dynamics
courses.description: Introduction to the basic fundamental fluid dynamics that control atmospheric motions.

courses.title: Introductory Fluid Dynamics and Synoptic Meteorology
courses.description: Fundamental principles of atmospheric fluid dynamics, analysis of meteorological codes, weather data and patterns, and numerical weather prediction.

courses.title: Dynamic Meteorology
courses.description: An introduction to the use of geophysical fluid dynamics in describing and modeling the atmosphere.

courses.title: Dynamics of the Tropical Atmosphere and Oceans
courses.description: Explores the dynamics of the tropical atmosphere and ocean and how they interact to produce climatic features such as the monsoons, El Nino, and La Nina.

courses.title: Weather Risk and Modeling
courses.description: Overview of the physics and dynamics behind different types of hazardous weather and the mathematical tools to model the risks associate with these events.

courses.title: Large-scale Atmospheric Circulations
courses.description: Structure and dynamics of phenomena including weather regimes, storm tracks, El Nino-Southern Oscillation, teleconnections, monsoons, Artic Oscillation, stratospheric polar vortex, and stratosphere-troposphere coupling.

courses.title: Atmospheric Dyanmics II
courses.description: This course emphasizes physical concepts and analytic techniques for solving problems in atmospheric instabilities and wave dynamics at various temporal and spatial scales.
