courses.title: Industrial Design Fundamentals 1
courses.description: Art and design theory and practice in Industrial Design including an introduction to process, methodology, ergonomics, research tools and user research. Focus is on fundamental design principles based on design history and practice.

courses.title: Industrial Design Fundamentals 2
courses.description: Art and design theory and practice in Industrial Design including an introduction to process, methodology, ergonomics, research tools and user research. Focus is on CAD and digital prototyping.

courses.title: Introduction to Industrial Design 1
courses.description: Introduction to Industrial Design – a survey of evolving diverse career options and the designer’s impact on society. Emphasis on traditional product design, research, and strategy.

courses.title: Introduction to Industrial Design 2
courses.description: Introduction to Industrial Design – a survey of evolving diverse career options and the designer’s impact on society. Emphasis is on user experience and interaction design.

courses.title: Introduction to Graphic Communications 1
courses.description: Introduction to graphic design, composition, layout, color, typography, photography, social media & videography. Emphasis of this first course is on the history and theory of development of basic visual literacies.

courses.title: Introduction to Graphic Communications 2
courses.description: Introduction to graphic design history and practice, composition, layout, color, typography, photography, social media & videography. This second course in the sequence will emphasize digital skill development.

courses.title: Introduction to Sketching and Modeling 1
courses.description: Introduction to basic visual representation techniques that empower designers of products, services and systems through sketching, model making, computer-assisted drawing, rapid prototyping, and other methods.

courses.title: Introduction to Sketching and Modeling 2
courses.description: Introduction to intermediate visual representation techniques that empower designers of products, services and systems through sketching, model making, computer-assisted drawing, rapid prototyping, and other methods.

courses.title: Introductory Design I
courses.description: Foundation course in visual communications theory and practice, continuing the development of two-dimensional visual literacy. Emphasis on both analog and digital media.

courses.title: Introductory Design II
courses.description: Foundation course in form giving and representing, continuing the development of three-dimensional visual literacy.  Emphasis on visual relationships between form and image.

courses.title: Industrial Design Studio 1
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to the design process on visual principles and presentation techniques with a focus on sketching and modeling techniques related to 3D form.

courses.title: Industrial Design Studio 2
courses.description: This course applies more structured design methods to research and exploration of product form and function and introduces concepts of universal design and user centered design.

courses.title: Industrial Design Studio 1
courses.description: This course applied structured design methods to research and exploration of product form and function and introduces concepts of user centered design.

courses.title: Industrial Design Studio 2
courses.description: This course applies structured user-centered design methods to research and exploration of product design and function, and introduces concepts of universal design.

courses.title: Digital Design Methods
courses.description: This course introduces the basics of product design in the CAD environment. Stuents design a product, apply 3D scanning, produce an animation and 3D print.

courses.title: 3D Modeling
courses.description: This course introduces 3D modeling methods for solid and surface modeling in CAD software. Students create multi-component assembly drawings and explore rendering techniques for product design.

courses.title: Sustainable Issues for Design
courses.description: Introduction to the broad environmental issues that face humankind as a participant in the biosphere.

courses.title: History of Modern Industrial Design
courses.description: History and development of industrial design from the beginning of the Industrial Revolution to the present.

courses.title: History of Art 1
courses.description: This course surveys art from Prehistory through the Renaissance and is organized around stylistic periods that are arranged chronologically. Classes will consist of lectures with slides that focus on these stylistic periods.

courses.title: History of Art 2
courses.description: This course surveys the major artistic movements and aesthetics of the 17th, 18th, 19th, 20th, and early 21st centuries in painting, sculpture and architecture.

courses.title: Human Factors in Design
courses.description: This course examines the theory of Human Factors to provide a working knowledge of the physical and cognitive attributes of people that designers must accomodate.

courses.title: User Centered Design Methods
courses.description: This course introduces students to user-centric design methods used to identify, understand, assess and prioritize the neuroscience factors and perceptions that contribute to more effective product design and human-centered design solutions.

courses.title: Visual Design Thinking
courses.description: Introduction to techniques to help designers build a vocabulary to support effective visual communication including fundamentals of layout, sketching, rendering, schematics, information graphics & storyboarding.

courses.title: Introduction to Smart Product Design
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to smart product design including the basics of sensor technologies, electronics and programming required to produce working product concept prototypes.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research Assistantship
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Intermediate Design I
courses.description: The systematic design process as applied to industrial design and packaging problems.

courses.title: Intermediate Design II
courses.description: Various dimensions of human factors applied to design, including: aging, disability, normal age change, childhood and adult anthropometrics, and human capability.

courses.title: Health Design Studio 1
courses.description: The application of systematic user-centered design methods and research to projects focused on the design development of new and/or improved health-related products with an emphasis on inclusive design.

courses.title: Health Design Studio 2
courses.description: The application of systematic user-centered design methods and research to projects focused on the design development of new and/or improved health-related products with an emphasis on products and product systems.

courses.title: Product Development Studio 1
courses.description: The application of systematic user-centered design methods and research to projects focused on the use of parametric design and CNC capabilities in the design development of products, services & systems.

courses.title: Product Development Studio 2
courses.description: The application of systematic user-centered design methods to projects focused on the design development of 'real-world' products, services, interfaces & systems in collaboration with external sponsors.

courses.title: Interactive Product Design Studio 1
courses.description: The application of systematic product design and research methods to projects focused on new applications of sensor-based technologies to the creation of interactions, products and interfaces with an emphasis on the importance of user-centered design.

courses.title: Interactive Product Design Studio 2
courses.description: The application of systematic user-centered design methods to projects focused on new applications of sensor-based technologies with an emphasis on interactive environments, interfaces, navigation and mobility.

courses.title: Industrial Design Computing I
courses.description: Introduction to 2-D computer drawing systems.

courses.title: Industrial Design Computing II
courses.description: Introduction to 3-D modeling systems.

courses.title: Design & Community: The Social and Environmental Impact of Design
courses.description: Students explore socially and environmentally responsible industrial design practices at home and abroad, and partner with local organizations to develop community-based design projects.

courses.title: Materials I: Renewables
courses.description: This course examines the characteristics, production technologies, histories, and environmental impacts of nine categories of renewable materials familiar to product and product system design.

courses.title: Materials and Processes II: Nonrenewables
courses.description: Examination of characteristics, production technologies, histories, and environmental impacts of nonrenewable materials used in product design.

courses.title: Design Methods: User Centered Design
courses.description: This course introduces students to current user-centric design methods used to identify, understand, assess and prioritize the factors and perceptions that contribute to more effective product design and human-centered design solutions.

courses.title: Introduction to Interactive Product Design
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to interactive product design including the basics of sensor technologies, electronics and programming required to produce working product concept prototypes.

courses.title: Tangible Interaction
courses.description: This course addresses the design process related to interactive environments.  Projects will emphasize the inclusion of ubiquitous and emerging interactive technologies.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Topics of current interest in industrial design.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Topics of current interest in Industrial Design.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special Topics in Industrial Design (lecture and lab).

courses.title: Advanced Design I
courses.description: Application of the design process to advanced multidisciplinary design problems. Experience in solving real design problems from areas such as consumer products and equipment, transportation and equipment.

courses.title: Advanced Design II
courses.description: Capstone industrial design project of student's own choosing, with consent of instructor, to refine problem-solving and design ability in preparation for professional practice.

courses.title: ID Capstone Design Studio 1
courses.description: Comprehensive team-based projects incorporating an iterative approach to design development of products, & systems with emphasis on integration of research, user-centered design, prototyping, usability and testing.

courses.title: ID Capstone Design Studio 2
courses.description: Comprehensive team-based projects incorporating an iterative approach to design development of products, & systems with emphasis on integration of research, user-centered design, prototyping, usability and testing.

courses.title: Invention Studio 1
courses.description: An interdisciplinary team-based approach to integrate industrial design and engineering competencies in user-centered design development of products and systems with emphasis on corporate-sponsored projects.

courses.title: Invention Studio 2
courses.description: Comprehensive projects incorporating an iterative approach to user-centered design development of products, systems & services with emphasis on invention, innovation and entrepreneurship.

courses.title: ID/ME Collaborative Design Studio 1
courses.description: An interdisciplinary team-based approach to integrate industrial design and engineering competencies in user-centered design development of products and systems with emphasis on corporate-sponsored projects.

courses.title: ID/ME Collaborative Design Studio 2
courses.description: An interdisciplinary team-based approach to integrate industrial design and engineering competencies in user-centered design development of products and systems with emphasis on humanitarian projects.

courses.title: Alias Studio I
courses.description: Introduction to modeling, rendering, and animation with Alias Studio software.

courses.title: Alias Studio II
courses.description: Introduction to product animation using Alias Studio software.

courses.title: Advanced Modeling Concepts for Creating Complex Forms
courses.description: The Advance Modeling Concepts Course explores concepts, tools and theories used to model and validate complex forms encountered in the product design process.

courses.title: Parametric Product Modeling
courses.description: This course focuses on advanced digital methods in product modeling for visual analysis, flexible design approaches and digital fabrication methods.

courses.title: Design/Research Methods
courses.description: Research methods applicable to industrial design including task definition, information gathering, and analysis.

courses.title: Professional Practice and Preparation
courses.description: Principles of consulting and corporate industrial design including preparation of the professional portfolio.

courses.title: French Society and Culture
courses.description: Studies in French society and culture.

courses.title: Theorizing Design
courses.description: Introduction to what designers do and how they undertake their tasks; examples will come from a variety of design disciplines.

courses.title: French Design and Culture
courses.description: Studies in French design and culture.

courses.title: Culture of Objects:  A Seminar on the Design and Culture of Objects
courses.description: This seminar surveys the theories and methodologies within the field of industrial design that locate meaning in the designed object as derived from culture.

courses.title: Introduction to Universal Design in the Built Environment
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to universal design focusing on the implications of ability on the usability of places, products, and systems for all individuals.

courses.title: Prototyping Interaction: Designing for Experience
courses.description: This course exposes students to a range of practical methods for research and design exploration to support the design development of interactive products and technologies.

courses.title: Design Sketching
courses.description: This course addresses drawing and visualization techniques necessary for design thinking and development and introduces methods and processes to formulate and present visual information.

courses.title: Developing a Professional Design Portfolio
courses.description: The portfolio development course provides students with a structured approach to preparing a professional visual record of their work in print and digital formats.

courses.title: Wearable Product Design
courses.description: Wearable Product Design explores techniques in producing designs and prototypes for on-body interactions, and general textile knowledge for making effective wearable products.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research Assistantship
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Special Topics: Furniture
courses.description: Special topics in furniture design not covered in the professional curriculum.

courses.title: Special Topics: Sustainability
courses.description: Special topics in sustainability not included in the professional curriculum.

courses.title: Special Topics: Information Technology
courses.description: Special topics in information technology not included in the professional curriculum.

courses.title: Special Topics: Collaborative
courses.description: Application of the design process to advanced multidisciplinary problems by a team. Projects from a range of interest areas:  consumer, industrial products, transportation, furniture.

courses.title: Special Topics: History and Theory
courses.description: Special topics in history and theory not included in the professional curriculum.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special Topics Course.

courses.title: Special Problems: Visual Communications
courses.description: Special problems in communication not covered in the professional curriculum.

courses.title: Special Problems: Mentor Program
courses.description: Special problems in teaching pedagogy; mentoring by senior faculty in basic and intermediate design courses.

courses.title: Special Problems: Mentor Program
courses.description: Special problems in teaching pedagogy; mentoring by senior faculty in basic and intermediate design courses.

courses.title: Special Problems: Research
courses.description: Special research topics for advanced students not covered in the professional curriculum.

courses.title: Special Problems: Research
courses.description: Special research topics for advanced students not covered in the professional curriculum.

courses.title: Introduction to Graduate Studies in Industrial Design
courses.description: Introduction to the theory and practice of graduate studies in Industrial Design in relation to human-centered design, assistive technology, interaction, product system design, usability, user experience, interface, and instructional design.

courses.title: Human Centered Design
courses.description: This course examines design artifacts in relation to the human body, aging, disabilities, and environments with a perspective of  human-centered methodology that includes data gathering, analysis, and usability.

courses.title: Graduate Studio A
courses.description: Studio introduces the MID certificate in Design. The ID studio class stands at the heart of design education and professional practice. Industrial Design is considered from a strategic perspective. Assignments explore the business, technology and use experience components.

courses.title: Graduate Studio B
courses.description: This course is a project-based ID studio that gives students an overview of and practice with the insights-driven, iterative ID process.

courses.title: Rapid Design Vis
courses.description: This course trains students in the basics of sketching and free hand drawing needed in the Industrial Design studio environment.

courses.title: Brand and Visual Design
courses.description: This course introduces the principles of branding and visual identity. It emphasizes branded experiences in a service/product/mobile context.

courses.title: 3D Design Methods
courses.description: This course teaches students about the 3D digital  tools needed to develop products for human form.  By learning how to model, render and animate, students can better express their research, ideations and designs.

courses.title: Integrated Product Design
courses.description: Introduction to smart products teaches students to create IOT products. Students work with sensors and signals, U/I design, and multi-platform prototyping.

courses.title: Survey of Industrial Design History
courses.description: This course surveys the history of industrial design from the Industrial Revolution to contemporary times.

courses.title: Human Factors and Ergonomics
courses.description: This course teaches students about the human perspective in design, research, and interactions with physical and interface products. Students learn about tools and techniques used instructional design, human-computer interaction, product design, user-centered design, and usability.

courses.title: Industrial Design Graduate Studio I
courses.description: Graduate application of the design process to advanced multidisciplinary design problems. Experience in solving real design problems for consumer products.

courses.title: Industrial Design Graduate Studio II
courses.description: Graduate-level application of the design process to advanced multidisciplinary problems.

courses.title: Graduate Studio One
courses.description: This course introduces the design program philosophy, human-centered design and evidence-driven research from a strategic perspective. Assignments explore the technology, business, and user experience components in the design process and validate the final design with advanced usability tools and methods.

courses.title: Grad Studio Two: Health and Wellness
courses.description: This course explores the application of systematic product design methods to projects that focus on the design of new and/or improved health products, interactions, and delivery of services.

courses.title: Grad Studio Two: Interactive Products
courses.description: This course explores the application of systematic product design methods to projects that focus on the design development of new/or improved interactive or smart products.

courses.title: Strategic Design Language
courses.description: Introduction to techniques to help designers clarify and support design ideas in a strategic business context by exploring methods to better leverage visual design skills.

courses.title: Service Design
courses.description: This course introduces best practices of service design and focuses on the alignment and design of multiple brand touch points to optimize customer experience.

courses.title: Service Design, Brand and Value Creation
courses.description: This course introduces students to how data gathering and analysis, perception, visual, product, interface, and service design align to optimize user experiences that drive business service and value creation.

courses.title: Healthcare Design of the Future
courses.description: Introduction to research-based approaches to integrated healthcare design innovation.

courses.title: Master's Project
courses.description: Under the guidance of a faculty member, students explore a design project that relates to advance theoritical  research through a human prespective with a design and/or technology  focus on a product.  The project may include areas  in instructional design, human-computer interaction, learning, neuroscience, perception, product design, user-centered design, and usability.

courses.title: Visualizing Interaction
courses.description: Introduction to techniques that empower designers to plan and create effective and clear visual communication depicting the interaction and relationships between people, products, and services.

courses.title: Intro to Thesis Studies
courses.description: This introduction to thesis course helps students understand the human-centered research methods, analytical tools, and design processes used in developing a thesis or project in graduate studies.

courses.title: Advanced Sketching
courses.description: This class will focus on developing advanced, traditional (non-digital) sketching, rendering, and presentation techniques.

courses.title: Parametric Product Modeling
courses.description: This graduate course focuses on advanced digital methods in product modeling for visual analysis, flexible design approaches and digital fabrication methods.

courses.title: Shape Grammars
courses.description: Shape grammars are a powerful formal system for the generative description, interpretation and evaluation of designs.

courses.title: Computation, Creativity and Design Cognition
courses.description: This course investigates computational methods, models, tools that support design creativity and cognition.  Credit not allowed for both ID 6509 and ARCH 6509.

courses.title: Design for Interaction: Working with New Technologies
courses.description: This course examines opportunities for designers to leverage visualization and prototyping methods to foster new applications of technology to enhance user experience in everyday life.

courses.title: Interface Prototyping: Exploring Tools & Theories
courses.description: This course focuses on interface prototypes, how these are used throughout the design process and the varity of ways they can be created with different technologies.  Through interface prototypes, students learn how to express their research, receive user feedback, explore user perceptions, and improve their designs.

courses.title: Crafting Design Methods
courses.description: Traditional craftwork and how we can use material change, scale shifts, methods of manufacture, and algorithmic analysis to incorporate and revitalize these traditions into design.

courses.title: Soft Goods Design
courses.description: This graduate course focuses on product opportunities highlighting user benefits from soft material integration.

courses.title: Human-Computer Interaction Professional Preparation and Practice
courses.description: Preparation for a professional career in HCI. Hands-on workshops in resume and portfolio building, interviewing, public speaking, team work. HCI career choices and trajectories.

courses.title: Design of Interactive Environments
courses.description: Investigate and design ambient, intelligent, interactive interfaces and computational applications in tangible and physical environment to support health, wellness and quality of life.  Credit not allowed for both ID 6763 and COA 6763 or CS 6763.

courses.title: Investigations of Universal Design in the Built Environment
courses.description: This course provides an advanced level to universal design focusing on the implications of ability on the usability of places, products, and systems for all individuals.

courses.title: Web Design, Usability and Accessibility
courses.description: This course will teach students the fundamentals of web design and usability issues in online environments, with an emphasis on universal design principles and accessibility.

courses.title: Wearable Tech for Health
courses.description: This course explores the future of wearable technologies for health by adopting various human-centered design methodologies to meet users’ needs, abilities, and expectations.

courses.title: HCI Master's Project
courses.description: Final project for students completing a Human-Computer Interaction master's degree in the Digitial Media track. Repeatable for multi-semester projects.

courses.title: Master's Thesis
courses.description: Under the guidance of a faculty member, students explore advance  theoretical  research through a human perspective in areas instructional design, human-computer interaction, learning, neuroscience, perception, product design, user-centered design, and/or usability.

courses.title: Designing For Curiosity
courses.description: This course focuses on the development of research-through-design skills particular to their application in interaction design.

courses.title: Special Topics in ID
courses.description: Special Topics in Industrial Design.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special Topics in Industrial Design.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special Topics in Industrial Design (lecture and supervised lab).

courses.title: Special Problems
courses.description: Special problems in industrial design.

courses.title: Special Problems in Human-Computer Interaction
courses.description: Small-group of individual investigation of advanced topics in human-computer interaction. Guided study and research.

courses.title: Teaching Assistantship
courses.description: For graduate students holding graduate teaching assistantships.

courses.title: Research Assistantship
courses.description: For graduate students holding graduate research assistantships.

courses.title: Analytical Methods
courses.description: This course provides an overview of optimization, statistical, and stochastic models and methods with special emphasis on application to logistics.

courses.title: Demand and Yield Management
courses.description: This course focuses on demand estimation and modeling and revenue management.

courses.title: Reverse Green Logistics
courses.description: This course addresses issues, driving forces, and analytical approaches to aid in designing operating reverse logistics systems.

courses.title: Labor Relations
courses.description: This course compares labor practices in Europe, North America, and Asia with special attention on the influences on logistics.

courses.title: European Trade and Transport
courses.description: This course provides an overview of legal, cultural, political, and infrastructure issues influencing logistics in Europe.

courses.title: Finance for the Logistics Practitioner
courses.description: This course provides an in-depth understanding of concepts of finance that relate to logistics, such as valuing logistics activities and measuring logistics performance.

courses.title: Financial Decision Making for Logistics
courses.description: This course provides a thorough understanding of the key elements of building a better logistics business case.

courses.title: Trade and Transportation in the Americas
courses.description: This course provides an overview of legal, cultural, political, and infrastructure issues influencing logistics practices in the Americas.

courses.title: Warehousing and Cross-Docking
courses.description: This course surveys the different types of warehouses and their functions, principles of operation, and strategic relationship to the supply chain.

courses.title: International Trade and Transportation
courses.description: This course discusses how international trade is financed, what instruments are used and how they work, how transactions are settled, and the role of documentation.

courses.title: International Freight Management
courses.description: This course focuses on international freight management including consolidation, export packaging, customs, tracking, terminal operations, mode selection, and carrier selection.

courses.title: Asian Trade and Transportation
courses.description: This course provides an overview of legal, cultural, political, and infrastructure issues influencing logistics practices in Asia.

courses.title: Supply Chain Management II: ERP Systems
courses.description: This course provides a strategic view of Enterprise Resource Planning and its relationship to logistics functions.

courses.title: Marketing Channels and Partnering
courses.description: This course focuses on logistics and supply chain issues as they impact the global marketing strategies of companies.

courses.title: Global Supply Chain Design and Measurement
courses.description: This course focuses on concepts and models for designing and measuring a global supply chain, with special focus on the impact of e-commerce.

courses.title: Transportation
courses.description: This course focuses on logistics planning, execution, and performance measurement in the transportation industry.

courses.title: Manufacturing
courses.description: This course focuses on logistics issues within the manufacturing facility including inventory, throughput, lead-time batching, and managing variability.

courses.title: Supply Chain Integration Lab III
courses.description: This course integrates supply chain management techniques in the Americas, Asia, and Europe through case studies.

courses.title: Cases in International Logistics I
courses.description: In this course, cases are used to integrate strategic, management, and operating issues in international logistics and supply chain design.

courses.title: Cases in International Logistics II
courses.description: In this course, cases are used t integrate strategic, management, and operating issues in international logistics and supply chain design.

courses.title: Cases in International Logistics III
courses.description: In this course, cases are used to integrate strategic, management, and operating issues in international logistics and supply chain design.

courses.title: Cases in International Logistics IV
courses.description: In this course, cases are used to integrate strategic, management, and operating issues in international logistics and supply chain design.

courses.title: Supply Chain Lab I
courses.description: This course integrates supply chain management techniques in the region through readings, case studies, meetings and site visits.  Typically Supply Chain Lab I focuses on the US.  Credit not allowed for both IL 6480 and IL 6470.

courses.title: Supply Chain Lab II
courses.description: This course integrates supply chain management techniques in the region through readings, case studies, meetings and site visits.  Typically Supply Chain Lab II focuses on Europe.  Credit not allowed for both IL 6481 and IL 6471.

courses.title: Supply Chain Lab IV
courses.description: This course integrates supply chain management techniques in the region through readings, case studies, meetings and site visits.  Typically Supply Chain Lab IV focuses on Asia.  Credit not allowed for both IL 6483 and IL 6473.

courses.title: Supply Chain Lab V
courses.description: This course integrates supply chain management techinques in the region through readings, case studies, meetings, and site visits.  Typically Supply Chain Lab V focuses on Mexico and NAFTA.  Credit not allowed for both IL 6484 and IL 6474.

courses.title: Strategic Decision Making and Compromise Game
courses.description: A multifirm, competitive management simulation.  The objective is to sharpen intra-firm communications skills using the internet as the communications channel and the art of compromise.

courses.title: Cross-cultural Communications for Management
courses.description: Participants learn tools and information to improve communications skills with new approaches and increased understanding while taking into account the effects of cross-cultural differences on communications.

courses.title: Data Analysis for Business
courses.description: Covers common statistical tools for the analysis of corporate data such as descriptive statistics, probability concepts, sampling and estimation, hypothesis testing, and regression analysis.

courses.title: Organizational Behavior and Theory
courses.description: Students learn the basic concepts and principles of organizational behavior and utilize such to analyze and solve organizational decision-making problems.

courses.title: Leadership and Organizational Behavior
courses.description: This course focuses on the challenges in leading teams and organizations in increasingly complex, global, and dynamic business environments.

courses.title: Leadership and Organizational Behavior
courses.description: This course focuses on the challenges in leading teams and organizations in increasingly complex, global, and dynamic business environments.

courses.title: Economic Analysis of Decisions in a Global Economy
courses.description: Participants are provided with a non-traditional approach using an analytical method with a global perspective to the concepts and role of economics in the world environment.

courses.title: Financial and Managerial Accounting
courses.description: Course covers financial reporting and analysis issues facing firms, and managerial accounting information necessary for planning, controlling, and decision making within such firms.

courses.title: Information Systems for Global Organizations
courses.description: Tools and techniques to manage the information technology infrastructure that supports a global organization.

courses.title: Managerial Finance in World Markets
courses.description: A two-part course providing an understanding of finance concepts and how they are used.  The course then further integrates international and ethical considerations wherever applicable.

courses.title: Financial Management
courses.description: An introduction to finance. Topics include time value of money, capital budgeting, risk and return, capital structure, dividend policy, and working capital management.

courses.title: Manufacturing and Service Management
courses.description: Covers the basic conceptual and analytical skills that are required in managing operations and confronting operational problems in competitive markets.

courses.title: Managing Marketing
courses.description: Students are provided with an understanding of marketing and consumer behavior concepts and tools with an international environment approach.

courses.title: Product Strategies for Global Markets
courses.description: Developing and marketing new products and services with an emphasis on international markets.

courses.title: Risk Management and Technology Transfer
courses.description: A course based upon a combination of cases, historical data, and theoretical interpretation on the analysis and allocation of risk in international investment and technology transfer.

courses.title: Managing the Global Workforce
courses.description: A survey of global workforce management principles and the skills necessary to function effectively in a supervisory role in a global organization.

courses.title: Strategy
courses.description: Integrate knowledge of the functional areas of a business to understand how firms gain and sustain a competitive advantage in a globally competitive environment.

courses.title: Competing Globally
courses.description: This course utilizes case studies of companies in various industries and in national cultures to highlight organizational and cultural differences between major economies in the global environment.

courses.title: Entrepreneurship and Entrepreneurial Firms
courses.description: Participants explore the increasing importance of small and medium-sized businesses and new ventures in international business.

courses.title: National and International Regulation of Business
courses.description: Deals with learning how to control the legal aspects of international decisions.

courses.title: Quality, Sustainable Technology, Competitiveness
courses.description: Students learn the philosophy and techniques of strategic quality management while focusing on assessment and group decisions centered on sustaining technology and competitiveness.

courses.title: Leadership Skills and Processes
courses.description: Focuses on identifying and developing the attributes of successful leadership.

courses.title: Strategic Business Simulation
courses.description: A unifying course providing a simulated application of the material taught in the core courses of the program.

courses.title: Analysis of Emerging Technology
courses.description: A case-based course dealing with the role and impact of digital technology in large and small organizations, with special emphasis on multinational companies.

courses.title: Applied Entrepreneurship Seminar
courses.description: A case course building an information bank of theory and practice on start-up enterprises.  Several entrepreneurs will co-teach the course with a faculty leader.

courses.title: International Business Negotiations
courses.description: A role-play course involving the complex international negotiation simulation dealing with an international business enterprise and its relationship with one or more governments.

courses.title: International Finance
courses.description: Analysis of foreign exchange markets, exchange rate risk management, international portfolio investments, international asset pricing, cross-border M&A, and equilibrium conditions in international markets.

courses.title: Global Supply Chain and Electronic Commerce
courses.description: Examines business, managerial and economic issues in the management of global supply chains and the role of electronic commerce in the supply chain.

courses.title: Analysis of Global Environments I
courses.description: Analysis of a specific region through an international study tour with emphasis on understanding the economy, culture and business environment.

courses.title: Analysis of Global Environments
courses.description: Analysis of a specific region through an international study tour with emphasis on understanding its economy, culture and business environment.

courses.title: Analysis of Global Environments II
courses.description: Analysis of a specific region through an international study tour with emphasis on understanding the economy, culture and business environment.

courses.title: Global Strategy Project I
courses.description: Students work on a real world problem related to global strategy.  The focus in this course is on data collection and problem definition.

courses.title: Global Strategy Project I
courses.description: Students work on a real world problem related to global strategy. The focus in this course is on problem definition, data collection and client engagement management.

courses.title: Global Strategy Project II
courses.description: Students work on a real world problem related to global strategy.  The focus in this course is on defining a preliminary solution that has desirable characteristics.

courses.title: Global Strategy Project II
courses.description: Students work on a real world problem related to global strategy. The focus in this course is on problem definition, data collection and client engagement management.

courses.title: Global Strategy Project II
courses.description: Students work on a real world problem related to global strategy.  The focus in this course is on defining and presenting a comprehensive solution.

courses.title: Business Strategies for Sustainability
courses.description: Cross-functional strategies to address competitive and regulatory demands placed on firms for achieving sustainable business practices.

courses.title: Effective Study Abroad
courses.description: Introduces essential background information concerning countries, concepts, and what to do in order to gain maximum benefit from participation in school-sponsored study abroad programs.

courses.title: The World Today
courses.description: Introduction to current issues of politics, geography, and history around the globe, using a wide variety of media and sources.

courses.title: Introduction to International Relations
courses.description: An introduction to the major principles, concepts, actors, and theories of the international system and their application to current issues in world affairs.

courses.title: American Government in Comparative Perspective
courses.description: Examines American government in relation to other political and economic systems in countries around the world. Includes study of the Constitution of Georgia. Credit not allowed for both POL 1101 and INTA 1200.

courses.title: Careers in International Affairs
courses.description: Reinforces career development and planning process for international affairs majors.  Includes facilitation of decision-making skills, job search strategies, self-assessment, and overview from industry speakers.  Credit not allowed for both INTA 2001 and INTA 1001.

courses.title: Empirical Methods
courses.description: Develops skills in research design, model building, and hypothesis construction. Provides experience in using computer software programs to perform statistical tests including t-tests, chi-square, and regression.

courses.title: Ethics in International Affairs
courses.description: Surveys the main traditions and theories of international ethics with a focus on intervention and the use of force, human rights, self-determination, and global distributive justice.

courses.title: Science, Technology, and International Affairs
courses.description: An overview of science and technology as a determinant in the development and functioning of states and societies worldwide and the international context for the development of science and technology.

courses.title: Introduction to Global WMD Issues
courses.description: This course will explore the challenges, history, and major theoretical frameworks relating to weapons of mass destruction (WMD).

courses.title: Introduction to Global Development
courses.description: Mainstream and critical approaches to development, the role of diverse institutions and projects, and implications for sustainability in the countries of the global south.

courses.title: Theoretical Approaches to Great Power Relations
courses.description: Juxtaposes competing explanations for the patterns of conflict and cooperation among nations, illustrated by relations among the great powers of Europe and Asia during the past two centuries.

courses.title: Introduction to International Security
courses.description: Introduction to the role of theory and provide an understanding of the significance of various issues in international security.

courses.title: Comparative Political Philosophies and Ideologies
courses.description: Explores political ideologies and philosophies, including theories of democracy, capitalism, and socialism, as well as rival views of the "good society" in comparative and historical perspective.

courses.title: Government and Politics of Europe
courses.description: A comparative analysis of the politics and major institutions of the countries of contemporary Western Europe.

courses.title: Politics of the European Union
courses.description: Introduction and overview of the history and politics of the European Union from its inception to the new era of development under the 2009 Lisbon Treaty.

courses.title: Government and Politics of Asia
courses.description: An introduction to the major issues and aspects of the politics, societies, and cultures of East Asia, and the changing role of the region in international affairs.

courses.title: Government, Politics and Society of Latin America
courses.description: Introduction to the study of historical forces, cultural production, identity, political development and contemporary issues in Latin America.

courses.title: Government, Politics and Society of the Middle East
courses.description: Introduction to the study and analysis of contemporary Middle East politics with an emphasis on the Arab states.

courses.title: Intern Assistantship
courses.description: Undergraduate Internship for International Affairs for pay.

courses.title: Undergraduate Internship
courses.description: Undergraduate Internship for International Affairs for academic credit.

courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.description: Topics of current interest in International Affairs.

courses.title: International Technology Transfer
courses.description: Explores the impact of technology transfer on key contexts such as economic development and the international diffusion of defense production and technology.

courses.title: War in the 20th Century
courses.description: Provides historical foundation and understanding of the causes, conduct and consequences of modern war to support informed discussion and analysis of contemporary crisis and conflict.

courses.title: Contemporary Mexico
courses.description: This course examines the socio-economic and political history and development of twentieth century Mexico, with a focus on current problems and issues.

courses.title: Human Rights in a Technological World
courses.description: Explores how processes of globalization and advances in communication and technology have heightened and shaped human rights as a concern in international politics.

courses.title: Energy, Environment, and Policy
courses.description: Explores the interface between energy security and environmental sustainability with the aim of understanding the consequences of policy decisions for ecological, social, and economic systems.

courses.title: Energy and International Security
courses.description: Examines issues at the intersection of national energy security and international conflict and cooperation.

courses.title: Space Policy
courses.description: Examination of the origins, evolution and range of current challenges and debates in international space policy issues, including civil, military, and commercial activities.

courses.title: Global Politics of Technology
courses.description: Examination of the economic and political dynamics that influence how regulations governing technology are adopted around the world.

courses.title: The Meaning of Global Citizenship
courses.description: Explore the meaning of global citizenship in scholarly and public debates and how it is "practiced" by individuals and "institutionalized" by universities, corporations and organizations.

courses.title: International Institutions
courses.description: Scrutinizes the evolution of international institutions, and juxtaposes competing theoretical approaches for understanding the changing roles and functions of institutions in world affairs.

courses.title: The Problem of Proliferation
courses.description: Explores the political and economic issues, both international as well as domestic, involved in the spread of the weapons of mass destruction since the end of the Second World War.

courses.title: The Challenge of Terrorism
courses.description: Examines the contexts that nurture domestic and international terrorism, the variety of terrorist organizations, and alternative approaches to combating the problem.

courses.title: International Negotiations
courses.description: Examines the theories of bargaining and negotiation, with an emphasis on explaining success and failure in U.S. foreign policy and national security negotiations.

courses.title: U.S. Foreign Policy
courses.description: Analyzes the formulation and implementation of America's foreign policy from 1914 to the present, stressing economic, political, and strategic factors.

courses.title: U.S. Defense Policy
courses.description: Examines contemporary American defense policy, including the formulation of strategy, the defense budget, force structure, and nontraditional uses of military force.

courses.title: European Security Issues
courses.description: Explores the contemporary European security environment, including threats, challenges, and various security architectures (e.g., NATO, the WEU, and the OSCE).

courses.title: Foreign Policies of Russia and Eurasia
courses.description: Examines the many dimensions of the foreign and security policies of Russia and the other new post-Soviet states of Russia and Eurasia.

courses.title: Foreign Policy of China
courses.description: Analyzes the major dimensions of the foreign policies of the People's Republic of China and the domestic and international influences shaping those policies.

courses.title: Pacific Security Issues
courses.description: Examines past, present, and future security concerns in the Pacific, including the Korean peninsula, Japanese defense, the emergence of China as a military power, and the forward basing of American troops and materiel.

courses.title: Comparative Politics
courses.description: Contrasts competing theoretical perspectives in the comparative analysis of political systems.

courses.title: Government and Politics of Germany
courses.description: Examines the government and politics of Germany with an in-depth focus on the post-1945 period.  NOTE: When taught jointly with the School of Modern Languages, all lectures, assignments, and readings are in German.

courses.title: Post-Soviet Government and Politics
courses.description: Focuses on the challenge of building new social, political, and economic systems in Russia, but also considers some of the special problems confronting the other fourteen post-Soviet states.

courses.title: Transatlantic Relations
courses.description: Analysis of the different aspects of the relationship between the US and the EU and how it is characterized by cooperation, conflict and competition.

courses.title: Government and Politics of China
courses.description: Investigates the structure and institutions of political power as well as the patterns and features of political change in the contemporary People's Republic of China.

courses.title: Government and Politics of Japan
courses.description: Examines the main institutions, policies, and politics of contemporary Japan. Investigates the impact of social, cultural, and economic forces on Japan's government and politics.

courses.title: Sustainable Megaregion
courses.description: Explores the ways in which environmental, economic, social, and technological forces shape megaregion sustainability in through comparison with megaregions in countries around the world.

courses.title: Government and Politics of Africa
courses.description: A survey of the history, cultures, social systems, governments, economies, and international roles of Africa. Selected case studies of individual countries are presented.

courses.title: Latin American Politics
courses.description: Surveys the government and politics of Latin America.  The course begins with an overview of the region's geography and history, and then explains why demographic government has had a tenuous existence in this area.

courses.title: Soccer and Global Politics
courses.description: An examination of regional and national identity, development, and politics through the history of soccer.

courses.title: US - Latin American Relations
courses.description: Study of government and non-governmental influences on policy and effectiveness of political, economic, and military instruments of power in Latin America.

courses.title: Middle East Relations
courses.description: Course will provide an in-depth understanding of the Arab-Israeli conflict using theories of international relations and comparative politics.

courses.title: International Political Economy
courses.description: Analyzes the relationship between political and economic issues in international affairs. Examines the interaction of states and markets in the context of trade, investment, and production.

courses.title: Political Economy of Development
courses.description: Surveys theories of economic development and political change, and examines a range of cases that include the European-American experience, the East Asian episode, and the transition from socialism.

courses.title: International Trade and Production
courses.description: Examines the political economy of international trade and the global production process with particular emphasis on conflict and cooperation in national competition for high- technology industries.

courses.title: Political Economy of European Integration
courses.description: Explores the processes and problems of political and economic integration in the European Union, the world's largest trading bloc.

courses.title: Political Economy of China
courses.description: Examines the centuries of stagnation and the recent rapid growth of the Chinese economy, and seeks to understand the current interaction between politics and economic development in the People's Republic of China.

courses.title: Political Economy of Japan
courses.description: Surveys the political foundations and economic achievements of modern Japan.  Explores the interaction of domestic and international forces, and analyzes Japan's changing world role.

courses.title: Global Issues and Leadership
courses.description: Invited project based seminar: Uses global issues to explore diverse viewpoints, cultures and cognitive biases to develop leadership and presentation skills in small diverse groups.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Selected topics will vary from term to term.

courses.title: Intelligence and International Security
courses.description: This coures examines the history, nature and business of secret intelligence as a critical element of national and international security, with special emphasis given to its role in the global war on terror, and the relationship between the intelligence community and policy makers.

courses.title: Technology and Military Organization
courses.description: Addresses the impact of technological developments on the evolution of military organization and on international conflict from the Battle of Agincourt (1415) to the Gulf War (1991).

courses.title: Scenario Writing and Pathgaming
courses.description: Introduces students to the construction and presentation of formalized scenarios for international planning, and into the formation, implementation, and assessment of path games.  Credit not allowed for both INTA 4014 and INTA 6014.

courses.title: Strategy and Arms Control
courses.description: Explores elements of military strategy and tactics, weapons proliferation, and arms control efforts.

courses.title: Environmental Politics
courses.description: Examines the interface between politics and the environment.  Foci include sustainable development, the politics of the rain forest, eco-tourism, and export agriculture and the environment.

courses.title: International Affairs and Technology Policy Making
courses.description: International policy issues in which science and technology figure prominently.  Topics include: health, environment, information technologies, arms control and defense, critical infrastructure, transportation, and energy.  Emphasis placed on policy analysis and formation.

courses.title: International Law
courses.description: Explores major issues, concepts and cases in public international law and their policy ramifications. Specific topics include human rights, armed conflict, crimes against humanity, and the environment.

courses.title: Politics of the Vietnam War
courses.description: Strategic approaches and political environments of the United States, North Vietnam, China, and the USSR during 1954-1975 Vietnam War.

courses.title: Seminar in Europe: European Security
courses.description: Examines the history, institutional structure, and functions, as well as current policy challenges facing NATO and other European security arrangements.

courses.title: Seminar in Europe: European Union
courses.description: Explores the history and processes of economic and political integration within the framework of the European Union.

courses.title: Argentine Politics, History, and Culture
courses.description: Survey of the politics, history, and culture of Argentina. Topics include Argentine economic and political failure, the politics of immigration, and the relationship between culture and development.

courses.title: Democracy in the Global South
courses.description: Assesses theories about democracy and explores their applicability in the Global South. Examines the concept of democracy and explores its causes and effects.

courses.title: Chinese Economic Reform
courses.description: Addresses the profound and consequential process of the Chinese economic reform that started at the end of the 1970s and has led to China's rapid economic growth.

courses.title: Chinese Politics in Transition
courses.description: Investigates the organizational apparatus through which the Chinese Communist Party exercises leadership over politics and society, and the way in which reforms have changed those relationships.

courses.title: Chinese Institutions and Policy Process
courses.description: Supervised field research on the Chinese institutions and policy-making process especially in the areas of economic and social issues.

courses.title: Korean Security Policy
courses.description: An examination of the principal policy issues facing the United States with regard to the Korean Peninsula and the principal neighboring states, China and Japan.

courses.title: Latin American Regional Economic and Political Integration
courses.description: Examines institutional, interest group, international, and economic inputs and outputs of regional integration.

courses.title: Pro-Seminar in International Affairs
courses.description: Capstone experience in which students formulate strategies and policies to cope with international problems.  Themes vary from seminar to seminar.  Credit not allowed for both INTA 4500 and INTA 4400.

courses.title: Seminar in Political Economy
courses.description: Capstone experience in which students apply tools of political economy to international issues. Crosslisted with ECOn 4740.

courses.title: Thesis in Political Economy
courses.description: Individual project applying the tools of political economy to international issues. Crosslisted with ECON 4741.

courses.title: Modeling, Simulation, and Military Gaming
courses.description: Creation and use of modeling and simulation tools to analyze and train students regarding strategic events in international relations.  Credit not allowed for both INTA 4742 and INTA 6742 (or CSE 6742 or CS 4343).

courses.title: Global Development Capstone
courses.description: Teams develop solutions to multidisciplinary problems selected from globalization, food security, infrastructure, health, water, sanitation, hygiene, ecosystem resilience, services, capacity building, and urbanization.

courses.title: Information and Communication Technologies and Global Development
courses.description: Focus on technology, design, adoption, and use as seen through the lens of global development.

courses.title: Strategic Decision Making
courses.description: Examines the dynamics of individual, group, organizational, cross-cultural, and international interaction.

courses.title: Empirical Research Methods
courses.description: This course introduces research methods in international affairs.  It emphasizes writing research proposals, empirical techniques, gathering and assembling data, and methods for analyzing and reporting results.

courses.title: Modeling, Forecasting, and Decision Making
courses.description: This course introduces modeling and forecasting in strategic decision making, analysis of long-term developments, path gaming, formal analysis of games, and simulation.

courses.title: International Trade and Technology Transfer
courses.description: This course examines the relationship between international trade and technology transfer and their effect on national competitiveness, national security, and international cooperation and coercion.

courses.title: Scenario Writing and Path Gaming
courses.description: Introduces students to the construction and presentation of formalized scenerios for international planning, and into the formulation, implementation and assessment of path games.  Credit not allowed for both INTA 6014 and INTA 4014.

courses.title: Technology and Military Organizations
courses.description: Explores changes in military technology, organization, and operations leading to new conceptions of the conduct of warfare as a result of revolutions in military affairs.

courses.title: Strategy and Arms Control
courses.description: Explores elements of military strategy and tactics, weapons proliferation, and arms control efforts.

courses.title: Ethics and International Affairs
courses.description: An overview of the main tradition and theories of international ethics applied to four major issues: intervention and the use of force; human rights; self- determination; and global distributive justice.

courses.title: International Relations Theory
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to theoretical approaches to understanding international relations.  The focus of the course is on system-level theories and sub-systematic-level theories.

courses.title: International Security
courses.description: Examines traditional and nontraditional issues in international security, including the uses of military force, military strategy and policy, arms control, peacekeeping, the environment, and migration.

courses.title: International Institutional Design
courses.description: This course examines international institutions and their effect on foreign policy decision makers. Specific topics include: the theoretical study of cooperation; supranatural organizations and informal institutions.

courses.title: The State in International Affairs
courses.description: Explores various concepts of the state in international affairs as well as the concepts of sovereignty and revolution.

courses.title: U.S. Foreign and National Security Strategy
courses.description: This course focuses on the design and implementation of U.S. foreign policy and national strategy in the areas of arms control, the Third World, and economic policy.

courses.title: Seminar In Europe: European Security
courses.description: This course examines the history, institutional structure and functions, and current policy challenges facing the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) and other European security institutions.

courses.title: Science, Technology and National Security
courses.description: Topics in the study of the relationship between national security and the scientific-technological enterprise from diverse perspectives.

courses.title: Pacific Security Issues
courses.description: Examines past, present, and future security concerns in the Pacific, including the Korean pennisula, Japanese defense, the emergence of China as a military power, and the forward basing of American troops and material.

courses.title: Comparative Politics
courses.description: This course surveys the major political types of the late twentieth century world and explores their various development characteristics.

courses.title: Comparative Institutional Design
courses.description: This course examines the creation, maintenance, and evolution of political institutions, and the ways in which institutions affect policy choice.

courses.title: International Political Economy
courses.description: This course is an introduction to the politics of international economic relations.  Major theoretical approaches are applied to international trade, international monetary relations, and global production in the modern era.

courses.title: Globalization
courses.description: Research seminar exploring theoretical perspectives on globalization and the political and economic issues facing modern states and their citizens in a "borderless" world.

courses.title: Seminar in Europe: European Union
courses.description: This course explores the history and processes of economic and political integration within the framework of the European Union.

courses.title: Political Economy of East Asia
courses.description: This course explores the politics of economic development in China, Japan, and Korea.  Focal issues include: trade patterns, financial institutions, trade-bloc formation, industrial competitiveness, and the status of U.S.-East Asian economic relations.

courses.title: Chinese Political Economy
courses.description: This course examines the Chinese social and economic development from the seventh century to current day. Specific emphasis is placed on the political economic reforms of Deng Xiaoping and assessing the implications of continued Chinese modernization.

courses.title: Data Analytics and Security
courses.description: Explores use of big data techniques to problems at the national and international levels.  Topics may include cybersecurity, surveillance, economic development, behavioral prediction and manipulation.

courses.title: Introduction to Global Development
courses.description: This course introduces students to the goals, theories and key institutional actors involved in the field of Global Development.

courses.title: Seminar: Politics Tech & Proliferation
courses.description:
This seminar course is designed specifically to encourage new thinking and creative effort on nuclear deterrence and strategic 
stability for our global future.

courses.title: Innovation, the State and Industrial Development in International Perspective
courses.description: Research seminar exploring the role of the state in industrial development, innovation and business-government relations. Special attention given to science and technology policies and their influence in different international and industrial contexts.  Crosslisted with PUBP 6740.

courses.title: Modeling, Simulation and Military Gaming
courses.description: Focuses on the creation and use of modeling and simulation tools to analyze and train students regarding strategic events in international relations. Credit not allowed for both INTA 6742 and CSE 6742 (or INTA 4742 or CS 4343).

courses.title: Information and Communication Technologies and Global Development
courses.description: Focus on technology design, adoption, and use as seen through the lens of global development.

courses.title: Comparative Science and Technology Policy
courses.description: Examination of the social, political, and cultural contexts of science and technology, and how they affect the research, development, and regulatory policies of nations. Crosslisted with PUBP 6753.

courses.title: Master's Thesis
courses.description: Under the direct supervision of one or more faculty members, graduate students will complete an original research design and execute that study.

courses.title: Seminar in Science, Technology and International Affairs I
courses.description: Research course introducing engineers and scientists to issues in science and technology as related to international security policy and development.

courses.title: Seminar in Science, Technology and International Affairs II
courses.description: Research course introducing engineers and scientists to issues in science and technology as related to international security policy and development.

courses.title: International Affairs, Science and Technology Ph.D. Proseminar
courses.description: An overview of resources and practices of doctoral research in International Affairs, Science, and Technology. Meetings will consist of faculty guest lectures and talks from Library personnel and others.

courses.description: Topics include conditional probability, density and distribution functions from engineering, expectation, conditional expectation, laws of large numbers, central limit theorem, and introduction to Poisson Processes.

courses.description: Point and interval estimation of systems parameters, statistical decision making about differences in system parameters, analysis and modeling of relationships between variables.
