courses.title: Introduction to Literature, Media, and Communication
courses.description: An the introductory course to LMC, this course introduces students to key texts and modes of analysis associated with the study of literature, film, digital media, and communication.

courses.title: Seminar in Literature, Media, and Communication
courses.description: This course introduces second-semester majors to the intellectual movements, interpretive frameworks, and research skills central to the disciplines represented in LMC.

courses.title: Introduction to Literary Studies
courses.description: Students will study literary and cultural texts, methods, and critical movements from a variety of perspectives and historical periods.

courses.title: Introduction to Science, Technology and Culture
courses.description: Relation to other courses, programs and curricula: As the introductory course to the LMC Science, Technology and Culture thread, this course explores the way in which disciplines construct and represent the knowledge they generate.

courses.title: Introduction to Gender Studies
courses.description: This course introduces the cultural concept of gender, examining topics such as biology and gender, social constructions of gender, and the psychology of sexual roles.

courses.title: Introduction to Social Justice
courses.description: Introduces students to the work and theory of social justice through readings from various disciplines, including literature, history, anthropology, philosophy, science, policy, and law.

courses.title: Introduction to Media Studies
courses.description: This course offers an introduction to the historical development and cultural impact of various forms of media print, radio, television, film, and interactive electronic applications.

courses.title: Introduction to Game Studies
courses.description: Introduction to the games studies and game designs.

courses.title: Introduction to Black Media Studies
courses.description: Introduces scholarship in Black Media Studies (BMS), which studies the relationships among media, culture, and racial politics by and about people of African descent.

courses.title: Introduction to Film
courses.description: Introduces film techniques and vocabulary in an historical and cultural context. Written texts are supplemented by viewings of specific shots, scenes, and films.

courses.title: LMC 2500 Recitation
courses.description: Film Screening for Introduction to Film.

courses.title: Introduction to Performance Studies
courses.description: An examination of the origins of the field of performance studies in literary study of theatre and drama, anthropological investigations of ritual, and sociological analyses of performance in everyday life.

courses.title: Theatre Production I
courses.description: In this hands-on course, students learn theatrical construction and painting techniques while building scenery for DramaTech productions.

courses.title: Theatre Production II
courses.description: In this hands-on course, students create the lighting, property, and costume effects for two DramaTech Theatre productions.

courses.title: Research Assistantship
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Introduction to Computational Media
courses.description: Introduction to key concepts, methods, and achievements in computational media, and the convergence of digital technology with cultural traditions of representation.

courses.title: Principles of Visual Design
courses.description: Studio-based course that provides students with basic skills needed to create digital visual images and to analyze designs from historical and theoretical perspectives.

courses.title: Constructing the Moving Image
courses.description: Provides the student with the conceptual, formal, aesthetic, and technical approaches to reconsider film, videos, and animation within the context of emerging digital forms.

courses.title: Special Topics in Literature and Culture
courses.description: Examination of one or more topics of current interest in literary and cultural studies.

courses.title: Film Acting Workshop
courses.description: A workshop-based introduction to screen acting and the acting profession for the student who is interested in participating in the film and television industries.

courses.title: Science, Technology, and the Classical Tradition
courses.description: Explores the definition and transmission of science and technology within Greek, Arabic, and medieval Latin contexts.

courses.title: The Age of Scientific Discovery
courses.description: Examines the relationships among texts representing the literary, artistic, and scientific thought of the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries.

courses.title: The Age of Scientific Revolution
courses.description: Examines interrelation of technological, literary, artistic, and philosophical thought in the late sixteenth and seventeenth centuries.

courses.title: Evolution and the Industrial Age
courses.description: Connects later nineteenth century scientific and technological concepts and discoveries, particularly theories of evolution, to the literature and culture of the industrial age.

courses.title: Studies in Fiction
courses.description: Examines the elements of fiction and what has made fiction, especially the novel, distinctive, popular, and enduring. Readings may include formal, cultural, and historical theories.

courses.title: Poetry and Poetics
courses.description: A study of traditions of poetic practice and poetic theory in English through intensive line by line readings of poems from different periods in literary history.

courses.title: Communication & Culture
courses.description: Examines ways in which forms and media of communication create and are created by other cultural constructs.

courses.title: African American Literature and Culture
courses.description: Explores the works of African American writers from the Colonial period to the present and examines a variety of cultural constructs that have fundamentally shaped the African American literary tradition.

courses.title: Asian American Literature & Culture
courses.description: Explores Asian American literary and cultural contributions since the nineteenth century through the lens of migration histories and global events foundational to Asian American experience.

courses.title: Ethnicity in American Culture
courses.description: Explores literary and historical works considering ethnic issues in American culture, including immigration, social assimilation, "double consciousness", the development of ethnic identity/pride, and multiculturalism.

courses.title: Women, Literature, and Culture
courses.description: Students in this course will analyze writings by women and examine feminist and other relevant cultural critiques of literature.

courses.title: Science Fiction
courses.description: Examines science fiction texts from the last 200 years to show how they reflect ambigous reactions to change.

courses.title: Science Fiction Film and Television
courses.description: This course investigates science fiction as the genre developed during film history and has become one of the most popular forms of television narrative.

courses.title: LMC 3215 Recitation
courses.description: Film Screening for Science Fiction Film & Television.

courses.title: Literature and Medicine
courses.description: This course examines works of literature dealing overtly with illness and healing, works about or by physicians and other caregivers, and works that raise questions about ethical behavior in the face of sickness.

courses.title: Gender Studies in the Disciplines
courses.description: This course explores the concept of gender and its usefulness as a theoretical category in a variety of disciplines. It includes cultural studies of literature, communication media, cultural anthropology, sociology, history, and science.

courses.title: Major Authors
courses.description: An examination of the works and career of a major author in historical and cultural context.

courses.title: Shakespeare
courses.description: An examination of Shakespeare's works with attention to generic conventions, historical context, and the relationship of text and performance. Major works of Shakespeare's contemporaries are studied as appropriate.

courses.title: Creative Writing
courses.description: This course explores a range of creative literary genres, and combines study and analysis of existing modes of one or more forms in order to establish a basis for original creative work by class members.

courses.title: Writing for the Stage and Screen
courses.description: Basic principles of generating creative concepts, dramatic structure, character and dialogue development, and formatting for stage and screenplays.

courses.title: Studies in Film and Television
courses.description: Explores in depth a theoretical issue central to film and/or television. Among its concerns are authorship, genre history, spectatorship, ideology, narrative theory, and the relationship between these media and social history.

courses.title: LMC 3252 Recitation
courses.description: Film Screening for Studies in Film & Television.

courses.title: Animation
courses.description: This course examines animation from its earliest days as a "cinema of attractions' to its current development as a predominantly digital practice.

courses.title: LMC 3253 Recitation
courses.description: Film Screening for Animation.

courses.title: Film History
courses.description: Surveys the history of film from its machine origins to its present digital developments. It focuses on various movements, figures, and narrative developments in world cinema.

courses.title: LMC 3254 Recitation
courses.description: Film Screening for Film History.

courses.title: Cinema and Digital Culture
courses.description: This course examines the impact of digital technologies on contemporary cinema as well as the influence of different cinematic traditions on new digital media.

courses.title: LMC 3255 Recitation
courses.description: Film Screening for Cinema and Digital Culture.

courses.title: Major Filmmakers
courses.description: Traces in depth an individual artist's career and affords students the opportunity to immerse themselves in the works of an important figure in the world of film.

courses.title: LMC 3256 Recitation
courses.description: Film Screening for Major Filmmakers.

courses.title: Global Cinema
courses.description: This course examines selected movements, styles, and trends in world cinema, emphasizing how contemporary film's global nature affects cultural representation.

courses.title: LMC 3257 Recitation
courses.description: Film Screening for Global Cinema.

courses.title: Documentary Film
courses.description: This course examines significant movements, styles, and trends in fact-based film, emphasizing its cultural implications and formal strategies.

courses.title: LMC 3258 Recitation
courses.description: Film Screening for Documentary Film.

courses.title: Experimental Film
courses.description: This course examines the history and trends in experimental film and video, emphasizing the relationship to avant-garde art movements.

courses.title: LMC 3259 Recitation
courses.description: Experimental Film—Recitation.

courses.title: Performance Studies
courses.description: An examination of cultural theories of performance and their application to the analysis of specific performative events.

courses.title: Music, Culture, and Society
courses.description: Origins and development of contemporary popular music, including rock, trap, hip-hop, and other emerging and established forms.

courses.title: Science, Technology, and Ideology
courses.description: Examines specific scientific, philosophical, and literary/cultural texts in order to determine the role ideology plays in the construction of culture, especially scientific and technological culture.

courses.title: Science, Technology, and Gender
courses.description: Examines specific philosophical, scientific, and cultural texts to determine the role that gender has played in the scientific and technological knowledge, currently and historically.

courses.title: Science, Technology, and Race
courses.description: Examines specific historical and contemporary construction of race, within the prevailing scientific theories and ideologies in order to determine the role played by "race" in scientific and technological culture.

courses.title: Environmentalism and Ecocriticism
courses.description: Surveys the emergence of ecocriticism as an analytical framework for interpreting the verbal and visual rhetorics of environmentalism in both western and nonwestern cultures.

courses.title: The Rhetoric of Scientific Inquiry
courses.description: This course takes as its subject the ways in which argumentative and persuasive discourse is used to create and disseminate scientific knowledge.

courses.title: Technologies of Representation
courses.description: Explores historical, cultural, and theoretical issues related by technologies of representation, including written, spoken, and gestural languages; print, painting and illustration; still and moving photography; recorded sound; and computer mediated communications and interactive digital media.

courses.title: Science, Technology, and Postcolonialism
courses.description: Studies in the development of Postcolonial literary theory and historiography in order to analyze the interdependent discourses and practices of post-Enlightenment science/technology and European imperialism.

courses.title: Biomedicine and Culture
courses.description: Discuss the history of biology and medicine; popular representations of health, disease, and the medical establishment; and the cultural implications of medical imaging technologies.

courses.title: Film and/as Technology
courses.description: Examines the development of film technology and the implications of that technology for cinema's treatment of technology.

courses.title: LMC 3352 Recitation
courses.description: Film Screening for Film And/As Technology.

courses.title: Graphic and Visual Design
courses.description: Introduction to fundamentals of graphic and visual design of print and digital media. Familiarity with use of the World Wide Web, page layout, and computer graphic software recommended.

courses.title: Technical Communication, Theory and Practice
courses.description: This course introduces students to workplace document genres to develop visual and verbal skills in critical analysis and document development.

courses.title: Social Media
courses.description: Students learn the cultural history, theory, and practice of social media in a variety of settings, and its impact on personal, professional, and political life.

courses.title: Media, Culture, and Society
courses.description: Examines the transformative impact of various kinds of media on culture, politics, communication, and education.

courses.title: Video Production
courses.description: An introduction to video production including basic skills in storyboarding, scripting, filming, editing, and sound.

courses.title: Advanced Video Production
courses.description: This production course teaches students to create visually compelling and emotionally powerful images through shot design and the use of lights, cameras and prime lenses.

courses.title: The Rhetoric of Technical Narratives
courses.description: Focuses on the rhetorical problems posed by such narrative documents as technical proposals, recommendations reports, grant proposals, and marketing studies. Emphasis on document design, graphics, navigation systems, and editing.

courses.title: The Rhetoric of Nonlinear Documents
courses.description: Focuses on the rhetorical problems posed by hypertext documents. Emphasis in designing for multiple audiences, page and document design, and navigation in a nonlinear environment.

courses.title: The Rhetoric of Visual Communication
courses.description: Focuses on contexts, audiences, arguements, and design in creating and critiquing visuals. Emphasizes topics such as information design, technical visuals, and photography.

courses.title: Communicating Science and Technology to the Public
courses.description: Examines both the theoretical and practical issues involved in communicating scientific and/or technological material to a variety of lay audiences.

courses.title: Content Strategy
courses.description: Theory and professional communication practice of substance, workflow, structure, and governance of digital content for websites and social media.

courses.title: Technical Communication Approaches
courses.description: Part of a multi-semester sequence that students take in tandem with major-specific classes to develop professional written, visual, oral, and analytic strategies.

courses.title: Technical Communication Strategies
courses.description: Part of a multi-semester sequence that students take in tandem with major-specific classes to develop professional written, visual, oral, and analytic strategies.

courses.title: Blackness, Media, and Meaning-Making
courses.description: Considers the significance of Blackness in print, broadcast, and digital media.

courses.title: Race, Gender, and Digital Media
courses.description: Explores issues of race, ethnicity, and gender + the politics of technology (technoculture) in digital venues, social media, artificial intelligence, algorithms, and mundane digital phenomena.

courses.title: Introduction to Black Cultural Production
courses.description: Examines the communicative and cultural practices of Black mediated narratives across the Diaspora.

courses.title: Afrofuturism
courses.description: Students study Black cultural producers melding art and technology in science fiction and fantasy that reflect the complicated politics of envisioning the future.

courses.title: Producing Black Documentary Film and Podcasts
courses.description: Connects building healthy Black communities and Black economic empowerment within the framework of contemporary documentary filmmaking. Students will write, produce, edit, and distribute a mini-documentary.

courses.title: Major Topics in Black Media Studies
courses.description:
Surveys the origins, development, and considers conventions through an investigation of major topics 
of black media and music.

courses.title: Technoculture
courses.description: Grounded in a critical race and cultural theoretic framework, the course explores systems and practices of scientific inquiry as mediated by Whiteness, imperialism, and modernity.

courses.title: Black Cultural Politics and the Southern Experience
courses.description: Investigate racial politics, social justice, and technocultural innovation across  Atlanta and the American South.

courses.title: Afrofuturism and the Anthropocene
courses.description: Explores history and current status of Afrofuturism, a cultural movement, an epistemology, and an aesthetic centering Blackness and technology with visions for the future considering the Anthropocene.

courses.title: Ancient and Medieval Literature and Culture
courses.description: Introduction to Greece, Rome, and Medieval Europe through an examination of one or a few major culture conflicts expressed in the literary genres and periods.

courses.title: Renaissance Literature and Culture
courses.description: An examination of literature and culture from 1450 to 1650 with an emphasis on both major achievements and divergent voices.

courses.title: Enlightenment and Culture
courses.description: Examines the nature of the age from an intial boldness, optimism, and faith in reason to a recognition of its limits.

courses.title: American Literature & Culture
courses.description: Introduces students to American literature and culture broadly construed, examining foundational works of critical and historical significance.

courses.title: British and Continental Romanticism
courses.description: Examines British and Continental Romanticism as it appeared during the latter part of the eighteenth century and the first half of the nineteenth century.

courses.title: Victorian Literature and Culture
courses.description: Investigates the period 1830 - 1901 in English literature and culture, focusing on how that period defined key questions, especially ones about human nature, society, and the relation of religion to science.

courses.title: Literary and Cultural Modernism
courses.description: A partial investigation of the aesthetic ferment that characterizes English-language cultural production from the turn of the century to the end of World War II.

courses.title: Literary and Cultural Postmodernism
courses.description: A survey of major themes, representational techniques, and social and cultural concerns of postmodern art and literature.

courses.title: Contemporary Issues in Literature & Culture
courses.description: This course will cover a range of possible critical areas of global concern in contemporary literature and culture. Focus will vary each semester.

courses.title: Theatre Production III: Management
courses.description: In this "hands-on" course, students will create and execute a publicity campaign and operate the box office for DramaTech Theatre productions.

courses.title: Theatre Production IV: Acting
courses.description: This course providess students an opportunity to perform onstage in a production at DramaTech Theatre. Auditions are required.

courses.title: Principles of Information Design
courses.description: Presents principles and practices guiding the development of emerging digital genres. Emphasis on maximizing the affordances of the computer in organizing and communicating complex information.

courses.title: Principles of Interaction Design
courses.description: Examines principles of design for shaping the procedural and participatory affordances of digital environments, emphasizing the role of cultural context and media transitions.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Special Topics.

courses.title: Senior Seminar in Literature, Media, and Communication
courses.description: Capstone seminar that asks majors to draw upon their training to engage in closer analysis, research, and/or production in topical area. Topic varies by instructor.

courses.title: Senior Thesis
courses.description: Preparation for and writing of a thesis through faculty-directed independent study.

courses.title: Poetry and Poetics II
courses.description: Advanced study of the traditions of poetic theory and practice with a special emphasis on processes of poetic conception and revision.

courses.title: Contemporary Issues in Professional Communication
courses.description: Intended primarily for students planning careers in professional communication, this course will alternate among a number of issues including property law, integrating print and electronic media, and cultural studies of corporate environments.

courses.title: Video Editing and Postproduction
courses.description: Introduction to Editing and Post Production develops the skills and knowledge of digital film post-production, concentrating on editing, editing theory, narrative editing, and post-production workflow.

courses.title: Seminar in Film Studies
courses.description: An in-depth investigation of a major movement, theory, period, or technological development in film studies.

courses.title: LMC 4500 Recitation
courses.description: Film Screening for Seminar in Film.

courses.title: Performance Practicum
courses.description: Practical experience and theoretical investigations in theatre and performance making including acting, directing, designing, playwriting, performance art, performance and new media.

courses.title: Research Assistantship
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research Proposal Writing
courses.description: This course is intended to guide undergraduate students from all disciplines through the stages of writing a proposal for their research option project and thesis.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research Thesis Writing
courses.description: This course is intended to guide undergraduate students from all disciplines through the stages of writing their undergraduate thesis.

courses.title: Game Studio
courses.description: Project-based course in designing and implementing video games.

courses.title: Interactive Narrative
courses.description: Examines significant examples of this emerging genre, including its roots ini experimental uses of older media, and engages students in creating their own interactive narrative.

courses.title: Games Design as a Cultural Practice
courses.description: Emphasis is on the design elements common to games and the expressive possibilities and cultural concerns specific to digital games.

courses.title: Experimental Digital Art
courses.description: Provides students with key conceptual, formal, aesthetic and technical elements needed in creating artifacts in areas ranging from augmented and mixed reality to scientific visualization.

courses.title: Game AI
courses.description: Examines expressive possibilities of artificial intelligence techniques in computer games.

courses.title: Mixed Reality Experience Design
courses.description: Project-based course in designing implementing experiences using the technologies of Augmented, Mixed, and Virtual Reality. Credit not awarded for both LMC 4733 and CS 4770/6770/LMC 6340.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Topic of current interest not covered in the regular course offerings.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Topics of current interest not covered in the regular course offerings.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Topics of interest not covered in the regular course offerings.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Topics of interest not covered in the regular course offerings.

courses.title: Internship
courses.description: Offers students a workplace-based learning experience that stresses application of principles and skills gained in other STAC classes.

courses.title: Edu Applications New
courses.description: This course introduces students to a variety of perspectives on learning as they apply to work in educational technology. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6213 and LCC 6213.

courses.title: Issues in Media Studies
courses.description: This course focuses on the study of mass media from historical, theoretical, and cultural perspectives. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6215 and LCC 6215.

courses.title: The Computer as an "Expressive Medium"
courses.description: Explores the development of the representational power of the computer and the interplay between digital technology and culture. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6310 and LCC 6310.

courses.title: Visual Culture and Design
courses.description: Explores visual media through a mutually instructive and integrated interplay between critical analyses and the creation of digital artifacts. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6311 and LCC 6311.

courses.title: Design, Technology & Representation
courses.description: Explores historical, cultural, and theoretical issues raised by technologies of representation through critical analyses and the creation of digital artifacts. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6312 and LCC 6312.

courses.title: Principles of Interaction Design
courses.description: Explores visual media through a mutually instructive and integrated interplay between critical analyses and the creation of digital artifacts. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6313 and LCC 6313.

courses.title: Design of Networked Media
courses.description: Issues in hypertextual and multimedia design in networked environments, including the World Wide Web, interactive television, and wireless applications. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6314 and LCC 6314.

courses.title: Product Production
courses.description: Focuses on defining user and client needs, analysis of competing products, budgeting, scheduling and management of the production process, and the design of the testing process. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6315 and LCC 6315.

courses.title: Historical Approaches to Digital Media
courses.description: Examines digital media in the context of earlier media, such as handwriting and printing as well as photography, radio, film, and television. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6316 and LCC 6316.

courses.title: Interactive Narrative/Fiction
courses.description: Students create interactive fictions in a variety of formats including intersecting story worlds, interactive characters, simulations, and replay worlds. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6317 and LCC 6317, LMC 6317 and LCC 4720, or LMC 6317 and LMC 4720.

courses.title: Experimental Media
courses.description: Students will develop the critical, intellectual, and creative tools necessary to understand, work with, and reimagine design at the developmental stages of emerging technologies. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6318 and LCC 6318.

courses.title: Intellectual Property Policy and Law
courses.description: Students examine constitutionally informed policy and pragmatic legal issues in intellectual property law, focusing on the effects of power structures and information digitization. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6319 and LCC 6319.

courses.title: Globalization and New Media
courses.description: Historical and theoretical approach to the connections between modes of global integration and modes of representing information. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6320 and LCC 6320.

courses.title: Architecture of Responsive Spaces
courses.description: Historical and theoretical approach to the connections between modes of global integration and modes of representing information. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6321 and LCC 6321.

courses.title: Global Intellectual Property Policy and Law
courses.description: This course requires that students gain facility with intellectual property statutory and treaty law and understand US and global policies that affect power and access.

courses.title: Game Design and Analysis
courses.description: Focused topics in the theory and practice of game design, theory, and analysis, including issues of creation, and reception, such as a single sub-genre, procedural technique, or media tradition. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6325 and LCC 6325, LMC 6325 and LCC 4725, or LMC 6325 and LMC 4725.

courses.title: Expressive Virtual Space
courses.description: Practical and theoretical investigation of virtual space in real-time 3D environments with a focus on meditation and functionality. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6330 and LCC 6330.

courses.title: Mixed Reality Experience Design
courses.description: This course introduces students to the design of digital experienced for education and entertainment using Augmented Reality, Tangible Computing, or other forms of Mixed Reality. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6340 and LCC 6340/LMC 4733/CS 6770/4770.

courses.title: The spatial construction of meaning: Design formulation and design cognition
courses.description: Study of the way in which space is manipulated to construct meaning in design formulation. Emphasis on logical structure, geometry, and experiential correlates. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6350 and LCC 6350.

courses.title: Global Ethnographies and Communication Practices
courses.description: This course employs ethnographic methods to examine how the creation of visual, textual and digita; artifacts can be understood as practices of intercultural communication.

courses.title: Transnational Networks
courses.description: In this course, we will look at the historical and theoretical implications of the networked construction of the Atlantic World, and the legacies it has left for contemporary global protest and liberation movements.

courses.title: Cultures of Empire
courses.description: This course focuses upon empires of the nineteenth-century and contemporary post-colonial responses to European colonization. Central issues include immigration, globalization, nationalism, imperial subjectivity, and belonging.

courses.title: Global Science Fiction
courses.description: Explores how authors and critics across the globe use science fiction to communicate experiences with science and technology across centuries, continents, and cultures.

courses.title: Literary and Cultural Theory
courses.description: Concentration on a single literary or cultural theorist and/or major school of literary or cultural theory, including, among others, Materialist, Feminist, Structuralist, Post-Structuralistm Cultural Studies.

courses.title: Global Cinema
courses.description: This course examines significant movements, styles, and trends in world cinema, with an emphasis on how the global nature of contemporary film affects cultural representation.

courses.title: Discovery & Invention
courses.description: Required course for all DM majors. The purpose of this course is to give students a suite of methods they can use in professional settings to discover opportunities for inventive new computational products and services. It complements the design and production skills developed in 6310 and 6313 with applied research skills. For students in the MS DM and MS HCI programs it will also help them in the development of their MS proposals. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6399 and LCC 6399.

courses.title: Project Studio
courses.description: This course offers students the opportunity to work on focused research within existing long-term projects of the New Media(NM) Center.

courses.title: STS Core Seminar
courses.description: This survey course covers key works Science, Technology & Society, and guest lectures introduce students to faculty doing STS-related research across the Ivan Allen College. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6743 and LCC 6743, LMC 6743 and HTS 6743, or LMC 6743 and PUBP 6743.

courses.title: Social Justice, Critical Theory, and Philosophy of Design
courses.description: Focuses on social justice from a Science, Technology, and Society(STS) point of view that is informed by critical theory and philosophy of design. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6748 and LCC 6748 or LMC 6748 and PUBP 6748.

courses.title: Feminist Theory and STS
courses.description: This course is an advanced science, technology and society (STS) seminar in feminist theory. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6749 and LCC 6749 or LMC 6749 and PUBP 6749.

courses.title: Human-Computer Interaction Professional Preparation and Practice
courses.description: Preparation for a professional career in HCI. Hands-on workshops in resume and portfolio building, interviewing, public speaking, team work. HCI career choices and trajectories.

courses.title: Mixed Reality Design
courses.description: This course introduces students to mixed reality design and prototyping with a focus on Augmented Reality. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 6770 and CS 4770.

courses.title: Digital Media Master's Project
courses.description: Final project course in Digital Media.

courses.title: HCI Master's Project
courses.description: Final project for students completing a Human-Computer Interaction master's degree in the Digital Media track. Repeatable for multi-semester projects.

courses.title: Digital Media Master's Thesis
courses.description: Final Thesis course in Digital Media.

courses.title: PhD Qualifying Prep
courses.description: Preparation for Ph.D. Qualifying exam.

courses.title: Proseminar in Media Theory
courses.description: Key traditions of media theory that contribute to the study of Digital Media. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 8000 and LCC 8000.

courses.title: Proseminar in Digital Media Studies
courses.description: Advanced work in production and critique of new media forms. Students cannot receive credit for LMC 8001 and LCC 8001.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Topic of current interest not covered in the regular course offerings.

courses.title: Special Topics in Digital Media
courses.description: Special Topics in Digital Media.

courses.title: Advanced Issues in Interactive Narrative
courses.description: Advanced Issues in Interactive Narrative.

courses.title: Special Topics in Game Design and Analysis
courses.description: Advanced topics in the theory and practice of game design, theory, and analysis, including creation, reception, procedural technique, and tradition.

courses.title: Special Topics in Technologies of Representation
courses.description: Special Topics in Technologies of Representation.

courses.title: Special Problems in Human-Computer Interaction
courses.description: Small-group of individual investigation of advanced topics in human-computer interaction. Guided study and research.

courses.title: Special Problems in Information Design and Technology
courses.description: An independent study course.

courses.title: Teaching Assistantship
courses.description: For graduate students holding teaching assistantships.

courses.title: Research Assistantship
courses.description: For graduate students holding research assistantships.

courses.title: PhD Doctoral Prep
courses.description: Doctoral Thesis Prep in Digital Media.

courses.title: Doctoral dissertation in Digital Media
courses.description: Doctoral Dissertation.

courses.title: Reading Skills
courses.description: Development of reading comprehension and speed, vocabulary, and study skills.  Review of grammar and usage.

courses.title: English Skills
courses.description: Development of basic skills used in writing the sentence, paragraph, and short essay. Development of reading speed.

courses.title: Mathematical Skills
courses.description: Intense review of arithmetic and algebra skills.  Development of mathematics study skills.

courses.title: Support for Precalculus
courses.description: Practicum for Learning Support students enrolled in MATH 1113 (Precalculus).

courses.title: Support for College Algebra
courses.description: This Learning Support course provides corequisite support in mathematics for students enrolled in MATH 1111 – College Algebra. Topics will parallel topics being studied in MATH 1111 and the course will provide support for the essential quantitative skills needed to be successful in MATH 1111. Taken with MATH 1111, this course provides an in-depth study of the properties of algebraic, exponential and logarithmic functions as needed for calculus. Emphasis is on using algebraic and graphical techniques for solving problems involving linear, quadratic, piece-wise defined, rational, polynomial, exponential and logarithmic functions.

courses.title: College Algebra
courses.description: This course provides an in-depth study of the properties of algebraic, exponential and logarithmic functions as needed for calculus. Emphasis is on using algebraic and graphical techniques for solving problems involving linear, quadratic, piece-wise defined, rational, polynomial, exponential and logarithmic functions.

courses.title: Pre-calculus
courses.description: This course is an intensive study of the basic functions needed for the study of calculus. Topics include algebraic, functional, and graphical techniques for solving problems with algebraic, exponential, logarithmic, and trigonometric functions and their inverses. May only be used for degree credit with departmental approval.

courses.title: Support for Differential Calculus
courses.description: This corequisite studio course provides extra precalculus support for students enrolled in Math 1551, Differential Calculus.

courses.title: Calculus I
courses.description: Differential calculus and basic integral calculus including the fundamental theorem of calculus. Credit not allowed for both MATH 1501 and 1712.

courses.title: Calculus I for the Life Sciences
courses.description: Differential and basic calculus: sequences, difference equations, limits, continuity, differentiation, integration, applications.  The topics parallel those of MATH 1501 with applications from life sciences.

courses.title: Calculus I for the Life Sciences
courses.description: Taylor approximations, introduction to differential equations, linear algebra, and introduction to multivariable calculus.  Motivating examples drawn from life sciences.

courses.title: Honors Calculus II
courses.description: The topics covered parallel those of 1502 with a somewhat more intensive and rigorous treatment.  Credit not allowed for both honors calculus and the corresponding regular calculus course.  Credit not allowed for both MATH 1512 and MATH 1522.  Credit not allowed for both MATH 1512 and MATH 15X2.

courses.title: Introduction to Differential Calculus
courses.description: An introduction to differential calculus including applications and the underlying theory of limits for functions and sequences. Credit not awarded for both MATH 1550 and MATH 1501, MATH 1551, or MATH 1503.

courses.title: Differential Calculus
courses.description: Differential calculus including applications and the underlying theory of limits for functions and sequences. Credit not awarded for both MATH 1551 and MATH 1501, MATH 1503, or MATH 1550.

courses.title: Integral Calculus
courses.description: Integral calculus: Definite and indefinite integrals, techniques of integration, improper integrals, infinite series, applications. Credit not awarded for both MATH 1552 and MATH 1502, MATH 1504, MATH 1512 or MATH 1555.

courses.title: Introduction to Linear Algebra
courses.description: An introduction to linear alegbra including eigenvalues and eigenvectors, applications to linear systems, least squares. Credit not awarded for both MATH 1553 and MATH 1522, MATH 1502, MATH 1504, MATH 1512, MATH 1554 or MATH 1564.

courses.title: Linear Algebra
courses.description: Linear algebra eigenvalues, eigenvectors, applications to linear systems, least squares, diagnolization, quadratic forms.

courses.title: Calculus for Life Sciences
courses.description: Overview of intergral calculus, multivariable calculus, and differential equations for biological sciences. Credit not awarded for both MATH 1555 and MATH 1552, MATH 1502, MATH 1504, MATH 1512 or MATH 2550.

courses.title: Linear Algebra with Abstract Vector Spaces
courses.description: This is an intensive first course in linear algebra including the theories of linear transformations and abstract vector spaces. Credit not awarded for both MATH 1564 and MATH 1553, MATH 1554, MATH 1522, MATH 1502, MATH 1504 or MATH 1512.

courses.title: Introduction to Higher Mathematics
courses.description: This course is designed to teach problem solving and proof writing.  Mathematical subject matter is drawn from elementary number theory and geometry.

courses.title: Finite Mathematics
courses.description: Linear equations, matrices, linear programming, sets and counting, probability and statistics.

courses.title: Survey of Calculus
courses.description: Techniques of differentiation, integration, application of integration to probability and statistics, multidimensional calculus. Credit not allowed for both MATH 1712 and 1501.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in Mathematics.

courses.title: Foundations of Mathematical Proof
courses.description: An introduction to proofs in advanced mathematics, intended as a transition to upper division courses including Abstract Algebra I and Analysis I.

courses.title: Abstract Vector Spaces
courses.description: A proof-based development of linear algebra and vector spaces, with additional topics such as multilinear algebra and group theory.

courses.title: Introduction to Multivariable Calculus
courses.description: Vectors in three dimensions, curves in space, functions of several variables, partial derivatives, optimization, integration of functions of several variables. Vector Calculus not covered. Credit will not be awarded for both MATH 2550 and MATH 2605 or MATH 2401 or MATH 2551 or MATH 1555.

courses.title: Multivariable Calculus
courses.description: Multivariable calculus: Linear approximation and Taylor's theorems, Lagrange multiples and constrained optimization, multiple integration and vector analysis including the theorems of Green, Gauss, and Stokes. Credit will not be awarded for both MATH 2551 and MATH 2401 or MATH 2411 or MATH 2561.

courses.title: Differential Equations
courses.description: Methods for obtaining numerical and analytic solutions of elementary differential equations. Applications are also discussed with an emphasis on modeling. Credit not awarded for both MATH 2552 and MATH 2403 or MATH 2413 or MATH 2562.

courses.title: Honors Multivariable Calculus
courses.description: The topics covered parallel those of MATH 2551 with a somewhat more intensive and rigorous treatment. Credit not awarded for both MATH 2561 and MATH 2401 or MATH 2411 or MATH 2551.

courses.title: Honors Differential Equations
courses.description: The topics covered parallel those of MATH 2552 with a somewhat more intensive and rigorous treatment.

courses.title: Introduction to Discrete Mathematics
courses.description: Mathematical logic and proof, mathematical induction, counting methods, recurrence relations, algorithms and complexity, graph theory and graph algorithms. Credit not awarded for both MATH 2603 and MATH 2602.

courses.title: Calculus III for Computer Science
courses.description: Topics in linear algebra and multivariate calculus and their applications in optimization and numerical methods, including curve fitting, interpolation, and numerical differentiation and integration.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research Assistantship
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Foundations of Mathematics and Computing
courses.description: This course introduces the essential mathematical concepts and computational techniques that form the basis of modern computing.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

courses.title: Applied Combinatorics
courses.description: Elementary combinatorial techniques used in discrete problem solving: counting methods, solving linear recurrences, graph and network models, related algorithms, and combinatorial designs.

courses.title: Applied Combinatorics Recitation
courses.description: Recitation for MATH 3012.

courses.title: Honors Applied Combinatorics
courses.description: Topics are parallel to those of MATH 3012 with a more rigorous and intensive treatment. Credit is not allowed for both MATH 3012 and 3022.

courses.title: Introduction to Probability and Statistics
courses.description: This course is a problem-oriented introduction to the basic concepts of probability and statistics, providing a foundation for applications and further study.

courses.title: Honors Probability and Statistics
courses.description: The topics covered parallel those of MATH 3215, with a more rigorous and intensive treatment.  Credit is not allowed for both MATH 3215 and 3225.

courses.title: Probability Theory
courses.description: This course is a mathematical introduction to probability theory, covering random variables, moments, multivariable distributions, law of large numbers, central limit theorem, and large deviations. Credit not awarded for both MATH 3235 and MATH 3215 or 3225 or 3670.

courses.title: Statistical Theory
courses.description: An introduction to theoretical statistics for students with a background in probability. A mathematical formalism for inference on experimental data will be developed. Credit not awared for both MATH 3236 and MATH 3215 or 3225 or 3670.

courses.title: A Second Course in Linear Algebra
courses.description: This course will cover important topics in linear algebra not usually discussed in a first-semester course, featuring a mixture of theory and applications.

courses.title: Probability and Statistics with Applications
courses.description: Introduction to probability, probability distributions, point estimation, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing, linear regression and analysis of variance. Students cannot receive credit for both MATH 3670 and MATH 3770 or ISYE 3770 or CEE 3770.

courses.title: Probability and Statistics for Computing and Machine Learning
courses.description: Introductory probability and statistics for computing and machine learning, from random variables, joint distribution and concentration inequalities to parameter estimation, statistical models and Bayesian simulation.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

courses.title: Algebraic Structures in Coding Theory
courses.description: Introduction to linear error correcting codes with an emphasis on the algebraic tools required, including matrices vector spaces, groups, polynomial rings, and finite fields.

courses.title: Introduction to Graph Theory
courses.description: The fundamentals of graph theory: trees, connectivity, Euler torus, Hamilton cycles, matchings, colorings, and Ramsey theory.

courses.title: Combinatorial Analysis
courses.description: Combinatorial problem-solving techniques including the use of generating functions, recurrence relations, Polya theory, combinatorial designs, Ramsey theory, matroids, and asymptotic analysis.

courses.title: Senior Project I
courses.description: The first of a two-course sequence of faculty-directed independent research culminating in the writing of a senior thesis and its presentation.

courses.title: Senior Project II
courses.description: The second course of a two-course sequence of faculty-directed independent research culminating in the writing of a senior thesis and its presentation.

courses.title: Introduction to Abstract Algebra I
courses.description: This course develops in the theme of "Arithmetic congruence and abstract algebraic structures". Strong emphasis on theory and proofs.

courses.title: Introduction to Abstract Algebra II
courses.description: Continuation of Abstract Algebra I, with emphasis on Galois theory, modules, polynomial fields, and the theory of linear associative algebra.

courses.title: Introduction to Number Theory
courses.description: Primes and unique factorization, congruences, Chinese remainder theorem, Diophantine equations, Diophantine approximations, quadratic reciprocity.  Applications such as fast multiplication, factorization, and encryption.

courses.title: Mathematical Foundations of Data Science
courses.description: Data science methods and their mathematical foundations: linear regression, classification, and clustering, kernel methods, regression trees and ensemble methods, dimension reduction.

courses.title: Stochastic Processes I
courses.description: Simple random walk and the theory of discrete time Markov chains.

courses.title: Stochastic Processes II
courses.description: Renewal theory, Poisson processes and continuous time Markov processes, including an introduction to Brownian motion and martingales.

courses.title: Monte Carlo Methods
courses.description: Probability distributions, limit laws, and applications through the computer.

courses.title: Mathematical Statistics I
courses.description: Sampling distributions, Normal, t, chi-square, and f distributions. Moment-generating function methods, Bayesian estimation, and introduction to hypothesis testing.

courses.title: Mathematical Statistics II
courses.description: Hypothesis testing, likelihood ratio tests, nonparametric tests, bivariate and multivariate normal distributions.

courses.title: Introduction to Information Theory
courses.description: The measurement and quantification of information.  These ideas are applied to the probabilistic analysis of the transmission of information over a channel along which random distortion of the message occurs.

courses.title: Topics in Linear Algebra
courses.description: Finite dimensional vector spaces, inner product spaces, least squares, linear transformations, the spectral theorem for normal transformations.  Applications to convex sets, positive matrices, difference equations.

courses.title: Analysis I
courses.description: Real numbers, topology of Euclidean spaces, Cauchy sequences, completeness, continuity and compactness, uniform continuity, series of functions, Fourier series.

courses.title: Analysis II
courses.description: Differentiation of functions of one real variable, Riemann-Stieltjes integral, the derivative in Rn, and integration in Rn.

courses.title: Complex Analysis
courses.description: Topics from complex function theory, including contour integration and conformal mapping.

courses.title: Partial Differential Equations I
courses.description: Method of characteristics for first- and second-order partial differential equations, conservation laws and shocks, classification of second-order systems and applications.

courses.title: Partial Differential Equations II
courses.description: Green's functions and fundamental solutions.  Potential, diffusion, and wave equations.

courses.title: Introductory Topology
courses.description: Point set topology, topological spaces and metric spaces, continuity and compactness, homotopy, and covering spaces.

courses.title: Introduction to Algebraic Topology
courses.description: Introduction to algebraic methods in topology. Includes homotopy, the fundamental group, covering spaces, simplicial complexes.  Applications to fixed point theory and group theory.

courses.title: Differential Geometry
courses.description: The theory of curves, surfaces, and more generally, manifolds.  Curvature, parallel transport, covariant differentiation, Gauss-Bonet theorem.

courses.title: Dynamics and Bifurcations I
courses.description: A broad introduction to the local and global behavior of nonlinear dynamical systems arising from maps and ordinary differential equations.

courses.title: Dynamics and Bifurcations II
courses.description: A continuation of Dynamics and Bifurcations I.

courses.title: Linear Programming
courses.description: A study of linear programming problems, including the simplex method, duality, and sensitivity analysis with applications to matrix games, interger programming, and networks.

courses.title: Classical Mathematical Methods in Engineering
courses.description: The Laplace transform and applications, Fourier series, boundary value problems for partial differential equations.

courses.title: Numerical Analysis I
courses.description: Introduction to numerical algorithms for some basic problems in computational mathematics.  Discussion of both implementation issues and error analysis.

courses.title: Numerical Analysis II
courses.description: Introduction to the numerical solution of initial and boundary value problems in differential equations.

courses.title: Undergraduate Internship
courses.description: Undergraduate internship for academic credit.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research Assistantship
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

courses.title: Computational Methods for Simulation and Machine Learning
courses.description: Introduction to numerical methods which are fundamental in modeling, simulation, and machine learning.

courses.title: Mathematical Biology
courses.description: Problems from the life sciences and the mathematical methods for solving them are presented.  The underlying biological and mathematical principles and the interrelationships are emphasized. Crosslisted with BIOL 4755.

courses.title: Vector and Parallel Scientific Computation
courses.description: Scientific computational algorithms on vector and parallel computers. Speed-up and algorithm complexity, interprocesses communication, synchronization, modern algorithms for linear systems, programming techniques, code optimization. Crosslisted with CS 4777.

courses.title: Quantum Information and Quantum Computing
courses.description: Introduction to quantum computing and quantum information theory, formalism of quantum mechanics, quantum gates, algorithms, measurements, coding, and information. Physical realizations and experiments. Crosslisted with PHYS 4782.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

courses.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

courses.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

courses.description: Courses on special topics of current interest in mathematics.

courses.title: Special Topics
courses.description: This course enables the school of Mathematics to comply with requests for courses in selected topics.

courses.title: Reading or Research
courses.description: Reading or research in topics of current interest.

courses.title: Introduction to Graduate Studies in Mathematics
courses.description: This course covers practical information helping students start their careers as a professional mathematician. It also satisfies the Georgia Tech RCR requirements for "in-person" training.

courses.title: Graph Theory and Combinatorial Structures
courses.description: Fundamentals, connectivity, matchings, colorings, extremal problems, Ramsey theory, planar graphs, perfect graphs. Applications to operations research and the design of efficient algorithms.

courses.title: Topology of Euclidean Spaces
courses.description: Metric spaces, normed linear spaces, convexity, and separation; polyhedra and simplicial complexes; surfaces; Brouwer fixed point theorem.

courses.title: Advanced Linear Algebra
courses.description: An advanced course in Linear Algebra and applications.

courses.title: Modern Abstract Algebra I
courses.description: Graduate-level linear and abstract algebra including groups, finite fields, classical matrix groups and bilinear forms, multilinear algebra, and matroids. First of two courses.

courses.title: Modern Abstract Algebra II
courses.description: Graduate-level linear and abstract algebra including rings, fields, modules, some algebraic number theory and Galois theory. Second of two courses.

courses.title: Probability Theory for Scientists and Engineers
courses.description: Classical introduction to probability theory including expectation, notions of convergence, laws of large numbers, independence, large deviations, conditional expectation, martingales, and Markov chains.

courses.title: Stochastic Processes in Finance II
courses.description: Advanced mathematical modeling of financial markets, derivative securities pricing, and portfolio optimization. Concepts from advanced probability and mathematics are introduced as needed.

courses.title: Probability I
courses.description: Develops the probability basis requisite in modern statistical theories and stochastic processes.  Topics of this course include measure and integration foundations of probability, distribution functions, convergence concepts, laws of large numbers, and central limit theory. First of two courses.

courses.title: Probability II
courses.description: Develops the probability basis requisite in modern statistical theories and stochastic processes.  Topics of this course include results for sums of independent random variables, Markov processes, martingales, Poisson processes, Brownian motion, conditional probability and conditional expectation, and topics from ergodic theory.  Second of two classes.

courses.title: Advanced Statistical Inference I
courses.description: Basic theories of statistical estimation, including optimal estimation in finite samples and asymptotically optimal estimation.  A careful mathematical treatment of the primary techniques of estimation utilized by statisticians.

courses.title: Testing Statistical Hypotheses
courses.description: Basic theories of testing statistical hypotheses, including a thorough treatment of testing in exponential class families.  A careful mathematical treatment of the primary techniques of hypothesis testing utilized by statisticians.

courses.title: Linear Statistical Models
courses.description: Basic unifying theory underlying techniques of regression, analysis of variance and covariance, from a geometric point of view.  Modern computational capabilities are exploited fully.  Students apply the theory to real data through canned and coded programs.

courses.title: Multivariate Statistical Analysis
courses.description: Multivariate normal distribution theory, correlation and dependence analysis, regression and prediction, dimension-reduction methods, sampling distributions and related inference problems, selected applications in classification theory, multivariate process control, and pattern recognition.

courses.title: Ordinary Differential Equations I
courses.description: This sequence develops the qualitative theory for systems of ordinary differential equations. Topics include stability, Lyapunov functions, Floquet theory, attractors, invariant manifolds, bifurcation theory, normal forms. First of two courses.

courses.title: Ordinary Differential Equations II
courses.description: This sequence develops the qualitative theory for systems of differential equations. Topics include stability, Lyapunov functions, Floquet theory, attractors, invariant manifolds, bifurcation theory, and normal forms.  Second of two courses.

courses.title: Functions of a Complex Variable I
courses.description: Complex integration, including Goursat's theorem; classification of singularities, the argument principle, the maximum principle; Riemann Mapping theorem; analytic continuation and Riemann surfaces; range of an analytic function, including Picard's theorem.

courses.title: Real Analysis I
courses.description: Lebesgue measure and integration, differentiation, abstract measure theory. Credit cannot be received for both MATH 6337 and MATH 6579.

courses.title: Real Analysis II
courses.description:
Continuation of MATH 6337.  L^p and Hilbert spaces, introduction to operator theory and functional analysis.
Credit cannot be received for both MATH 6338 and MATH 6580.

courses.title: Partial Differential Equations I
courses.description: Introduction to the mathematical theory of partial differential equations covering the basic linear models of science and exact solution techniques.

courses.title: Partial Differential Equations II
courses.description: This course covers the general mathematical theory of linear stationary and evolution problems plus selected topics chosen from the instructor's interests.

courses.title: Algebraic Geometry I
courses.description: The study of zero sets of polynomials: algebraic varieties, regular and rational mappings, the Zariski topology.

courses.title: Algebraic Geometry II
courses.description: A continuation of Algebraic Geometry I.

courses.title: Algebraic Topology I
courses.description: Simplicial homology.  Chain complexes and acyclic carriers. Simplicial approximation.  The exact homology sequence. Maps of spheres. Mayer-Vietoris sequence.

courses.title: Algebraic Topology II
courses.description: Continuation of MATH 6441. Singular homology.  Local homology and manifolds. CW complexes.  Cohomology. Duality in manifolds.

courses.title: General Topology
courses.description: Introduction to topological and metric spaces. Continuity, compactness, convergence, completion.  Product and quotient spaces.  Elementary homotopy.

courses.title: Differential Topology
courses.description: Manifolds. Differentiable structures.  Tangent bundles. Embeddings and immersions.  Maps on manifolds. Transversality.  Morse-Sard Theorem. Vector bundles.

courses.title: Geometric Topology
courses.description: Characteristic classes, Morse theory, three-manifolds, four-manifolds, symplectic and contact manifolds, knot theory.

courses.title: Differential Geometry I
courses.description: Core topics in differential, including: Lie groups, curvature, and relations with topology.

courses.title: Differential Geometry II
courses.description: Introduces students to topics of current interest in geometry.

courses.title: Industrial Mathematics I
courses.description: Applied mathematics techniques to solve real-world problems. Topics include mathematical modeling, asymptotic analysis, differential equations and scientific computation.  Prepares the student for MATH 6515.

courses.title: Measure Theory for Scientists and Engineers
courses.description:
An introduction to measure theory and Lebesgue integration with a focus on topics that tend to be of the most utility in
science and engineering. Credit cannot be received for both MATH 6337 and MATH 6579.

courses.title: Hilbert Spaces for Scientists and Engineers
courses.description:
Structure of linear operators in infinite dimensional spaces, applications.
  Credit cannot be received for both MATH 6338 and MATH 6580.

courses.title: Integral Equations and Transforms
courses.description: Volterra and Fredholm linear integral equations; relation to differential equations; solution methods; Fourier, Laplace, and Mellin transforms; applications to boundary value problems and integral equations.

courses.title: Special Functions of Higher Mathematics
courses.description: Gamma function; exponential function; orthogonal polynomials; Bessel, Legendre, and hypergeometric functions; application to singular ordinary differential equations; and separation of variables for partial differential equations.

courses.title: Numerical Methods in Finance
courses.description: Basic numerical and simulation techniques used in the pricing of derivative securities and in related problems in finance. Some programming experience required.

courses.title: Introduction to Numerical Methods for Partial Differential Equations
courses.description: Introduction to the implementation and analysis of numerical algorithms for the numerical solution of the classic partial differential equations of science and engineering. Must have knowledge of a computer programming language, familiarity with partial differential equations and elements of scientific computing.

courses.title: Advanced Numerical Methods for Partial Differential Equations
courses.description: Analysis and implementation of numerical methods for nonlinear partial differential equations including elliptic, hyperbolic, and/or parabolic problems. Must have knowledge of classic linear partial differential equations and exposure to numerical methods for partial differential equations at the level of MATH 6640 or numerical linear algebra at the level of MATH 6643.

courses.title: Numerical Linear Algebra
courses.description: Introduction to the numerical solution of the classic problems of linear algebra including linear systems, least squares, Singular value decomposition, eigenvalue problems. Crosslisted with CSE 6643.

courses.title: Iterative Methods for Systems of Equations
courses.description: Iterative methods for linear and nonlinear systems of equations including Jacobi, G-S, SOR, CG, multigrid, Newton quasi-Newton, updating, and gradient-based methods. Crosslisted with CSE 6644.

courses.title: Numerical Approximation Theory
courses.description: Theoretical and computational aspects of polynomial, rational, trigonometric, spline, and wavelet approximation.

courses.title: Numerical Methods for Ordinary Differential Equations
courses.description: Analysis and implementation of numerical methods for initial and two-point boundary value problems for ordinary differential equations.

courses.title: Numerical Methods for Dynamical Systems
courses.description: Approximation of the dynamical structure of a differential equation and preservation of dynamical structure under discretization. Must be familiar with dynamical systems and numerical methods for initial and boundary value problems in ordinary differential equations.

courses.title: Math Methods of Applied Sciences I
courses.description: Review of linear algebra and ordinary differential equations, brief introduction to functions of a complex variable.

courses.title: Math Methods of Applied Sciences II
courses.description: Review of vector calculus and its applications to partial differential equations.

courses.title: Modeling and Dynamics
courses.description: Mathematical methods for solving problems in the life sciences.  Models-based course on basic facts from the theory of ordinary differential equations and numerical methods of their solution.  Introduction to the control theory, diffusion theory, maximization, minimization and curve fitting.  Math majors may not use this course toward any degree in the School of Mathematics.

courses.title: Numerical Methods in Computational Science and Engineering I
courses.description: Introduction to numerical algorithms widely used in computational science and engineering. Numerical linear algebra, linear programming, and applications. Crosslisted with CSE 6710.

courses.title: Numerical Methods in Computational Science and Engineering II
courses.description: Efficient numerical techniques for solving partial differential equations and large-scale systems of equations arising from discretization of partial differential equations or variational problems in applications in science and engineering. Crosslisted with CSE 6711.

courses.title: Stochastic Processes in Finance I
courses.description: Mathematical modeling of financial markets, derivative securities pricing, and portfolio optimization.  Concepts from probability and mathematics are introduced as needed. Crosslisted with ISYE 6759.

courses.title: Stochastic Processes I
courses.description: Discrete time Markov chains, Poisson processes, and renewal processes. Transient and limiting behavior.  Average cost and utility measures of systems.  Algorithms for computing performance measures.  Modeling of inventories, and flows in manufacturing and computer networks. Crosslisted with ISYE 6761.

courses.title: Stochastic Processes II
courses.description: Continuous time Markov chains. Uniformization, transient and limiting behavior.  Brownian motion and martingales. Optional sampling and convergence.  Modeling of inventories, finance, flows in manufacturing and computer networks. Crosslisted with ISYE 6762.

courses.title: Design and Implementation of Systems to Support
courses.description: Computational Finance Introduction to large scale system design to support computational finance for options, stocks, or other financial instruments. Some programming experience, and previous exposure to stocks, bonds, and options required. Crosslisted with ISYE 6767.

courses.title: Fixed Income Securities
courses.description: Description, institutional features, and mathematical modeling of fixed income securities.  Use of both deterministic and stochastic models. Crosslisted with ISYE 6769.

courses.title: Statistical Techniques of Financial Data Analysis
courses.description: Fundamentals of statistical inference for models used in the modern analysis of financial data. Crosslisted with ISYE 6783.

courses.title: The Practice of Quantitative and Computational Finance
courses.description: Case studies, visiting lecturers from financial institutions, student group projects of an advanced nature, and student reports, all centered around quantitative and computational finance. Crosslisted with ISYE and MGT 6785.

courses.title: Advanced Topics in Quantitative and Computational Finance
courses.description: Advanced foundational material and analysis techniques in quantitative and computational finance. Crosslisted with ISYE 6793.

courses.title: Enumerative Combinatorics
courses.description: Fundamental methods of enumeration and asymptotic analysis, including the use of inclusion/exclusion, generating functions, and recurrence relations.  Applications to strings over a finite alphabet and graphs.

courses.title: Advanced Graph Theory
courses.description: Advanced topics in graph theory.  Selection of arguments varies every year.

courses.title: Combinatorics
courses.description: Fundamental combinatorial structures including hypergraphs, transversal sets, colorings, Sperner families, intersecting families, packings and coverings, perfect graphs, and Ramsey theory.  Algebraic and topological methods, applications.

courses.title: Probabilistic Methods in Combinatorics
courses.description: Applications of probabilistic techniques in discrete mathematics, including classical ideas using expectation and variance as well as modern tools, such as martingale and correlation inequalities.

courses.title: Stochastic Processes and Stochastic Calculus I
courses.description: An introduction to the Ito stochastic calculus and stochastic differential equations through a development of continuous-time martingales and Markov processes. First of two courses.

courses.title: Stochastic Processes and Stochastic Calculus II
courses.description: An introduction to the Ito stochastic calculus and stochastic differential equations through a development of continuous-time martingales and Markov processes. Continuation of MATH 7244.

courses.title: High-dimensional probability
courses.description: The goal of this PhD level graduate course is to provide a rigorous introduction to the methods of high-dimensional probability.

courses.title: High-dimensional statistics
courses.description: The goal of this PhD level graduate course is to provide a rigorous introduction to the methods of high-dimensional statistics.

courses.title: Harmonic Analysis
courses.description: Fourier analysis on the torus and Euclidean space.

courses.title: Functional Analysis
courses.description: Spectral theory of bounded and unbounded operators, major theorems of functional analysis, additional topics.

courses.title: Advanced Analysis
courses.description:
A comprehensive overview of advanced material in analysis. This is a Repeatable Course with 5 different subtitles;
Recommended prerequisites may vary with each offering.

courses.title: Graph Algorithms
courses.description: Algorithms for graph problems such as maximum flow, covering, matching, coloring, planarity, minimum cuts, shortest paths, and connectivity.  Crosslisted with ISYE 7510 and CS 7510.

courses.title: Calculus of Variations
courses.description: Minimization of functionals, Euler-Lagrange equations, sufficient conditions for a minimum; geodesic, isoperometric, and time of transit problems; variational principles of mechanics; applications to control theory.

courses.title: Tensor Analysis
courses.description: Review of linear algebra, multilinear algebra, algebra of tensors, co- and contravariant tensors, tensors in Riemann spaces, geometrical interpretation of skew tensors.

courses.title: Aural-Oral English Skills for Math ESL International Teaching Assistants
courses.description: Enhancement of English listening/speaking skills for SOM international graduate students, post-docs, and new faculty who speak English as their second language (ESL) and who will be teaching undergraduate students.

courses.title: Academic Communication for Intermediate ESL Math International Teaching Assistants
courses.description: Continued enhancement of English listening/speaking skills for current and future SOM graduate international teaching assistants and international lead instructors who speak English as their second language (ESL).

courses.title: Academic Communication for Advanced ESL Math International Teaching Assistants
courses.description: Continued enhancement of English listening/speaking skills for current and future SOM graduate international teaching assistants and international lead instructors who speak English as their second language (ESL).
